Quiz Results

Part 30 of 85 (Quiz Attempts 291-300)
← Prev Part 30 of 85 Next →

Quiz Attempt #119238

Total Questions: 30
Question 1
In horizontal analysis, each item is expressed as a percentage of the:
  • A.net income amount
  • B.stockholders’ equity amount
  • C.total assets amount
  • D.base year amount
Correct Answer: base year amount

Horizontal analysis converts each succeeding year’s balance to a percentage of the base year amount.

Question 2
Which of the following would be considered an investing activity and a source of cash?
  • A.Purchase of equipment
  • B.Sale of BBB’s stock held as an investment
  • C.Issuance of corporate stock
  • D.Receipt of interest on savings account
Correct Answer: Sale of BBB’s stock held as an investment

Sale of BBB’s stock held as an investment is covered under investing activity and is a source of cash. When investments are sold, there is an inflow of cash in the business. Thus, option B is the correct answer.

Question 3
Which of the following is not an example of cash equivalents?
  • A.Certificates of Deposit
  • B.Money market accounts
  • C.Money market mutual funds
  • D.Euro Bond
Correct Answer: Euro Bond

Cash and cash equivalents

GAAP defines cash equivalents as “short-term, highly liquid investments that are readily convertible to known amounts of cash and that are so near their maturity that they present insignificant risk of changes in value because of changes in interest rates”.

They are one of the three main asset classes, along with stocks and bonds. These securities have a low-risk, low-return profile and include:

• Current investments

• Cash & bank

• U.S. government Treasury bills,

• Bank certificates of deposit,

• Bankers' acceptances,

• Corporate commercial paper and

• Other money market instruments.

 

Euro bonds are not covered under the definition of cash and cash equivalents, thus, option D is the correct answer.

Question 4
Cash flow analysis is an important financial tool for an organization. Its advantages are:(a) Helps in internal cash management(b) Helps in external cash management(c) Helps in external financial management(d) Helps in internal financial managementCodes:
  • A.a, b, c & d
  • B.a, b, & d
  • C.a, b & c
  • D.a & b
Correct Answer: a, b, & d

Advantages of using cash flow statement are as follows:

(a) Helps the Internal Management

(b) Helps to make Cash Forecast

(c) Ascertaining Liquidity and Profitability Positions

(d) Ascertaining Optimum Cash Balance

(e) Cash Management

(f) Planning and Coordination

(g) Performance Appraisal by comparing the actual Cash Flow Statement with the projected Cash Flow Statements.

Question 5
Which of the following is not considered as cash equivalent?
  • A.Treasury bills
  • B.Commercial papers
  • C.Investment
  • D.Short term deposits with bank
Correct Answer: Investment

Cash and cash equivalents

GAAP defines cash equivalents as “short-term, highly liquid investments that are readily convertible to known amounts of cash and that are so near their maturity that they present insignificant risk of changes in value because of changes in interest rates”.

They are one of the three main asset classes, along with stocks and bonds. These securities have a low-risk, low-return profile and include:

• Current investments

• Cash & bank

• U.S. government Treasury bills,

• Bank certificates of deposit (Short term deposits with bank),

• Bankers' acceptances,

• Corporate commercial paper

• Other money market instruments.

Thus, investments are not considered as cash equivalents. Therefore, option C is the correct answer.

Question 6
How will you deal with increase in the balance of securities premium reserve while preparing a cash flow statement?
  • A.Cash flow from operating activities
  • B.Cash flow from investing activities
  • C.Cash flow from financing activities
  • D.Cash equivalent
Correct Answer: Cash flow from financing activities

Securities Premium Reserve records for premium collected over and above face value of the share. It may be in cash or for considerations other than cash. Cash Flow Statement shows the flow of cash. Treatment of any change in value of Securities Premium Reserve can be as follows:

If the Securities Premium increase due to premium collected on issue of securities (shares/debentures/bonds) for cash, the amount increased will be treated as cash flows from Financing Activity.

If there is increase in value of Securities Premium due to shares issued for consideration other than cash, it will not be recorded in cash flow statement.

If there is decrease in value of Securities Premium due to preliminary expense written off/share issue expense written off etc, it will not be recorded in cash flow statement.

Question 7
Dividend paid by a trading company is classified under which kind of activity while preparing cash flow statement?
  • A.Cash equivalent
  • B.Cash flow from operating activities
  • C.Cash flow from investing activities
  • D.Cash flow from financing activities
Correct Answer: Cash flow from financing activities

Interest and Dividend treatment in cash flow statement:

In case of a financial enterprise (whose main business is lending and borrowing), interest paid, interest received, and dividend received are classified as operating activities while dividend paid is a financing activity.

In case of a non-financial enterprise, as per AS-3, it is considered more appropriate that payment of interest and dividends are classified as financing activities whereas receipt of interest and dividends are classified as investing activities.

Therefore, dividend paid by a trading company is classified under financing activity while preparing cash flow statement.

Question 8
Which of the following is not a source of cash?
  • A.Dividend received
  • B.Purchase of machinery
  • C.Issue of shares
  • D.Sale of asset
Correct Answer: Purchase of machinery

Dividend received, issue of shares and sale of asset are sources of cash since they all involve inflow of cash.

Whereas purchase of machinery involves outflow of cash and therefore, is not a source of cash. Thus, option B is the correct answer.

Question 9
A ltd. is engaged in the business retailing of Air conditioners, investedRs. 25,00,000in the shares of a manufacturing company. Dividend received on this investment will be:
  • A.Cash flow from operating activities
  • B.Cash flow from investing activities
  • C.Cash flow from financing activities
  • D.Cash equivalent
Correct Answer: Cash flow from investing activities

A ltd. is a trading company and investment made by A ltd. is not in the form of a trade investment. Dividend received from non-trade investments is treated as cash flow from investing activity.

 

The word ‘Trade Investment’ has not been particularly defined in any of the Accounting Standards or Companies Act, 2013. Guidance Note on Revised Schedule VI to the Companies Act, 1956 (corresponding to Schedule III of the Companies Act, 2013) issued by the ICAI states that:

 

“The term ‘trade investment’ is normally understood as an investment made by a company in shares or debentures of another company, to promote the trade or business of the first company.” For example, Red Chilies Entertainment Private Limited (RCE) is in the business of production and distribution of movies. It invested in shares of PVR Pictures Private Limited (PVR) which is carrying on the business of distribution of movies under its brand name PVR. Therefore, this investment is promoting the business of RCE and so shall be ‘Trade Investment’.

 

All Investments other than trade Investments are referred to as Non-Trade Investments.

Question 10
Observing changes in financial variables across the year is termed as:
  • A.Vertical analysis
  • B.Horizontal analysis
  • C.Peer firm analysis
  • D.Industry analysis
Correct Answer: Horizontal analysis

Horizontal Analysis: When financial statement of one year are analyzed and interpreted after comparing with financial statements of another year or yers, it is termed as horizontal analysis. It can be based upon the ratios derived from the financial information over the same time span.

 

Vertical Analysis: When financial statement of single year is analyzed then it is called as vertical analysis. this analysis is useful in inter firm comparison. Every item of Profit and Loss account is expressed as a percentage of gross sales, while every item on a balance sheet is expressed as a percentage of total assets held by the firm.

 

Industry Analysis: An industry analysis is a business function completed by business owners and other individuals to assess the current business environment. This analysis helps businesses understand various economic pieces of the marketplace and how these various pieces may be used to gain a competitive advantage.

 

Peer-Firm Analysis: Companies most commonly use peer group analysis to evaluate compensation plans at other organizations and make sure theirs are competitive - an important strategy considering today's tight labor market. Companies identify their peers using factors such as industry, number of employees and geographic location, and then study the practices of those peers to make sure their own pay is up to snuff.

Thus, Option B is the correct answer.

Question 11
Which of the following items would be specifically included in the statement of cash flows constructed in compliance with AS-3? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2014)
  • A.Conversion of debt to equity
  • B.Acquiring an asset through lease
  • C.Operating and non-operating cash flow information
  • D.Purchasing a building by giving a mortgage to the seller
Correct Answer: Operating and non-operating cash flow information

Conversion of debt to equity will not be included in the statement of cash flows constructed in compliance with AS-3, since it does not relate to any of the three activities, that is, it does not relate to any inflow or outflow of cash from operating, investing, or financing activity.

Acquiring an asset through lease will not be included in the statement of cash flows constructed in compliance with AS-3 since it does involve any outflow or inflow of cash.

Operating and non-operating cash flow information is to be specifically included in the statement of cash flows constructed in compliance with AS-3 as Operating activities cover all the cash flows from ordinary activities of business and cash flow from non-operating activities is included in either investing or financing activities, depending upon the nature of cash flow.

Purchasing a building by giving a mortgage to the seller will not be included in the statement of cash flows constructed in compliance with AS-3, since it does not relate to any of the three activities, that is, it does not relate to any inflow or outflow of cash from operating, investing, or financing activity.

Question 12
Which of the following isnotreported in the statement of cash flows?
  • A.The net change in stockholders’ equity during the year
  • B.Cash payments for plant assets during the year
  • C.Cash receipts from sales of plant assets during the year
  • D.How acquisitions of plant assets during the year were financed
Correct Answer: The net change in stockholders’ equity during the year

The net change in stockholders’ equity during the year is not reported in the statement of cash flows.

Question 13
The statement of cash flows classifies cash receipts and cash payments by these activities:
  • A.operating andnonoperating
  • B.investing, financing, and operating
  • C.financing, operating, andnonoperating
  • D.investing, financing, andnonoperating
Correct Answer: investing, financing, and operating

Operating, investing, and financing activities are the three classifications of cash receipts and cash payments used in the statement of cash flows.

Question 14
Cash dividends paid to stockholders are classified on the statement of cash flows as:
  • A.an operating activity
  • B.an investing activity
  • C.a combination of (a) and (b)
  • D.a financing activity
Correct Answer: a financing activity

Cash dividends paid to stockholders are classified as a financing activity.

Question 15
Which is an example of a cash flow from a financing activity?
  • A.Receipt of cash from sale of land
  • B.Issuance of debt for cash
  • C.Purchase of equipment for cash
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Issuance of debt for cash

Issuance of debt for cash is a financing activity.

The receipt of cash for the sale of land is an investing activity.

The purchase of equipment for cash is an investing activity.

Question 16
Which of the following isincorrectabout the statement of cash flows?
  • A.The direct method may be used to report net cash provided by operating activities.
  • B.The statement shows the net cash provided (used) for three categories of activity.
  • C.The operating section is the last section of the statement.
  • D.The indirect method may be used to report net cash provided by operating activities.
Correct Answer: The operating section is the last section of the statement.

The operating section of the statement of cash flows is the first, not the last, section of the statement.

Question 17
Net income isRs. 132,000, accounts payable increasedRs. 10,000 during the year, inventory decreasedRs. 6,000 during the year, and accounts receivable increasedRs. 12,000 during the year. Under the indirect method, what is net cash provided by operating activities?
  • A.Rs. 102,000
  • B.Rs. 112,000
  • C.Rs. 124,000
  • D.Rs. 136,000
Correct Answer: Rs. 136,000

Net cash provided by operating activities is computed by adjusting net income for the changes in the three current asset/ current liability accounts listed.

 

An increase in accounts payable (Rs. 10,000) and a decrease in inventory (Rs. 6,000) are added to net income, while an increase in accounts receivable (Rs. 12,000) is subtracted from net income.

 

Rs. 132,000 + Rs. 10,000 + Rs. 6,000 - Rs. 12,000 = Rs. 136,000

Question 18
Items that are added back to net income in determining net cash provided by operating activities under the indirect method donotinclude:
  • A.depreciation expense
  • B.an increase in inventory
  • C.amortization expense
  • D.loss on disposal of equipment
Correct Answer: an increase in inventory

An increase in inventory is subtracted, not added, to net income in determining net cash provided by operating activities. The other options are incorrect because depreciation expense, amortization expense, and loss on disposal of equipment are all added back to net income in determining net cash provided by operating activities.

Question 19
The following data are available for a corporation:Net incomeRs. 200,000Depreciation expenseRs. 40,000Dividends paidRs. 60,000Gain on disposal of landRs. 10,000Decrease in accounts receivableRs. 20,000Decrease in accounts payableRs. 30,000Net cash provided by operating activities is:
  • A.Rs. 160,000
  • B.Rs. 220,000
  • C.Rs. 240,000
  • D.Rs. 280,000
Correct Answer: Rs. 220,000

Net cash provided by operating activities is Rs. 220,000 calculated as under:

 

Net income + Depreciation expense - Gain on disposal of land + Decrease in accounts receivable - Decrease in accounts payable

 

Rs. 200,000 + 40,000 - 10,000 + 20,000 - 30,000 = Rs. 220,000

Question 20
The following data are available for Orange Peels Corporation.Proceeds from sale of landRs. 100,000Proceeds from sale of equipmentRs. 50,000Issuance of EquityRs. 70,000Purchase of equipmentRs. 30,000Payment of cash dividendsRs. 60,000Net cash provided by investing activities is:
  • A.Rs. 120,000
  • B.Rs. 130,000
  • C.Rs. 150,000
  • D.Rs. 190,000
Correct Answer: Rs. 120,000

Net cash provided by investing activities is Rs. 120,000 calculated as under:

 

Sale of land + Sale of equipment - Purchase of equipment

 

100,000 + 50,000 - 30,000 = Rs. 120,000

 

Issuance of Equity and payment of cash dividends are financing activities.

Question 21
The following data are available for Something Strange!Increase in accounts payableRs. 40,000Increase in bonds payableRs. 100,000Sale of investmentRs. 50,000Issuance of SharesRs. 60,000Payment of cash dividendsRs. 30,000Net cash provided by financing activities is:
  • A.Rs. 90,000
  • B.Rs. 130,000
  • C.Rs. 160,000
  • D.Rs. 170,000
Correct Answer: Rs. 130,000

Net cash provided by financing activities is Rs. 130,000 calculated as follows:

 

Increase in bonds payable + Issuance of Shares - Payment of cash dividends

100,000 + 60,000 - 30,000 = Rs. 130,000

 

Increase in accounts payable is an operating activity and sale of investment is an investing activity.

Question 22
The statement of cash flows shouldnotbe used to evaluate an entity’s ability to:
  • A.earn net income
  • B.generate future cash flows
  • C.pay dividends
  • D.meet obligations
Correct Answer: earn net income

The statement of cash flows is not used to evaluate an entity’s ability to earn net income.

Question 23
Which of the following items is reported on a statement of cash flows prepared by the direct method?
  • A.Loss on disposal of building
  • B.Increase in accounts receivable
  • C.Depreciation expense
  • D.Cash payments to suppliers
Correct Answer: Cash payments to suppliers

Cash payments to suppliers are reported on a statement of cash flows prepared by the direct method.

 

Loss on disposal of building, increase in accounts receivable, and depreciation expense are reported in the operating activities section of the statement of cash flows when the indirect method is used.

Question 24
The beginning balance in accounts receivable isRs. 44,000, the ending balance isRs. 42,000, and sales during the period areRs. 129,000. What are cash receipts from customers?
  • A.Rs. 127,000
  • B.Rs. 129,000
  • C.Rs. 131,000
  • D.Rs. 141,000
Correct Answer: Rs. 131,000

Cash collections from customers amount to Rs. 131,000 i.e., Rs. 129,000 + Rs. 2,000.

 

Alternatively, we can prepare accounts receivable account:

Accounts Receivable Account

Particulars

(Amt. in Rs.)

Particulars

(Amt. in Rs.)

To balance b/d

44,000

By cash received (from customers) (Bal. fig.)

131,000

To Sales A/c

129,000

By balance c/d

42,000

 

173,000

 

173,000

 

Question 25
Cash flows from sale of fixed assets is treated as:
  • A.Cash flow from operating activities
  • B.Cash flow from investing activities
  • C.Cash flow from financing activities
  • D.Cash flow from sales activities
Correct Answer: Cash flow from investing activities

Cash flows from sale of fixed assets is treated as cash flow from investing activities.

Question 26
Summary financial information for a Company is as follows:December 31, 2017December 31, 2016Current Assets (CA)234,000180,000Non-Current Assets (NCA)756,000420,000Total Assets (TA)990,000600,000Compute the percentage changes in current assets, non-current assets and total assets, separately, in 2017 using horizontal analysis, assuming 2016 is the base year. Choose your answer from the options given below :
  • A.CA- 35%; NCA- 82% TA 63%
  • B.CA- 30%; NCA- 82% TA 66%
  • C.CA- 35%; NCA- 82% TA 68%
  • D.CA- 30%; NCA- 80% TA 65%
Correct Answer: CA- 30%; NCA- 80% TA 65%

Option D is correct.

 

Increase in 2017

 

Amount

Percentage

Current Assets

54,000

(234,000-180,000180,000 ×100) = 30%

Non-Current Assets

336,000

(756,000-420,000420,000 ×100) = 80%

Total Assets

990,000

(990,000-600,000180,000 ×100) = 65%

 

Question 27
Comparisons of data within a company are an example of the following comparative basis:
  • A.Industry averages
  • B.Intracompany
  • C.Intercompany
  • D.Both B and C
Correct Answer: Intracompany

Comparisons of data within a company are called intracompany comparisons. Intercompany comparisons are among companies.

Question 28
Thompson Corporation reported net sales ofRs. 300,000,Rs. 330,000, andRs. 360,000 in the years, 2015, 2016, and 2017, respectively. If 2015 is the base year, what is the trend percentage for 2017?
  • A.77%
  • B.108%
  • C.120%
  • D.130%
Correct Answer: 120%

The trend percentage for 2017 is 120% calculated as follows:

 

360,000300,000 = 120%

Question 29
The following schedule is a display of what type of analysis.Amount (inRs.)Percentage (%)Current Assets200,00025%Property, Plant and Equipment600,00075%Total Assets800,000Choose your answer from the options given below.Options:
  • A.Horizontal analysis
  • B.Differential analysis
  • C.Vertical analysis
  • D.Ratio analysis
Correct Answer: Vertical analysis

The data in the schedule is a display of vertical analysis because the individual asset items are expressed as a percentage of total assets.

Question 30
In vertical analysis, the base amount for depreciation expense is generally:
  • A.net sales
  • B.depreciation expense in a previous year
  • C.gross profit
  • D.fixed assets
Correct Answer: net sales

In vertical analysis, ‘net sales’ is used as the base amount for income statement items.

Quiz Attempt #119239

Total Questions: 40
Question 1
From the following information you are required to compute Return on Total Capital employed.(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2023)Net Profit Rs. 100,000Provision for tax Rs. 100,000Income from Investment Rs. 10,000Fixed Assets Rs. 450,000Current Assets Rs. 1,50,000Interest on debentures Rs. 10,000Reserves Rs. 100,000
  • A.30%
  • B.50%
  • C.60%
  • D.40%
Correct Answer: 40%

Return on Capital Employed = EBITCapital Employed × 100 ……(i)

Earnings before Interest and Tax = Net Profit + Provision for Tax + Interest on debentures (interest paid) – Income from Investment (Interest received)

 

Earnings before Interest and Tax =1,00,000 + 1,00,000 + 10,000 – 10,000 = 2,00,000 ….. (ii)

 

Capital Employed = Total Assets – Total Outside Liabilities ……. (iii)

 

Total Assets = Fixed Assets + Current Assets = 4,50,000 + 1,50,000 = 6,00,000

 

Total Outside Liabilities = Provision for Taxation = 1,00,000

 

Putting values of Total Assets and Total Outside Liabilities in (iii) above, Capital Employed = 6,00,000 – 1,00,000 = 5,00,000

 

Putting the values of (ii) and (iii) in (i) above,

 

Return on Capital Employed = 2,00,0005,00,000 × 100 = 40%

Question 2
Which of the following ratios are critically significant for an investor?(UGC NET Commerce Dec 2023)a. Debt-Equity ratiob. Price-Earningratioc. Dividend yieldd. Asset turnover ratioe. Debtor turnover ratioChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.a, b and c only
  • B.d and e only
  • C.b, c and d only
  • D.a, d and e only
Correct Answer: a, b and c only

For an investor, certain financial ratios are particularly important because they provide insights into different aspects of a company's financial health and performance.

 

Let's analyze each ratio to determine its significance for an investor:

a. Debt-Equity Ratio: This ratio measures a company's financial leverage by comparing its total liabilities to its shareholders' equity. It's significant for investors as it indicates the level of risk associated with the company's debt levels.

b. Price-Earning Ratio (P/E Ratio): This ratio compares a company's current share price to its earnings per share (EPS). It's critical for investors as it helps in assessing whether a stock is overvalued or undervalued and provides insights into the company's future growth prospects.

c. Dividend Yield: This ratio shows how much a company pays out in dividends each year relative to its share price. It is important for investors, especially those looking for income through dividends, as it reflects the return on investment from dividends.

d. Asset Turnover Ratio: This ratio measures the efficiency of a company's use of its assets in generating sales revenue. While useful, it is more critical for operational efficiency assessment rather than direct investment decisions.

e. Debtor Turnover Ratio: This ratio measures how quickly a company collects cash from its credit sales. It is more relevant for understanding the company's credit policies and cash flow management rather than direct investment decisions.

Based on this analysis, the ratios that are critically significant for an investor are Debt-Equity Ratio, Price-Earning Ratio and Dividend Yield.

Therefore, the correct answer is option A.

Question 3
The current ratio of a company is 2:1 Which one the following suggestions would improve the current ratio?(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2024)
  • A.Purchase of stock for cash
  • B.Cash collection from debtors
  • C.Pay a current liability
  • D.Purchase of fixed assets
Correct Answer: Pay a current liability

To determine which option would improve the current ratio of a company, let’s first understand what the current ratio represents. The current ratio is calculated as:

 

Current Ratio= Current AssetsCurrent Liabilities

 

Now, given Current Ratio: 2:1, this means that for every 2 units of current assets, there is 1 unit of current liabilities. Thus, to improve current ratio, either the current assets must increase, or current liabilities must decrease.

 

Let us now analyze each of the given question:

 

(A) Purchase of stock for cash: This transaction does not affect the current ratio because both current assets (stock) and cash are current assets. While stock increases one component, cash decreases by the same amount, leaving the overall current assets unchanged.

 

(B) Cash collection from debtors: This transaction also does not affect the current ratio. Collecting cash from debtors converts one current asset (accounts receivable) into another (cash), resulting in no overall change in current assets.

 

(C) Pay a current liability: This option improves the current ratio. When a company pays off a current liability, current liabilities decrease while current assets remain the same, which increases the current ratio. For example, if current liabilities reduce while current assets remain constant, the overall ratio increases.

 

(D) Purchase of fixed assets: This transaction does not directly affect the current ratio. When a company uses current assets (like cash) to purchase fixed assets, current assets decrease while non-current assets increase, leading to a lower current ratio.

 

Thus, the correct answer is option (C).

Which is the value of P/V Ratio?(UGC NET Management Dec 2023)Period IPeriod IISales (Rs.)700000900000Profit (Rs.)-1000010000
  • A.10%
  • B.20%
  • C.30%
  • D.25%
Correct Answer: 10%

The explanation is discussed below.

 

 

Question 5
If Current Ratio = 2.5, Liquid Ratio = 1.5, Working Capital = Rs. 90,000. What is the value of Inventory?(UGC NET Management Dec 2023)
  • A.Rs. 60,000
  • B.Rs. 90,000
  • C.Rs. 1,50,000
  • D.Rs. 2,10,000
Correct Answer: Rs. 60,000

Current Ratio = Current AssetsCurrent Liabilities …….. (i)

 

Liquid Ratio = Current Assets - InventoryCurrent Liabilities ………(ii)

 

Working Capital = Current Assets – Current Liabilities

 

According to given information, Current Assets = 90,000 + Current Liabilities ……..(iii)

 

Putting value of Current Assets from Equation (iii) in Equation (i), we get

 

2.5 = 90,000 + Current LiabilitiesCurrent Liabilities

 

Therefore, Current Liabilities = Rs. 60,000 and Current Assets = Rs. 1,50,000

 

Now, putting all the values in Equation (ii), we will get the value of Inventory

 

1.5 = 1,50,000 - Inventory60,000

 

Or, Inventory = Rs. 60,000

Question 6
From the following information:Year20212022SalesRs. 32,00,000Rs. 57,00,000Profit/ LossRs. 3,00,000Rs. 7,00,000What is the value of P/V Ratio?(UGC NET Management Jun 2024)
  • A.16%
  • B.40%
  • C.12.5%
  • D.25%
Correct Answer: 16%

Change in Profit = 7,00,000-3,00,000 = Rs 4,00,000

Change in Sales = 57,00,000-32,00,000 = Rs 25,00,000

 

 

Question 7
Given below are two statements: (UGC NET Management June 2022)Statement I:Interest coverage ratio indicates how many times fixed interest charges are earned, based on the earnings available to pay these expenses.Statement II:One minus the reciprocal of interest coverage ratio indicates how far earnings could decline before it would be impossible to pay the interest charges from current earnings.In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are true.
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are false.
  • C.Statement I is true but Statement II is false.
  • D.Statement I is false but Statement II is true.
Correct Answer: Both Statement I and Statement II are true.

Both Statement I and Statement II are true.

Statement I: Interest coverage ratio indicates how many times fixed interest charges are earned, based on the earnings available to pay these expenses.

The interest coverage ratio is a financial metric that measures a company's ability to meet its fixed interest charges. It is calculated by dividing the earnings before interest and taxes (EBIT) by the interest expense. The result indicates how many times a company can cover its interest charges with its earnings. A higher interest coverage ratio suggests a better ability to meet interest obligations.

 

Statement II: One minus the reciprocal of the interest coverage ratio indicates how far earnings could decline before it would be impossible to pay the interest charges from current earnings.

This statement is a correct interpretation of the interest coverage ratio. The interest coverage ratio is calculated as EBIT/Interest Expense. Taking the reciprocal of this ratio provides a measure of how far earnings could decline before the company would be unable to cover its interest charges. Subtracting this value from 1 gives an indication of the margin of safety or cushion available before reaching a point where the company might struggle to meet its interest obligations.

Question 8
The following data are available from the annual report of a company: (UGC NET Jun 2013)Current Assets ₹ 4,80,000; Current Liabilities ₹ 3,00,000; Average total assets ₹ 20,00,000; Operating income ₹ 2,40,000; Average total equity ₹ 8,00,000; Net income ₹ 80,000. Which of the following statement is correct?
  • A.Return on equity exceeds the return on assets.
  • B.Working capital is ₹ 12,00,000.
  • C.Current Ratio is 0.625 to 1.
  • D.None of the above.
Correct Answer: Return on equity exceeds the return on assets.

(A) ROE = Annual Net IncomeEquity Shareholder's Funds × 100

80,0008,00,000 × 100 = 10%

ROA = Annual Net Income after tax (Net profit after tax)Average Total Assets × 100 = 10%

= 80,00020,00,000× 100 = 4%

Therefore, option A is correct.

(B) Working capital = Current Assets – Current liabilities

= Rs. 4,80,000 – 3,00,000 = Rs. 1, 80,000, therefore statement B is incorrect.

 

(C) Current Ratio = Current AssetsCurrent Liablities = 4,80,0003,00,000 = = 1.6, therefore statement C is incorrect.

Question 9
DUPONT analysis refers to (UGC NET Management Dec 2013)
  • A.EarningPer Share = (Net Profit / Number of Equity Shares)
  • B.Return on Assets =NetProfitMarginTotalAssestsTurnoverRatio
  • C.Total Assets Turnover Ratio =SalesAverageTotalAssests
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: None of the above

The DuPont system of financial analysis was developed by DuPont Corporation in 1919, which is used around the world today and serves as the basis of components that make up return on equity. Du Pont breaks up ROE (Return on Equity) into net profit margin, asset turnover and financial leverage that is represented by equity multiplier. To calculate the return on equity using the DuPont model, simply multiply the three components (i.e., net profit margin, asset turnover, and equity multiplier*). In simple words, it breaks down the ROE to analyze how corporates can increase the return on equity for their shareholders.

Return on Equity = Net Profit Margin × Asset Turnover × Equity Multiplier

ROE = Net IncomeSales×Sales Total Assets×Total AssetsShareholder's Equity

The company can increase its Return on Equity if it:

  • generates a high Net Profit Margin.
  • effectively uses its assets to generate more sales.
  • has a high financial leverage.

 

* Equity Multiplier: It is possible for a company with terrible sales and margins to take on excessive debt and artificially increase its return on equity. The equity multiplier, a measure of financial leverage, allows the investor to see what portion of the return on equity is the result of debt.

Question 10
A high debtor’s turnover ratio indicates (UGC NET Management Sep 2013)
  • A.low amount tied upon debtors
  • B.increase in sales turnover
  • C.efficient conversion of debtors into cash
  • D.A & C
Correct Answer: A & C

Debtor's turnover ratio is calculated as = Net Credit Sales/ Average Debtors

​A high debtor's turnover ratio indicates that the company is efficiently converting its debtors into cash, suggesting effective management of receivables.

It also indicates a low amount tied up in debtors, as higher turnover means faster collection of cash from debtors.

So, option (D) "A & C" is correct.

Question 11
JK Ltd. has earned 8% return on total assets of ₹ 50,00,000and has a Net Profit Ratio of 5%. Find out the sales of the firm. (UGC NET Jun 2013)
  • A.₹ 4,00,000
  • B.₹ 2,80,000
  • C.₹ 80,00,000
  • D.₹ 83,33,333
Correct Answer: ₹ 80,00,000

Net Profit Margin = Net ProfitNet Sales×100

 

So, according to question, 5= 4,00,000Net Sales ×100

 

Therefore, net sales = Rs. 80,00,000

Note that Net profit = Rs. 4,00,000 as it is given 8% of total assets of Rs. 50,00,000.

Question 12
The average speed between the cost of goods sold and the sales revenue is indicated by: (UGC NET Management Jun 2015)
  • A.Operating Expense Ratio
  • B.Gross Profit Ratio
  • C.Net Profit Ratio
  • D.Return on Equity
Correct Answer: Gross Profit Ratio

It is also known as ‘Gross Profit Margin’. It is the ratio of gross profit of a business to its revenue. It is a profitability ratio measuring that proportion of revenue which is converted into gross profit (i.e., revenue less cost of goods sold). A high Gross Profit Margin is a favourable sign of good management.

 

Gross Profit = Gross ProfitNet Sales×100

Question 13
Debt management ratios do not include (UGC NET Management Jul 2016)
  • A.Times-interest-earned ratio
  • B.EBITDA coverage ratio
  • C.Debt ratio
  • D.Price/Cash flow ratio
Correct Answer: Price/Cash flow ratio

(A) Times-interest-earned ratio measures the company's ability to cover its interest expenses using its earnings before interest and taxes (EBIT).

(B) EBITDA coverage ratio evaluates the company's ability to cover its interest, taxes, and other fixed charges using earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (EBITDA).

(C) Debt ratio assesses the proportion of a company's assets financed by debt.

However, (D) Price/Cash flow ratio is not typically considered a debt management ratio.

Question 14
Credit sales of a firm in a certain year amounted to ₹ 12,00,000and the sundry debtors outstanding at the beginning and the end of the year amounted to ₹ 1,20,000 and ₹ 80,000 respectively. Indicate the correct code for the debtors’ turnover ratio and the average collection period from the following: (UGC NET Management Jan 2017)
  • A.10 and 1.2 months
  • B.12 and 1 month
  • C.15 and 0.8 month
  • D.6 and 2 months
Correct Answer: 12 and 1 month

Debtors’ Turnover Ratio = Net Credit SalesAverage Trade Receivables

 

= 12,00,0001,20,000+80,0002 = 12

Average Collection period = Number of days/months/weeks in a yearDebtors Turnover Ratio  

 

= 1212   = 1 month.

Question 15
Indicate the correct code for the liquidity ratios from the following: (UGC NET Management Jan 2017)a. Current Ratiob. Acid Test/Quick Ratioc. Total Assets Turnover Ratiod. Defensive-Interval Ratio
  • A.a, b, and c
  • B.b, c, and d
  • C.a, b, and d
  • D.a, c, and d
Correct Answer: a, b, and d

Total assets turnover ratio is an activity ratio.

Rest all are liquidity ratio. Therefore, the correct answer is option C.

Question 16
Authorised capital of a company is ₹ 5 lacs; 40% of it is paid up. Loss incurred during the year is ₹ 50,000. Accumulated loss carried from last year is ₹ 2 lac. The company has a Tangible Net Worth of: (UGC NET Management Jul 2018)
  • A.₹ 2 lacs
  • B.₹ 2.50 lacs
  • C.₹ (−)50,000
  • D.₹ 7,50,000
Correct Answer: ₹ (−)50,000

Paid-up share capital = 40% × 500000 = 200000

Loss = 50000

Accumulated loss = 200000

Tangible net worth = Paid-up share capital – current year loss – accumulated = 200000 – 50000 – 200000 = Rs. (-) 50,000

Question 17
Debt Service Coverage Ratio indicates which one of the following? (UGC NET Management Jul 2018)
  • A.Effective utilisation of assets.
  • B.Number of times fixed assets cover borrowed funds.
  • C.Excess of Current Assets over Current Liabilities.
  • D.Number of times surplus covers interest and instalments of Term Loans.
Correct Answer: Number of times surplus covers interest and instalments of Term Loans.

Debt Service Coverage Ratio (DSCR) is one of the coverage ratios, calculated to know the cash profit availability to repay the debt including interest. Essentially, DSCR is calculated when a firm takes a loan from bank / financial institution / any other loan provider. This ratio suggests the capability of cash profits to meet the repayment of the financial loan. DSCR is very important from the viewpoint of the financing authority, as it indicates the repaying capability of the entity taking a loan. Normally, DSCR of 1.5 to 2 is satisfactory.

 

DSCR = Earnings available for debt servicesDebt Service

 

Debt Service = Interest + Instalments

 

Earning for debt service includes Net profit (Earning after taxes) + Non-cash operating expenses like depreciation and other amortizations + Interest + Other adjustments like loss on sale of fixed assets etc.

Thus, option D is the correct answer.

Question 18
Net profit after taxes of a firm is Rs.1,00,000and its fixed interest charges on long term debt areRs. 20,000. What is the interest coverage ratio if the rate of income tax is 60%? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2022)
  • A.13 times
  • B.13.5 times
  • C.12.5 times
  • D.5 times
Correct Answer: 13.5 times

The interest coverage ratio measures the ability of a company to meet its interest obligations. It is calculated by dividing the earnings before interest and taxes (EBIT) by the interest expense.

 

Interest Coverage Ratio = EBITInterest

 

Now, earning after Tax (EAT) = EBIT – Interest – Tax

Therefore, EBIT = EAT + Interest + Tax

 

Or, EBIT = 1,00,000 + 20,000 + 60% of (EBIT – Interest)

 

Let EBIT be x, then the required equation will be:  x = 1,20,000 + 60100 (x-20,000)

 

or x=2,70,000

 

Now, Interest Coverage Ratio = EBITInterest = 2,70,00020.000= 13.5

 

Therefore, the correct answer is option B i.e., 13.5 times.

Question 19
Match List IwithList II: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022)List I (Earnings- Valuation ratios)a. Price- Earnings (P-E) ratiob. Earnings Yield Ratioc. Price- Book (P/B) ratiod. Relative P/E ratioList II (Underlying Description(s))i. Stock price divided by accounting net worth.ii. Firm's P/E ratio divided by an index P/E ratio.iii. Stock price divided by the earnings per share.iv.Earningper share divided by stock price.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.a- ii, b- iv, c-i, d- iii
  • B.a-i, b- iv, c- iii, d- ii
  • C.a- ii, b- iii, c- iv, d-i
  • D.a- iii, b- iv, c-i, d- ii
Correct Answer: a- iii, b- iv, c-i, d- ii

Match List I with List II: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022)

List I (Earnings- Valuation ratios) - List II (Underlying Description(s))

a. Price- Earnings (P-E) ratio - Stock price divided by the earnings per share

b. Earnings Yield Ratio - Earning per share divided by stock price

c. Price- Book (P/B) ratio - Stock price divided by accounting net worth

d. Relative P/E ratio - Firm's P/E ratio divided by an index P/E ratio

Question 20
The following information with respect to a company is given below: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022)Net profit before tax =Rs. 1,00,00010% Preference share capital (Rs. 10 each) =Rs. 1,00,000Equity share capital (Rs. 10 each) =Rs. 1,00,000Taxation at 50% of Net profit.Which one among the following is the earning per share?
  • A.Zero
  • B.Rs. 4
  • C.Rs. 10
  • D.Rs. 40
Correct Answer: Rs. 4

EPS = Net Income After Tax - Preference dividendTotal Number of Outstanding Equity Shares

Net Income after Tax = Net profit before tax – tax = 1,00,000 – 50,000 = 50,000

Preference dividend = 10% of 1,00,000 = 10,000

No. of Outstanding Equity Shares = 10000

EPS = 50,000-10,00010000 = Rs. 4

Question 21
The information with respect to a company is: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022)EBIT =Rs35 Lakhs15% Term loan =Rs. 50 LakhsWorking capital term loan from bank @ 20% =Rs. 30 Lakhs10% Preference share capital =Rs. 10 lakhsPublic deposits accepted @ 14% =Rs. 15 LakhsWhich one among the following is the Interest Coverage Ratio for the company?
  • A.0.45
  • B.1.98
  • C.2.24
  • D.2.59
Correct Answer: 2.24

Interest Coverage Ratio = Net Profit before Interest and TaxInterest on long-term debt

 

Interest on long term debt = 15% Interest on term loan of Rs. 50 Lakh + 20% Interest on Working capital term loan of Rs. 30 Lakh + 14% Interest on Public deposits of Rs. 15 Lakh

 

Thus, Interest on long term debt = 7,50,000 + 6,00,000 + 2,10,000 = Rs 15,60,000

 

Putting in the values in Interest Coverage Ratio = 35,00,00015,60,000 = 2.24 times

Question 22
Given below are two statements, one is labelled as Assertion A and the other is labelled as Reason R (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2021)Assertion A:Quick ratio is a more penetrating test of liquidity than the current ratio, yet a high quick ratio does not necessarily imply sound liquidity.Reason R:A company with a high value of quick ratio can suffer from a shortage of funds if it has slow‐paying, doubtful and long duration outstanding debtorsIn light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both A and R are correct, and R is the correct explanation of A
  • B.Both A and R are correct but R is NOT the correct explanation of A
  • C.A is correct but R is not correct
  • D.A is not correct but R is correct
Correct Answer: Both A and R are correct, and R is the correct explanation of A

Both A and R are correct, and R is the correct explanation of A.

 

The quick ratio establishes the relationship between quick or liquid assets and current liabilities. Quick assets mean current assets excluding inventory. The exclusion of inventory is for the reason that it is not easily and readily convertible into cash. 

 

Standard norm of quick ratio is 1:1 means for every 1 dollar of Quick liabilities; Quick assets should be 1 dollar. A Quick ratio is considered as a better test of liquidity than Current ratio. But Quick ratio itself may not be taken as a conclusive test of liquidity. A high Quick ratio along with a higher Current ratio is favourable which indicates a good short-term liquidity and debt repayment capacity of the firm. Even if the Current ratio is high, a low Quick ratio does not indicate a good debt repayment capacity of the firm. A company with a high value of Quick ratio can suffer from the shortage of funds if it has slow paying, doubtful and long duration outstanding debtors.

Question 23
Match List IwithList II (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2020)List II. Inability to pay interestII. Liquidity crisisIII. Inefficient collection of receivablesIV. Return of shareholder’s fund being much higher than the overall return on investmentList II1. Current ratio2. Debt turnover ratio3. Interest coverage ratio4. Debts equity ratioChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.I-3, II-1, III-2, IV-4
  • B.I-3, II-2, III-1, IV-4
  • C.I-2, II-3, III-1, IV-4
  • D.I-1, II-2, III-3, IV-4
Correct Answer: I-3, II-1, III-2, IV-4

Inability to pay interests: Interest coverage ratio

The interest coverage ratio is a debt ratio and profitability ratio used to determine how easily a company can pay interest on its outstanding debt. The Interest coverage ratio is also called “times interest earned.” Lenders, investors, and creditors often use this formula to determine a company's riskiness relative to its current debt or for future borrowing.

 

Liquidity crisis: Current ratio

The current ratio is a liquidity ratio that measures a company's ability to pay short-term obligations or those due within one year. It tells investors and analysts how a company can maximize the current assets on its balance sheet to satisfy its current debt and other payables.

 

Inefficient collection of receivables: Debt turnover ratio

The receivables/debt turnover ratio is an accounting measure used to quantify a company's effectiveness in collecting its receivables or money owed by clients. The ratio shows how well a company uses and manages the credit it extends to customers and how quickly that short-term debt is collected or is paid. The receivables turnover ratio is also called the accounts receivable turnover ratio.

 

Return of shareholder’s fund being much higher than the overall return on investment: Debts equity ratio

The debt-to-equity (D/E) ratio is calculated by dividing a company’s total liabilities by its shareholder equity. These numbers are available on the balance sheet of a company’s financial statements. It is a measure of the degree to which a company is financing its operations through debt versus wholly owned funds. More specifically, it reflects the ability of shareholder equity to cover all outstanding debts in the event of a business downturn.

Question 24
When current ratio is 2:1 and if there are equal increases in current assets and current liabilities then what would be the result? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2020)
  • A.No change in current ratio
  • B.Increase in current ratio
  • C.Decrease in current ratio
  • D.Current ratio will double
Correct Answer: Decrease in current ratio

When the current ratio is 2:1, an equal increase in current assets and current liabilities would decrease the current ratio.

Let us understand this through an example;

Current Assets = Rs.100000 and Current Liabilities = Rs.50000

Current ratio = Current assets / Current liabilities

                       = 100000 / 50000

                       = 2:1 

Now let us increase the current assets and current liabilities by Rs. 50000 and calculate the new current ratio;

 Current ratio = 150000/100000

                        = 1.5:1.

Question 25
A firm has inventory turnover of 3 and cost of goods sold is RS.2,70,000. With better inventory management, the inventory turnover is increased to 5. This would result in (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2018)
  • A.Decrease in inventory by Rs.36,000
  • B.Increase in inventory by Rs.54,000
  • C.Decrease in inventory by Rs.90,000
  • D.Increase in cost of goods sold by Rs.20,000
Correct Answer: Decrease in inventory by Rs.36,000

Inventory Turnover Ratio = Cost of Goods SoldAverage Inventory

 

Therefore, taking this Ratio as 3, let the average inventory be Xo;

3 = 2,70,000Xo

 

X0 = 90,000 (average inventory)

 

Taking this Ratio as 5, let the average inventory be Xn;

 

5 = 2,70,000Xn

 

Now, the new inventory value (Xn) comes out at Rs. 54,000

 

Therefore, there is a reduction in average inventory = Xn – X0 = 90,000 – 54,000 = 36,000

Question 26
Which one of the following statements is not true? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2018)
  • A.Long-term liabilities due for payment within a year should be treated as current liabilities.
  • B.Cost of sales is a better numerator than sales while calculating stock turnover.
  • C.Conversion of debentures into preference shares will decrease debt-equity ratio.
  • D.Higher operating ratio indicates higher profits.
Correct Answer: Higher operating ratio indicates higher profits.

(i) The statement A is correct as Current liabilities are a company's debts or obligations that are due within one year or within a normal operating cycle. Furthermore, current liabilities are settled by the use of a current asset, such as cash, or by creating a new current liability. Current liabilities appear on a company's balance sheet and include short-term debt, accounts payable, accrued liabilities, and other similar debts.

 

(ii) The statement B is correct as inventory is at cost and not on the company's books at selling prices. Let's illustrate the ratio with the following amounts: Sales for the year Rs. 800,000; Cost of Goods Sold for the year Rs. 600,000; Inventory (average amount at cost during the year) Rs. 200,000. Inventory Turnover Ratio = Rs. 600,000 divided by Rs. 200,000 = 3 times. On average the inventory turned over approximately 3 times during the year.

 

Had Sales been used in the ratio, it would indicate that the inventory had turned over 4 times (Sales of Rs. 800,000 divided by Rs. 200,000 of Inventory), which is not the case. While some organizations do use Sales in the calculation, it is not logical to divide selling prices by cost. The resulting ratio is not reality.

 

Further to explanation, the inventory turnover ratio is an effective measure of how well a company is turning its inventory into sales. The ratio also shows how well management is managing the costs associated with inventory and whether they're buying too much inventory or too little.

 

The higher the inventory turnover, the better it is since a high inventory turnover typically means a company is selling goods very quickly and that demand for their product exists.

 

Low inventory turnover, on the other hand, would likely indicate weaker sales and declining demand for a company’s products.

 

(iii) The Statement C is correct because the conversion of debentures into preference shares will decrease debt-equity ratio as this will reduce the long-term debts but increase the shareholder’s funds.

 

(iv) The statement D is incorrect as a low operating ratio means a high net profit ratio (i.e., more operating profit) and vice versa. The concept of Operating Ratio is explained below:

 

Operating ratio (also known as operating cost ratio or operating expense ratio) is computed by dividing operating expenses of a particular period by net sales made during that period. Like expense ratio, it is expressed in percentage.

 

Formula:

Operating ratio is computed as follows:

 

Operating Ratio = Operating ExpensesNet Sales ×100

 

 

The basic components of the formula are operating cost and net sales. Operating cost is equal to cost of goods sold plus operating expenses. Non-operating expenses such as interest charges, taxes etc., are excluded from the computations.

 

The operating ratio is used to measure the operational efficiency of the management. It shows whether or not the cost component in the sales figure is within the normal range. A low operating ratio means a high net profit ratio (i.e., more operating profit) and vice versa.

 

The ratio should be compared: (1) with the company’s past years ratio, (2) with the ratio of other companies in the same industry. An increase in the ratio should be investigated and brought to attention of management as soon as possible. The operating ratio varies from industry to industry.

Question 27
Which one of the following is correct? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2011)(i) Liquidity ratios measure long term solvency of a concern.(ii) Inventory is a part of liquid assets.(iii) Rule of thumb for acid test ratio is 2: 1.(iv) The amount of gross assets is equal to net capital employed.
  • A.(i), (ii) and (iv)
  • B.(ii), (iii) and (iv)
  • C.(i), (ii), (iii) and (iv)
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: None of the above

None of the given statements is correct.

 

Statement (i) is incorrect. Liquidity ratios are also known as ‘Short-term solvency Ratios’. These are financial ratios that indicates whether a company's current assets will be sufficient to meet the company's obligations when they become due. Liquidity or short-term solvency means ability of a business to pay its short-term liabilities.

 

Statement (ii) is incorrect. Liquid Assets/ Quick Assets would include cash in hand, cash at bank, sundry debtors excluding bad debts and readily marketable securities. Prepaid expenses and stock are not taken as liquid assets.

 

Statement (iii) is incorrect. Rule of thumb for current ratio is 2:1.

 

Statement (iv) is incorrect. Gross assets include all assets, while net capital employed is calculated by deducting liabilities from gross assets, resulting in a lower figure.

Question 28
Which one of the following is correct? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2011)(i) A ratio is an arithmetical relationship of one number to another number.(ii) Liquid ratio is also known as acid test ratio.(iii) Rule of thumb for current ratio is 2: 1.(iv) Debt equity ratio is the relationship between outsiders’ fund and shareholders’ fund.
  • A.All (i), (ii), (iii) and (iv) are correct.
  • B.Only (i), (ii) and (iii) are correct.
  • C.Only (ii), (iii) and (iv) are correct.
  • D.Only (ii) and (iii) are correct.
Correct Answer: All (i), (ii), (iii) and (iv) are correct.

(i) A ratio is an arithmetical relationship of one number to another number. This statement is generally correct and defines the concept of a ratio.

 

(ii) Liquid ratio is also known as acid test ratio. This is correct. The liquid ratio (or quick ratio) is known as the acid test ratio, as it measures a company's ability to meet its short-term obligations using its most liquid assets.

 

(iii) Rule of thumb for current ratio is 2:1. This is a common rule of thumb suggesting that a healthy current ratio is generally considered to be 2:1. However, it's important to note that this is a guideline and may vary by industry.

 

(iv) Debt equity ratio is the relationship between outsiders’ fund and shareholders’ fund. This is correct. The debt-equity ratio represents the proportion of a company's financing that comes from debt compared to equity.

Question 29
Assertion ‘A’:A high operating ratio indicates a favourable position.Reasoning ‘R’: A high operating ratio leaves a high margin to meet non-operating expenses.(UGC NET Commerce Jul 2018)
  • A.A’ and ‘R’ both are correct and ‘R’ correctly explains ‘A’.
  • B.Both ‘A’ and ‘R’ are correct but ‘R’ does not explain ‘A’.
  • C.Both ‘A’ and ‘R’ are incorrect.
  • D.‘A’ is correct but ‘R’ is incorrect.
Correct Answer: Both ‘A’ and ‘R’ are incorrect.

The operating ratio is determined by comparing the cost of the goods sold and other operating expenses with net sales.

 

Operating ratio=COGS+Operating ExpensesNet Sales×100

 

This ratio is a test of the efficiency of the management in their business operation. It is a means of operating efficiency. Lower the operating ratio, the better is the position because greater is the profitability and management efficiency of the concern. The higher the ratio, the less favorable is the situation, because there will be smaller margin of profit available for the purpose of payment of dividend and creation of reserves.

 

Therefore, both (A) and (R) are incorrect.

Question 30
Match the items of List-I with those of List-II and indicate the correct code: (UGC NET Commerce Jan 2017)List – Ia. Acid Test Ratiob. Operating Ratioc. Debt Equity Ratiod. Stock Turnover RatioList – IIi. Profitability analysisii. Activity analysisiii. Liquidity analysisiv. Long-term solvency analysis
  • A.a-ii, b-i, c-iii, d-iv
  • B.a-ii, b-iii, c-iv, d-i
  • C.a-iii, b-iv, c-i, d-ii
  • D.a-iii, b-i, c-iv, d-ii
Correct Answer: a-iii, b-i, c-iv, d-ii

List – I - List – II

a. Acid Test Ratio - Liquidity analysis

The Quick Ratio is known as Acid Test Ratio.The quick assets are defined as those assets which are quickly convertible into cash. While calculating quick assets, we exclude the closing inventories and other current assets such as prepaid expenses, advance tax, etc., from the current assets. Because of exclusion of non-liquid current assets, it is considered better than current ratio as a measure of liquidity position of the business.

 

Quick Ratio = Quick or Liquid AssetsCurrent Liabilities

 

b. Operating Ratio - Profitability analysis

The operating ratio shows the efficiency of a company's management by comparing the total operating expense of a company to net sales. The operating ratio shows how efficient a company's management is at keeping costs low while generating revenue or sales. The smaller the ratio, the more efficient the company is at generating revenue versus total expenses.

 

Operating Profit Ratio = EBITNet Sales×100

 

c. Debt Equity Ratio - Long-term solvency analysis

It refers to the ratio of total liabilities of a business to its shareholders' equity. It is a leverage ratio and it measures the degree to which the assets of the business are financed by the debts and the shareholders' equity of a business. Lower values of debt-to-equity ratio are favorable indicating less risk. Debt to Equity Ratio indicates financial leverage of a firm. Generally, debt-equity ratio of 2:1 is considered safe.

Debt to Equity Ratio = Total outsider's Liabilities or Total DebtsShareholder's Equity

 

 

d. Stock Turnover Ratio - Activity analysis

It is an efficiency ratio which calculates the number of times per period a business may sell or replace its entire batch of inventories. In other words, this ratio indicates that how fast inventory is used or sold.

Inventory Turnover Ratio = COGS/ SalesAverage Inventories

Question 31
When opening stock isRs50,000, closing stock isRs60,000 and the cost of goods sold isRs2,20,000, the stock turnover ratio is: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2015)
  • A.2 times
  • B.3 times
  • C.4 times
  • D.5 times
Correct Answer: 4 times

Inventory Turnover Ratio = COGSAverage Inventories

Putting the given values in the above ratio,

Inventory Turnover Ratio = 2,20,000(50,000+60,000)/2 = 4 times.

Question 32
If: Stock turnover ratio is = 6 times (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2015)Average stock ₹ 8,000Selling price is = 25% above costWhatis the amount of gross profit?
  • A.₹ 2,000
  • B.(B) ₹ 4,000
  • C.(C) ₹ 10,000
  • D.(D) ₹ 12,000
Correct Answer: (D) ₹ 12,000

Inventory turnover ratio (ITR) is an activity ratio and is a tool to evaluate the liquidity of company’s inventory. It measures how many times a company has sold and replaced its inventory during a certain period of time.

 

Inventory Turnover Ratio = Cost of Good SoldAverage Stock

 

6 = Cost of Good Sold8000

COGS = 48,000

Sale = 25% above cost = 60,000.

Gross Profit = Sales – COGS

 

Gross Profit = 60,000 – 48000 = Rs.12,000

Question 33
Current Ratio 2.5, Liquid Ratio 1.5, and Working Capital ₹ 60,000. What is Current Assets? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2014)
  • A.₹ 60,000
  • B.₹ 80,000
  • C.₹ 1,00,000
  • D.₹ 1,20,000
Correct Answer: ₹ 1,00,000

Working Capital = Current Assets – Current Liabilities

60,000 = CA – CL

CA = 60,000 + CL………(1)

 

CR = Current AssetsCurrent Liabilities

 

2.5 = CACL

CA = 2.5CL…………..(2)

 

Combining (1) and (2)

2.5CL = 60,000 + CL

CL = 40,000

So, CA = 1,00,000.

Question 34
The Debt-Equity Ratio of a company is 2: 1. In this relation, match the following:(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2014)List – I(a) Issue of equity shares(b) Cash received from debtors(c) Redemption of debentures(d) Purchased goods on creditList – II1. No change on the ratio2. Reduce the ratio3. No change on the ratio4. Reduce the ratio
  • A.a-1, b-2, c-3, d-4
  • B.a-2, b-3, c-4, d-1
  • C.a-1, b-3, c-4, d-2
  • D.a-2, b-4, c-1, d-3
Correct Answer: a-2, b-3, c-4, d-1

Debt-To-Equity Ratio is the ratio of long-term debt to equity ratio and is used to determine the leverage that a business has taken on. To derive the ratio, divide the long-term debt of an entity by the aggregate amount of its common stock and preferred stock. When the ratio is comparatively high, it implies that a business is at greater risk of bankruptcy, since it may not be able to pay for the interest expense on the debt if its cash flows decline. The formula is:

Debt-Equity Ratio=Long-term DebtCommon stock + Preferred stock

When Debt-Equity Ratio of a company is 2: 1, then:

- Issue of equity shares will - Reduce the ratio (Because Equity is increased, and Debt is same as earlier)

- Cash received from debtors will result in - No change on the ratio (Because both the items are from current assets and doesn’t have impact on long term debt and equity).

- Redemption of debentures will - Reduce the ratio (Because debt is decreased, and Equity is same as earlier).

- Purchased goods on credit will result in - No change on the ratio (Because both the items are of current nature, creditor is current liability and stock is current assets, therefore, it doesn’t have impact on long term debt and equity).

Question 35
The DuPont approach breaks down the earnings power on the shareholders' book value (RoE) as (UGC NET Management Jun 2019)
  • A.Net Profit Margin × Total Assets Turnover × Equity Multiplier
  • B.Total Assets Turnover × Gross Profit Margin ×Debt Ratio
  • C.Total Assets Turnover ×Net Profit Margin
  • D.Total Assets Turnover ×Gross Profit Margin ×Equity Multiplier
Correct Answer: Net Profit Margin × Total Assets Turnover × Equity Multiplier

The Dupont analysis also called the Dupont model is a financial ratio based on the return on equity ratio that is used to analyze a company’s ability to increase its return on equity.

The Dupont analysis is an expanded return on equity formula, calculated by multiplying the net profit margin by the asset turnover by the equity multiplier.

ROE = Net Profit Margin × Asset Turnover × Equity Multiplier

where:

ROE = Return on Equity

Net Profit Margin= Net Income / Net Sales​

Asset Turnover= Net Sales / Average Total Assets

​Equity Multiplier= Total Assets / Total Equity

Question 36
Which one the following describes the relationship between market value of a firm’s securities and replacement cost of its physical assets? (UGC NETManagementJun 2020)
  • A.Tobin’s q- ratio
  • B.Residual analysis
  • C.Retention ratio
  • D.Book to price ratio
Correct Answer: Tobin’s q- ratio

Tobin’s Q Ratio was given by James Tobin and William Brainard. Replacement value is the cost that a company would incur in re-building the business, minus liabilities. Firms with higher Tobin's Q ratio tend to be those firms with attractive investment opportunities.

Tobin’s Q Ratio = Net Market CapitalizationReplacement Value

Question 37
A firm’s current assets and current liabilities areRs1600 andRs1000 respectively. How much it can borrow on a short-term basis without reducing the current ratio below 1.25? (UGC NETManagementJun 2020)
  • A.Rs2000
  • B.Rs1200
  • C.Rs1400
  • D.Rs1080
Correct Answer: Rs1400

Current ratio = current assets current liabilities

= 16001000

= 1.6

If the borrowings are made on short term basis then the current liabilities will increase plus current assets will also increase by the cash received from short term borrowing.

New current ratio should be 1.25

Let the amount will be borrowed be x

Current ratio = (1600 +  x) (1000+x)

1.25 = (1600 +  x) (1000+x)

1.25 (1000 + x) = 1600 + x

1250 + 1.25x = 1600 + x

0.25 x = 350

X = 1400

Question 38
As per Du Pont equation for ROE, other things remaining constant, which of the following statements is false? (UGC NET Management Dec 2022)a. An increase in the net profit margin will increase the ROE.b. A decrease in debt to asset ratio will increase the ROE.c. A decrease in return on assets will decrease the ROE.d. An increase in the average asset turnover will increase the ROE.e. An increase in equity multiplier will increase the ROE.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.b only
  • B.c, d only
  • C.a, e only
  • D.a, c only
Correct Answer: b only

Only Statement “b. A decrease in debt to asset ratio will increase the ROE” is wrong. The DuPont system of financial analysis was developed by DuPont Corporation in 1919, which is used around the world today and serves as the basis of components that make up return on equity. Du Pont breaks up ROE (Return on Equity) into net profit margin, asset turnover and financial leverage that is represented by equity multiplier. To calculate the return on equity using the DuPont model, simply multiply the three components (i.e., net profit margin, asset turnover, and equity multiplier*). In simple words, it breaks down the ROE to analyze how corporates can increase the return on equity for their shareholders.

Return on Equity = Net Profit Margin × Asset Turnover × Equity Multiplier

 

ROE = Net IncomeSales×Sales Total Assets×Total AssetsShareholder's Equity

The company can increase its Return on Equity if it:

generates a high Net Profit Margin.

effectively uses its assets to generate more sales.

has a high financial leverage.

 

* Equity Multiplier: It is possible for a company with terrible sales and margins to take on excessive debt and artificially increase its return on equity. The equity multiplier, a measure of financial leverage, allows the investor to see what portion of the return on equity is the result of debt.

Question 39
If a company's current ratio declined in a year during which its quick ratio improved, which of the following is the most likely explanation? (UGC NET Management June 2022)
  • A.Inventory is increasing
  • B.Inventory is declining
  • C.Receivables are being collected more rapidly than in the past
  • D.Receivables are being collected more slowly than in the past
Correct Answer: Inventory is declining

If a company’s current ratio declined in a year during which its quick ratio improved, then inventory must be declining.

 

Rates of receivables recovery does not impact current ratio, because receivables when converted into cash, the impact will be zero. Thus, certainly option C and option D cannot be the answer.

 

Considering option, A:

 

Current Ratio = Current AssetsCurrent Liabilities and

 

Quick Ratio (in terms of inventory only) = Current Assets-InventoryCurrent Liabilities

 

Now, according to option A, if inventory is increasing, then Current Ratio must improve instead of declining and Quick Ratio will decline. Therefore, option A cannot be the answer.

 

Considering option B:

Now, according to option B, if inventory is declining, then Current Ratio must be declining, and Quick Ratio will improve. Therefore, option B is correct.

Question 40
Du Pont analysis formula involves which financial elements for computation of earning power? (UGC NET Management Jun 2021)
  • A.Net profit margin, Total assets turnover and Equity multiplier
  • B.Total assets turnover and sales turnover profitability
  • C.Profit margin, Sales turnover and Asset‐use efficiency
  • D.Total assets turnover and Equity multiplier
Correct Answer: Net profit margin, Total assets turnover and Equity multiplier

Du Pont Analysis is a useful technique used to decompose the different drivers of return on equity (ROE). An investor can use Du Pont Analysis to compare the operational efficiency of two similar firms. Managers can use Du Pont analysis to identify strengths or weaknesses that should be addressed. It is an expanded return on equity formula, calculated by multiplying the net profit margin by the asset turnover by the equity multiplier.

 

DuPont Analysis = Net Profit Margin × Asset Turnover × Equity Multiplier

 

where:

 

Net Profit Margin = Net IncomeRevenue

 

Asset Turnover = SalesAverage Total Assets

 

Equity Multiplier = Average Total AssetsAverage Shareholder's Equity

 

Therefore, option A is correct.

Quiz Attempt #119240

Total Questions: 34
Question 1
If the current ratio is 2:1 and working capital isRs. 60,000, what is the value of the Current Assets? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2012)
  • A.Rs.60,000
  • B.Rs.1,00,000
  • C.Rs.1,20,000
  • D.Rs. 1,80,000
Correct Answer: Rs.1,20,000

Numeric explanation as per question:

Working Capital = Current Assets – Current Liabilities

60,000 = CA – CL

CA = 60,000 + CL………(1)

 

CR = Current AssetsCurrent Liabilities

 

2 = CACL

CA = 2CL…………..(2)

 

Combining (1) and (2)

2CL = 60,000 + CL

CL = 60,000

So, CA = 1,20,000.

Question 2
Given below are two statements: (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2012)I. Activity ratios show where the company is going.II. Balance Sheet ratios show where the company stand.
  • A.I is correct, but II is wrong.
  • B.Both I and II are correct.
  • C.I is wrong, but II is correct.
  • D.Both I and II are wrong.
Correct Answer: Both I and II are correct.

Financial ratio analysis is very useful tool because it simplifies the process of financial comparison of two or more businesses. Direct comparison of financial statements is not efficient due to difference in the size of relevant businesses. Financial ratio analysis makes the financial statements comparable both among different businesses and across different periods of a single business.

Financial ratio analysis is the process of calculating financial ratios, which are mathematical indicators calculated by comparing key financial information appearing in financial statements of a business, and analyzing those to find out reasons behind the business’s current financial position and its recent financial performance, and develop expectation about its future outlook.

 

These ratios can be broadly classified into:

Liquidity ratio: A liquidity ratio is a financial ratio that indicates whether a company's current assets will be sufficient to meet the company's obligations when they become due.

 

Solvency Ratio: Solvency ratio is one of the various ratios used to measure the ability of a company to meet its long-term debts.

 

Profitability ratio: Profitability ratio evaluates the company's ability to generate income against expenses and other cost associated with the generation of income.

 

Activity/turnover Ratio: An activity ratio is a metric which determines the ability of a company to convert its balance sheet accounts into revenue. It depicts how a company is performing.

 

Balance sheet ratios are financial metrics that include only balance sheet items and determine relationships between different aspects of a company’s financial position. It depicts the financial position of a business.

Question 3
When the Debt Turnover Ratio is 4, what is the average collection period, assuming 360 days in a year? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2012)
  • A.5 months
  • B.4 months
  • C.3 months
  • D.2 months
Correct Answer: 3 months

Average Collection Period =3604=3 Months (90 days)

Question 4
Assertion “A”:Ratio analysis is one of the tools employed to know the financial health of a concern.Reason “R”:Ratio analysis is not the only technique available to take investment decision.(UGCNET Commerce Dec 2012)
  • A.Both “A” and “R” are true and “R” is the correct explanation of “A”.
  • B.Both “A” and “R” are true, but “R” is incorrect explanation of “A”.
  • C.“A” is true, but “R” is false.
  • D.“A” is false, but “R” is true.
Correct Answer: Both “A” and “R” are true and “R” is the correct explanation of “A”.

Financial statement analysis is the process of analyzing a company's financial statements for decision making purposes and to understand the overall health of an organization. Following are some of methods of analysis of Financial Statements:

1) Comparative Statement Analysis

Comparative statement analysis is an analysis of financial statementat different period of time. When financial statements figures for two or more years are placed side-by-side to facilitate comparison, these are called 'Comparative Financial Statements.' Such statements not only show the absolute figures of various years but also provide for columns to indicate the increase or decrease in these figures from one year to another. In addition, these statements may also show the change from one year to another in percentage form.

Comparative financial statements is classified into 2 major parts:

-Comparative Balance Sheet Analysis: Comparative balance sheet analysis concentrates only the balance sheet of the concern at different periods of time. Under this analysis the balance sheets are compared with previous year’s figures or one-year balance sheet figures are compared with other years.

- Comparative Profit and Loss Account Analysis: Another comparative financial statement analysis is comparative profit and loss account analysis. Under this analysis, only profit and loss account is taken to compare with previous year’s figure or compare within the statement. This analysis helps to understand the operational performance of the business concern in a given period.

 

2) Trend Analysis

The financial statements may be analyzed by computing trends of series of information. It may be in upward or downward directions which involve the percentage relationship of each and every item of the statement with the common value of 100%. In other words, this method involves the calculation of percentages relationship that each statement bears to the same item in the base year. The base year may be any one of the periods involved in the analysis but the earliest period is mostly taken as the base year. This trend percentage can be represented in various ways. They may be shown in ahorizontal or vertical manner. They can be plotted on a chart or on a graph with the help of slotting curves. They are sometimes calculated using the trend “X” asindex.

 

3) Common Size Analysis

Another important financial statement analysis technique is common size analysis in which figures reported are converted into percentage to some common base. Common size statement is that statement which gives only the vertical percentages or ratios for financing data. In the balance sheet the total assets figures is assumed to be 100 and in profit and loss account, sales figure (total revenue) is assumed to be 100 and all figures are expressed as a percentage of this total. It is one of the simplest methods of financial statement analysis, which reflects the relationship of each and every item with the base value of 100%.

 

4) Fund Flow Statement

It helps to understand the changes in the financial position of a business enterprise between the beginning and ending financial statement dates. It is also called as statement of sources and uses/application of funds.

Fund flow statement has three separate statements:

- Statement showing changes in working capital.

- Statement showing funds from operations

- Statement of fund flow

 

5) Cash Flow Statement

Cash flow statement is a statement which shows the sources of cash inflow and uses of cash out-flow of the business concern during a particular period of time. It is the statement, which involves only short-term financial position of the business concern. Cash flow statement provides a summary of operating, investment and financing cash flows and reconciles them with changes in its cash and cash equivalents such as marketable securities. Institute of Chartered Accountants of India issued the Accounting Standard (AS-3) related to the preparation of cash flow statement in 1998.

 

6) Ratio Analysis

Financial ratio analysis is very useful tool because it simplifies the process of financial comparison of two or more businesses. Direct comparison of financial statements is not efficient due to difference in the size of relevant businesses. Financial ratio analysis makes the financial statements comparable both among different businesses and across different periods of a single business.

Financial ratio analysis is the process of calculating financial ratios, which are mathematical indicators calculated by comparing key financial information appearing in financial statements of a business, and analyzing those to find out reasons behind the business’s current financial position and its recent financial performance, and develop expectation about its future outlook.

These ratios can be broadly classified into:

- Liquidity ratio

- Solvency Ration

- Profitability ratio

- Activity/turnover Ratio

Question 5
Match the items of List – I with the items of List – II and select the correct answer using the codes given below the lists: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2012)List – I(a) Leverage Ratio(b) Liquidity Ratio(c) Turnover Ratio(d) Profitability RatioList – II(i) Short-term solvency(ii) Earning capacity(iii) Relationship between debt and equity(iv)Efficiency of Asset Management
  • A.(a)-(ii), (b)-(i), (c)-(iv), (d)-(iii)
  • B.(a)-(iii), (b)-(ii), (c)-(i), (d)-(iv)
  • C.(a)-(iv), (b)-(iii), (c)-(i), (d)-(ii)
  • D.(a)-(iii), (b)-(i), (c)-(iv), (d)-(ii)
Correct Answer: (a)-(iii), (b)-(i), (c)-(iv), (d)-(ii)

Financial ratio analysis is very useful tool because it simplifies the process of financial comparison of two or more businesses. Direct comparison of financial statements is not efficient due to difference in the size of relevant businesses. Financial ratio analysis makes the financial statements comparable both among different businesses and across different periods of a single business.

These ratios can be broadly classified into:

  • Liquidity ratio: Also called Short-term Solvency Ratios attempt to measure the ability of a firm to meet its short-term financial obligations. A liquidity ratio is a financial ratio that indicates whether a company's current assets will be sufficient to meet the company's obligations when they become due.
  • Solvency Ratio: Also known as leverage ratios is used to measure the ability of a company to meet its long-term debts. Ex. Debt equity ratio.
  • Profitability ratio: Profitability ratio evaluates the company's ability to generate income against expenses and other cost associated with the generation of income.

Activity/turnover Ratio: An activity ratio is a metric which determines, how efficiently a firm manages its assets or the ability of a company to convert its balance sheet accounts into revenue.

Question 6
Which one of the following will not affect the working capital? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2012)
  • A.Realization of cash from debtors.
  • B.Sale of plant and machinery in cash.
  • C.Issue of equity shares.
  • D.Redemption of debentures.
Correct Answer: Realization of cash from debtors.

Working capital indicates liquidity levels of companies for managing its daily expenses.

Working Capital = Current Assets – Current liabilities.

Working capitalis the difference between a company’s current assets, such as (customers’ unpaid bills) and inventories of raw materials and finished goods, and its current liabilities, such as accounts payable.

Current assets are short-term assets either in form of cash or a cash equivalent which can be liquidated within 12 months or within an accounting period. Ex. cash, accounts receivable, inventories of raw materials and finished goods, etc. Decrease in current asset results in inflow of funds in the business.

Current Liabilities are short-term liabilities of a business which are expected to be settled within 12 months or within an accounting period. Increase in current liabilities results in inflow of funds in the business. Ex. Accounts payable, bank overdraft, etc.

As per the question:

Realization of cash from debtors’ leads to Increase in Cash and Decrease in Debtor; and both are components of current assets, hence the difference gets offset. Therefore, this will not affect the working capital.

Question 7
Consider the following:(i) Basic defensive interval ratio(ii) Current ratio(iii) Super-quick ratio(iv) Quick ratioArrange these ratios in sequence to reflect the liquidity in descending order.
  • A.(ii), (iv), (iii) and (i)
  • B.(i), (ii), (iv) and (iii)
  • C.(iv), (ii), (iii) and (i)
  • D.(iii), (iv), (i) and (ii)
Correct Answer: (ii), (iv), (iii) and (i)
