The current ratio is a liquidity ratio that measures a company's ability to pay short-term obligations or those due within one year. It tells investors and analysts how a company can maximize the current assets on its balance sheet to satisfy its current debt and other payables.

 

Quick Ratio, (also known as acid test ratio) is a liquidity ratio which measures per dollars/rupees of liquid current assets available per dollar/rupees of current liabilities. Liquid current assets are current assets which can be quickly converted to cash without any significant decrease in their value. Liquid current assets typically include cash, marketable securities and receivables. Quick ratio is expressed as a number instead of a percentage. Optimum quick ratio is 1:1. Ratio is high when quick assets increase or current liabilities decrease.

 

Super acid test or super quick ratio, that measures liquidity in even more strict terms. This ratio treats only cash, bank deposits and investments in different securities as current assets and excludes money receivables from current assets. A company with a high super quick ratio is keeping most of the money in its own pocket. A good sign if the company owes you money, but not a very good sign for the owners of the company. A high super quick ratio means that the company is keeping its cash idle. That’s not a very smart way of doing business.

 

The defensive interval ratio (DIR), also called the defensive interval period (DIP) or basic defense interval (BDI), is a financial metric that indicates the number of days that a company can operate without needing to access noncurrent assets.

Question 8
Which of the following ratios are taken into consideration by a banker before sanctioning the loan? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2013)
  • A.Proprietary Ratio
  • B.Stock-Turnover Ratio
  • C.Debt-Equity Ratio
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: Debt-Equity Ratio

Debt-to-Equity Ratio: Debt-to-Equity ratio is the ratio of total liabilities of a business to its shareholders' equity. It is a leverage ratio and it measures the degree to which the assets of the business are financed by the debts and the shareholders' equity of a business. Lower values of debt-to-equity ratio are favorable indicating less risk. Debt to Equity Ratio indicates Financial Leverage of a firm.

Debt-equity ratio=Total LiabilitiesShareholders'Equity

Inventory turnover is the number of times a company sells and replaces its stock of goods during a period. Inventory turnover provides insight as to how the company manages costs and how effective their sales efforts have been.

- The higher the inventory turnover, the better since a high inventory turnover typically means a company is selling goods very quickly and that demand for their product exists.

- Low inventory turnover, on the other hand, would likely indicate weaker sales and declining demand for a company’s products.

- Inventory turnover provides insight as to whether a company is managing its stock properly.

The proprietary ratio (also known as net worth ratio or equity ratio) is used to evaluate the soundness of the capital structure of a company. This ratio shows the proportion of total assets of a company which are financed by proprietors' funds.

Question 9
The most suitable coverage ratio for deciding the debt capacity of a firm is? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2013)
  • A.Interest Coverage Ratio
  • B.Cash Flow Coverage Ratio
  • C.Debt Service Coverage Ratio
  • D.Fixed Assets Coverage Ratio
Correct Answer: Cash Flow Coverage Ratio

A Coverage ratio is a type of financial ratio which indicates the ability of a firm to pay off the outsiders’ obligations. Normally, a ratio greater than 1 implies a sound position of a firm to pay off the liability or obligation under concern.

Debt Service Coverage Ratio

Debt Service Coverage Ratio (DSCR), one of the coverage ratios, calculated in order to know the cash profit availability to repay the debt including interest. Essentially, DSCR is calculated when a firm takes a loan from bank / financial institution / any other loan provider. This ratio suggests the capability of cash profits to meet the repayment of the financial loan. DSCR is very important from the viewpoint of the financing authority as it indicates the repaying capability of the entity taking a loan.Normally DSCR of 1.5 to 2 is satisfactory.

 

DSCR = Earnings available for debt servicesDebt Services

 

Debt Service = Interest & Lease Payment + Principal Payment

Earning for debt service includes Net profit (Earning after taxes) + non-cash operating expenses like depreciation and other amortizations + Interest + other adjustments like loss on sale of Fixed Asset etc.

 

Times Interest Earned Ratio: Times interest earned ratio (also called interest coverage ratio) is an indicator of the company’s ability to pay off its interest expense with available earnings. It is a measure of a company’s solvency, i.e., its long-term financial strength. It calculates how many times a company’s operating income (earnings before interest and taxes) can settle the company’s interest expense. A higher times interest earned ratio indicates that the company’s interest expense is low relative to its earnings before interest and taxes (EBIT) which indicates better long-term financial strength, and vice versa.

If this Ratio is less than 1, it indicates the inability of firm’s profit to serve, its interest on debts.

Times Interest Earned Ratio = Earnings before Interest and TaxInterest Expense

 

Preference Dividend Coverage Ratio: Dividend Coverage Ratio essentially calculates the capacity of the firm to pay the dividend. Generally, this ratio is calculated specifically for preference equity shareholders. Preference shareholders have right to receive dividends. The dividends may be postponed but payment is compulsory and therefore they are considered as a fixed liability.

Preference Dividend Coverage Ratio = Profit After TaxPreference Dividend

 

Similarly, Equity Dividend Coverage Ratio is given by:

Equity Dividend Coverage Ratio = Profit After Tax-Prefeence DividendEquity Dividend

 

Fixed Charge Coverage: This ratio shows how many times the cash flow before interest and taxes covers all fixed financing charges. This ratio is more than 1 is considered as safe.

Fixed Charge Coverage = EBIT + Depreciation Interest + Repayment of Loans1-tax rate

 

Total Cash Flow Coverage Ratio: Total Cash Flow Coverage Ratio is a coverage ratio which considers the cash flows in place of the profits. It is because the payment of all kinds of fixed charges will be met from the cash but not from the profits. It sounds more appropriate to use cash flow as numerator instead of profits. Profits may be a result of non-cash transactions in the earnings statements.

Question 10
Which of the following is a non-operating expense? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2013)
  • A.Salary of Managing Director
  • B.Depreciation
  • C.Advertisement expenditure
  • D.Interest on loan
Correct Answer: Interest on loan

Operating expenses are the costs a business incurs as part of its regular business activities, not including the cost of goods sold. Here are some examples:

Ex. Administrative expenses, Office supplies, Salaries for administrative personnel, Commissions, marketing and advertising, Rent and utilities.

Depreciation represents the periodic, scheduled conversion of a fixed asset into anexpense as the asset is used during normal business operations. Since the asset is part of normal business operations, depreciation is considered an operating expense. 

 

A non-operating expense is an expense incurred by a business that is unrelated to the business' core operations. The most common types of non-operating expenses are interest on loan taken, loss by theft, pay expenses due to a lawsuit, loss on sale of fixed asset, etc.

Question 11
Which of the following comes under efficiency ratios? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2013)
  • A.Average collection period
  • B.Inventory turnover ratio
  • C.Fixed assets turnover ratio
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: All of the above

The efficiency ratio (also known an activity ratio) is typically used to analyze how well a company uses its assets and liabilities internally. An efficiency ratio can calculate the turnover of receivables, the repayment of liabilities, the quantity and usage of equity, and the general use of inventory and machinery. 

Some common efficiency ratios are accounts receivable turnover, fixed asset turnover ratio, sales to inventory ratio, sales to net working capital ratio, accounts payable to sales ratio and inventory turnover ratio.

Question 12
The appropriate ratio for indicating liquidity crisis is _______. (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2013)
  • A.Operating ratio
  • B.Sales turnover ratio
  • C.Current ratio
  • D.Acid test ratio
Correct Answer: Acid test ratio

Quick Ratio: Quick ratio (also known as acid test ratio) is a liquidity ratio which measures per dollars/rupees of liquid current assets available per dollar/rupees of current liabilities. Liquid current assets are current assets which can be quickly converted to cash without any significant decrease in their value. Liquid current assets typically include cash, marketable securities and receivables. Quick ratio is expressed as a number instead of a percentage. Optimum quick ratio is 1:1. Ratio is high when quick assets increase or current liabilities decrease.

Quick Ratio = Current Assets-Inventories-Prepaid ExpenseCurrent Liabilities

Therefore, it is most appropriate ratio for indicating liquidity crisis.

 

Current Ratio: Current ratio is one of the most fundamental liquidity ratios. It measures the ability of a business to repay current liabilities with current assets. Optimum current ratio is 2:1. Ratio is high when current assets increase or current liabilities decrease.

 

Current Ratio = Current AssetsCurrent Liabilities

The main elements of current assets are Inventories, Sundry Debtors, Cash and Bank Balances, Receivables/Accruals, Loans and Advances, Disposable Investments.

The Current liabilities include Creditors for goods and services, short term loans, Bank overdraft, Cash Credit, Outstanding Expenses, Provision for taxation, Proposed Dividend and Unclaimed dividend.

 

Operating Ratio: The operating ratio shows the efficiency of a company's management by comparing the total operating expense of a company to net sales. The operating ratio shows how efficient a company's management is at keeping costs low while generating revenue or sales. The smaller the ratio, the more efficient the company is at generating revenue versus total expenses.

Operating Ratio = Cost of Goods Sold+ Operating ExpensesNet Sales×100

 

Where Operating Expenses is equal to Office and Admin Expenses + Selling and Distribution Expenses.

Operating Ratio + Operating Profit Ratio = 100%

 

Sales turnover is frequently used to mean how rapidly a company uses up its inventory. 

Question 13
Generally, which of the following are the important items appearing on the assets side of the Balance Sheet of a Commercial Bank?(a) Cash in hand(b) Bills discounted(c) Money at call and short notice(d) Loans and advances(e) InvestmentsWhich of the following sequence is correct in the order of liquidity?
  • A.(a), (b), (d), (c) and (e)
  • B.(a), (c), (b), (e) and (d)
  • C.(b), (d), (c), (a) and (e)
  • D.(c), (d), (b), (e) and (a)
Correct Answer: (a), (c), (b), (e) and (d)

The balance sheet of a commercial bank provides a picture of its functioning. It is a statement which shows its assets and liabilities on a particular date at the end of one year.

Question 14
Which of the formula is used to calculate Absolute Liquid Ratio? (UGC NET Commerce Sep 2013)
  • A.CurrentAssets,Loans&Advances-InventoriesCurrentLiabilities&Provisions-BankOverdraft
  • B.CurrentAssets,Loans&AdvancesCurrentLiabilities&Provisions
  • C.AbsoluteliquidAssetsCurrentLiabilities
  • D.AbsoluteliquidAssetsQuickLiabilities
Correct Answer: AbsoluteliquidAssetsCurrentLiabilities

Absolute Liquid Ratio: The relationship between theabsolute liquid assets and current liabilities is established by this ratio. Absolute Liquid Assetstake into account cash in hand, cash at bank, and marketable securities or temporary investments. The most favorable and optimum value for this ratioshould be 1: 2.

Absolute Liquid Ratio=Absolute Liquid assets Current Liabilities

Question 15
Return on Investment (ROI) is computed as? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2014)
  • A.Net Profit Ratio × Capital Turnover Ratio
  • B.Operating Net Profit Ratio × Shareholders Fund
  • C.NetProfitSales
  • D.CostofSalesCapitalEmployed
Correct Answer: Net Profit Ratio × Capital Turnover Ratio

Return on investment (ROI) is a ratio between the net profit and cost of investment resulting from an investment of some resources.

The various profitability ratios have direct relationship with each other. A change in cost of goods sold ratio or administrative & office expenses ratio or selling and distribution expenses ratio directly affects the net profit ratio. Similarly, return on capital employed or investment is related directly with net profit ratio and capital turnover ratio. In fact, return on capital employed or ROI can be improved either by improving net profit ratio or capital turnover ratio or both.

Return on capital employed ROI=Net Profit Capital Employed

Return on capital employed ROI=Net Profit Sales×SalesCapital Employed

Net Profit ratio=Net Profit Sales

Capital Turnover=SalesCapital Employed

 

Hence, ROI = Net Profit Ratio × Capital Turnover Ratio

Question 16
Accounting information given by a company: (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2014)Total assets turnover = 3 timesNet profit margin = 10%Total assets =Rs. 1,00,000The net profit is?
  • A.Rs.10,000
  • B.Rs. 15,000
  • C.Rs. 25,000
  • D.Rs. 30,000
Correct Answer: Rs. 30,000

Total Assets Turnover Ratio: The asset turnover ratio is an efficiency ratio that measures a company’s ability to generate sales from its assets by comparing net sales with average total assets. In other words, this ratio shows how efficiently a company can use its assets to generate sales.

The total asset turnover ratio calculates net sales as a percentage of assets to show how many sales are generated from each dollar of company assets. For instance, a ratio of .5 means that each dollar of assets generates 50 cents of sales.

Assets Turnover Ratio=Sales Total Assets

 

 

3=Sales 1,00,000

Sales=3,00,000

Net profit Margin = Rs. 30,000 (10% of 3,00,000)

Question 17
If debt isRs. 220, cash balance isRs. 20 and equity isRs. 300, then the gearing ratio is? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2014)
  • A.20%
  • B.40%
  • C.50%
  • D.30%
Correct Answer: 40%

Gearing (otherwise known as "leverage") measures the proportion of assets invested in a business that are financed by long-term borrowing.

 

In theory, the higher the level of borrowing (gearing) the higher are the risks to a business, since the payment of interest and repayment of debts are not "optional" in the same way as dividends. However, gearing can be a financially sound part of a business's capital structure particularly if the business has strong, predictable cash flows.

 

Gearing Ratio= Net DebtNet Debt+Equity

Net Debt = Total Debt – Cash and Cash Equivalent

= 220 – 20

= 200

 

Gearing Ratio= Net DebtNet Debt+Equity= 200500=40%.

Question 18
Match the items of List – I with those of the List – II and indicate the correct code for the following: (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2015)List – I(a) Debtors Turnover Ratio(b) Proprietary Ratio(c) Operating Ratio(d) Acid Test RatioList – II(i) Solvency Ratio(ii) Liquidity Ratio(iii) Activity Ratio(iv) Profitability Ratio
  • A.(a)-(ii), (b)-(iv), (c)-(iii), (d)-(i)
  • B.(a)-(iii), (b)-(ii), (c)-(i), (d)-(iv)
  • C.(a)-(iii), (b)-(i), (c)-(iv), (d)-(ii)
  • D.(a)-(iv), (b)-(iii), (c)-(ii), (d)-(i)
Correct Answer: (a)-(iii), (b)-(i), (c)-(iv), (d)-(ii)

Financial ratios can be broadly classified into:

- Liquidity ratio: A liquidity ratio is a financial ratio that indicates whether a company's current assets will be sufficient to meet the company's obligations when they become due.

- Solvency Ratio: Solvency ratio is one of the various ratios used to measure the ability of a company to meet its long term debts.

- Profitability ratio: Profitability ratio evaluates the company's ability to generate income against expenses and other cost associated with the generation of income.

- Activity/turnover Ratio: An activity ratio is a metric which determines the ability of a company to convert its balance sheet accounts into revenue.

Question 19
X Ltd. has a liquid ratio of 2:1. If its stock isRs40,000 and its current liabilities are ofRs1 Lac, its current ratio will be: (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2015)
  • A.1.4 times
  • B.2.4 times
  • C.1.2times
  • D.3.4 times
Correct Answer: 2.4 times

Current Ratio = Current AssetsCurrent Liabilities

 

Liquid Ratio = Liquid AssetsCurrent Liabilities

 

Current liabilities = Rs. 1,00,000

Liquid assets = Liquid ratio × Current Liabilities

Liquid assets = 2 × Rs. 1,00,000

Liquid Assets = Rs. 2,00,000

Liquid Assets = Current Assets – Prepaid expenses – stock

So, Current Assets = 2,00,000 + 40000

= 2,40,000

Therefore, Current Ratio =2,40,0001,00,000= 2.4 times

Question 20
Which of the following statements is true? (UGC NET Commerce Aug 2016)
  • A.Rate of return on capital is Acid Test Ratio.
  • B.Equity capital to fixed interest- bearing securities is a turnover ratio.
  • C.Capital gearing is the ratio of equity capital to fixed interest bearing securities.
  • D.Input and output ratio is a measure of profitability.
Correct Answer: Capital gearing is the ratio of equity capital to fixed interest bearing securities.

A productivity measure is expressed as the ratio of output to inputs used in a production process, i.e. output per unit of input. 

 

Quick Ratio: Quick ratio (also known as acid test ratio) is a liquidity ratio which measures per dollars/rupees of liquid current assets available per dollar/rupees of current liabilities. Liquid current assets are current assets which can be quickly converted to cash without any significant decrease in their value. Liquid current assets typically include cash, marketable securities and receivables. Quick ratio is expressed as a number instead of a percentage. Optimum quick ratio is 1:1. Ratio is high when quick assets increase or current liabilities decrease.

Quick Ratio = Current Assets-Inventories-Prepaid ExpenseCurrent Liabilities

 

Capital Gearing Ratio: It shows the proportion of fixed interest bearing capital to equity shareholders’ fund. It also signifies the advantage of financial leverage to the equity shareholder.

Capital Gearing Ratio=Preference Share Capital + Debentures + Other Borrowed fundsEquity Share Capital + Reserves & Surplus - Losses

Question 21
The portion of earnings which is distributed among shareholders in the form of dividend is called (UGC NET commerce Jul 2016)
  • A.Proprietary Ratio
  • B.Earnings-yield Ratio
  • C.PayoutRatio
  • D.Retention Ratio
Correct Answer: PayoutRatio

The payout ratio, also called the dividend payout ratio, is the proportion of earnings paid out as dividends to shareholders. Some companies pay out all their earnings to shareholders, while some only pay out a portion of their earnings. If a company pays out some of its earnings as dividends, the remaining portion is retained by the business. To measure the level of earnings retained, the retention ratio is calculated.

 

- The proprietary ratio (also known as the equityratio) is the proportion of shareholders' equity to total assets, and as such provides a rough estimate of the amount of capitalization currently used to support a business.

 

- The earnings yield refers to the earnings per share for the most recent 12-month period divided by the current market price per share. The earnings yield (which is the inverse of the P/E ratio) shows the percentage of each dollar invested in the stock that was earned by the company.

Question 22
Match the items in Column – I with the items in Column – II and indicate the correct code: (UGC NET Commerce Jul 2016)Column – I(a) Debt-Equity Ratio(b) Proprietary Ratio(c) Interest coverage ratio(d) Capital gearing ratioColumn – II(i)NetProfitbeforeinterestandtaxInterestonlongtermloans(ii)PreferenceShareCapital+Debentures+OtherBorrowedfundsEquityShareCapital+Reserves&Surplus-Losses(iii)TotalLiabilitiesShareholders'Equity(iv)Shareholder'sFundTotalAssets
  • A.(a)-(i), (b)-(ii), (c)-(iii), (d)-(iv)
  • B.(a)-(iii), (b)-(iv), (c)-(i), (d)-(ii)
  • C.(a)-(iii), (b)-(iv), (c)-(ii), (d)-(i)
  • D.(a)-(ii), (b)-(iii), (c)-(iv), (d)-(i)
Correct Answer: (a)-(iii), (b)-(iv), (c)-(i), (d)-(ii)

Debt-to-Equity Ratio: Debt-to-Equity ratio is the ratio of total liabilities of a business to its shareholders' equity. It is a leverage ratio and it measures the degree to which the assets of the business are financed by the debts and the shareholders' equity of a business. Lower values of debt-to-equity ratio are favorable indicating less risk. Debt to Equity Ratio indicates Financial Leverage of a firm.

Debt to equity ratio=Total LiabilitiesShareholders' Equity

 

Capital Gearing Ratio: It shows the proportion of fixed interest-bearing capital to equity shareholders’ fund. It also signifies the advantage of financial leverage to the equity shareholder.

Capital Gearing Ratio=Preference Share Capital + Debentures + Other Borrowed fundsEquity Share Capital + Reserves & Surplus - Losses

 

 

The proprietary ratio (also known as net worth ratio or equity ratio) is used to evaluate the soundness of the capital structure of a company. This ratio shows the proportion of total assets of a company which are financed by proprietors' funds.

Proprietary Ratio=Shareholder's FundTotal Assets

 

Times Interest Earned Ratio: Times interest earned ratio (also called interest coverage ratio) is an indicator of the company’s ability to pay off its interest expense with available earnings. It is a measure of a company’s solvency, i.e., its long-term financial strength. It calculates how many times a company’s operating income (earnings before interest and taxes) can settle the company’s interest expense. A higher times interest earned ratio indicates that the company’s interest expense is low relative to its earnings before interest and taxes (EBIT) which indicates better long-term financial strength, and vice versa.

If this Ratio is less than 1, it indicates the inability of firm’s profit to serve, its interest on debts.

Times Interest Earned Ratio = Earnings before Interest and TaxInterest Expense

Question 23
Assertion “A”:Debt - equity ratio indicates the long-term solvency of a company. (UGC NET Commerce Nov 2017)Reasoning “R”:It measures the ability of the company to pay off its long-term liabilities.Select the correct answer from the code given below:
  • A.Both “A” and “R” are correct and “R” is the correct reason for “A”.
  • B.Both “A” and “R” are correct but “R” does not explain “A” correctly.
  • C.“A” is correct but “R” is wrong.
  • D.“A” is wrong but “R” is correct.
Correct Answer: Both “A” and “R” are correct and “R” is the correct reason for “A”.

Debt-to-Equity Ratio: Debt-to-Equity ratio is the ratio of total liabilities of a business to its shareholders' equity. It is a leverage ratio and it measures the degree to which the assets of the business are financed by the debts and the shareholders' equity of a business. Lower values of debt-to-equity ratio are favorable indicating less risk. Debt to Equity Ratio indicates Financial Leverage of a firm.

Debt to equity ratio=Total LiabilitiesShareholders' Equity

Question 24
Match the items of the following two lists and indicate the correct answer: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2013)List – I(i) Earning ability of firm(ii) Conservatism(iii) Cash profit(iv) Cash and AccrualList – II(a) Basis of Accounting(b) Profitability Ratio(c) Cash flow Statement(d) Prudence
  • A.(i)-(b), (ii)-(d), (iii)-(c), (iv)-(a)
  • B.(i)-(b), (ii)-(a), (iii)-(d), (iv)-(c)
  • C.(i)-(c), (ii)-(d), (iii)-(a), (iv)-(b)
  • D.(i)-(c), (ii)-(d), (iii)-(b), (iv)-(a)
Correct Answer: (i)-(b), (ii)-(d), (iii)-(c), (iv)-(a)

Profitability ratio is used to evaluate the company’s ability to generate income as compared to its expenses and other cost associated with the generation of income during a particular period. This ratio represents the final result of the company.

 

Conservatism concept takes into consideration all prospective losses but not the prospective profit. It means profit should not be recorded until it realized but all losses, even those which have remote possibility are to be recorded in the books. For example, valuing closing stock at cost or market value whichever is lower, creating provision for doubtful debts etc. This concept ensures that the financial statements provide the real picture of the enterprise.

 

Basis of Accounting: From the point of view the timing of recognition of revenue and costs, there can be two broad approaches to accounting. These are:

a) Cash basis: Entries in the book of accounts are made when cash is received or paid and not when the receipt or payment becomes due.

b) Accrual basis: Under the accrual basis, however, revenues and costs are recognized in the period in which they occur rather when they are paid.

A cash flow statement is a financial statement that provides aggregate data regarding all cash inflows a company receives from its ongoing operations and external investment sources, as well as all cash outflows that pay for business activities and investments during a given period. 

Question 25
Which of the following is considered a profitability measure?
  • A.Days sales in inventory
  • B.Fixed asset turnover
  • C.Price-earnings ratio
  • D.Return on Assets
Correct Answer: Return on Assets

Profitability ratio evaluates the company's ability to generate income against expenses and other cost associated with the generation of income. These ratios are expressed in percentage (%). Profitability ratios are considered as a measure of profitability.

(i) Return on Assets (ROA) Ratio: Return on assets is the ratio of annual net income to average total assets of a business during a financial year. It measures efficiency of the business in using its assets to generate net income. It is a profitability ratio.

ROA = (Annual Net Income after tax)/(Average Total Assets)

 

Return on assets is a profitability ratio and is therefore considered as a profitability measure.

 

(ii) Price/Earnings (P/E) Ratio: Price/Earnings or P/E ratio is the ratio of a company's share price to its earnings per share. It tells whether the share price of a company is fairly valued, undervalued or overvalued.

P/E Ratio = (Current Share Price)/(Earnings Per Share)

The price earnings ratio shows what the market is willing to pay for a stock based on its current earnings. The P/E ratio helps investors analyze, how much they should pay for a stock based on its current earnings. This is why the price to earnings ratio is often called a price multiple or earnings multiple. Investors use this ratio to decide what multiple of earnings a share is worth. In other words, how many times earnings they are willing to pay.

Price/Earnings ratio is a market test ratio and is therefore not considered as a profitability measure.

 

(iii) Days Sales Outstanding (DSO) Ratio: Days sales outstanding ratio (also called average collection period or days' sales in receivables) is used to measure the average number of days a business takes to collect its trade receivables after they have been created. It is an activity ratio and gives information about the efficiency of sales collection activities.

DSO = Accounts Receivables Credit Sales × Number of Days

 

Or DSO = Number of Days in the PeriodAccounts Receivable Turnover Ratio

 

 

Days sale outstanding ratio is an activity ratio, and therefore cannot be considered as a profitability measure.

 

(iv) Fixed Assets Turnover Ratio: Fixed assets turnover ratio is an activity ratio that measures how successfully a company is utilizing its fixed assets in generating revenue. It calculates the revenue earned per one Rupee of investment in fixed assets.

A higher fixed asset turnover ratio is generally better. However, there might be situations when a high fixed asset turnover ratio might not necessarily mean efficient use of fixed assets.

Fixed Assets Turnover Ratio = (Net Sales)/(Average Fixed Assets)

Average Fixed Assets = (Opening Balance of FA + Closing Balance of FA)/2

Fixed assets turnover ratio is an activity ratio and therefore, it cannot be considered as a profitability measure.

Question 26
Firm A has a Return on Equity (ROE) equal to 24%, while firm B has an ROE of 15% during the same year. Both firms have a total debt ratio (D/V) equal to 0.8. Firm A has an asset turnover ratio of 0.9, while firm B has an asset turnover ratio equal to 0.4. From this we know that
  • A.Firm A has a higher profit margin than firm B
  • B.Firm B has a higher profit margin than firm A
  • C.Firm A and B have the same profit margin
  • D.Firm A has a higher equity multiplier than firm B
Correct Answer: Firm B has a higher profit margin than firm A

Given,

Return on Equity of Firm A = 24%

Return on Equity of Firm B = 15%

Total debt ratio of both firms, that is, Total AssetsShareholders' Equity = 0.8

Asset turnover ratio of Firm A = 0.9

Asset turnover ratio of Firm B = 0.4

Where Asset Turnover ratio = Net SalesTotal Assets

Now, using Du Pont Identity,

Return on equity = Net IncomeNet Sales × Total AssetsShareholders' Equity × Net SalesTotal Assets

 

For Firm A, Return on equity = Net IncomeNet Sales × Total AssetsShareholders' Equity × Net SalesTotal Assets

24% = Net IncomeNet Sales × 0.9 × 0.8

24% = Net Profit ratio × 0.72

 

By solving, Net Profit Ratio of Firm A = 33.33%

 

For Firm B, Return on equity = Net IncomeNet Sales × Total AssetsShareholders' Equity × Net SalesTotal Assets

15% = Net IncomeNet Sales × 0.4 × 0.8

15% = Net Profit ratio × 0.32

 

By solving, Net Profit Ratio of Firm B = 46.875%

Therefore, from the above Du Pont Analysis, it can be inferred that Firm B has a higher profit margin than Firm A.

Question 27
If a firm has Rs100 in inventories, a current ratio equal to 1.2, and a quick ratio equal to 1.1, what is the firm's Net Working Capital?
  • A.Rs. 0
  • B.Rs. 100
  • C.Rs. 200
  • D.Rs. 1,000
Correct Answer: Rs. 200

Given,

Current Ratio = Current AssetsCurrent Liabilities = 1.2

Therefore, Current Assets = 1.2 × Current Liabilities


Quick Ratio = Quick AssetsCurrent Liabilities = 1.1

 

Implies, 1.1 = Current Assets-Inventory-Prepaid ExpensesCurrent Liabilities

1.1 = Current Assets-Rs.  100Current Liabilities

 

1.1 = 1.2×Current Liabilities- Rs.  100Current Liabilities

 

On solving, we get, Current Liabilities = Rs. 1,000

Therefore, Current Assets = 1.2 × Current Liabilities = 1.2 × Rs. 1,000

Current Assets = Rs. 1,200



Therefore, Net Working Capital = Current Assets – Current Liabilities

Net Working Capital = Rs. 1,200 – Rs. 1,000 = Rs. 200

Question 28
Calculate ‘Return on Investment’ and ‘Debt-Equity Ratio’ from the following information:Rs. Net Profit after interest and Tax isRs6,00,000, 10% DebenturesRs10,00,000, Tax Rate is 40 % , Capital Employed isRs80,00,000
  • A.12.5%, 1:3
  • B.13.5%, 2:9
  • C.13.75%, 1:7
  • D.14.25%, 1:4
Correct Answer: 13.75%, 1:7

Given,

Net Profit after interest and tax = Rs. 6,00,000

Tax Rate = 40%

Therefore, Net Profit before tax but after interest = Rs.  6,00,000100-Tax rate×100 = Rs.  6,00,000100-40×100

Net Profit before tax but after interest = Rs. 10,00,000

 

Interest on Debentures = Rs. 10,00,000 × 10% = Rs. 1,00,000

Therefore, Net Profit before interest and tax = Rs. 10,00,000 + Rs. 1,00,000 = Rs. 11,00,000

 

Return On investment = Net Profit Before Interest And Tax Capital Employed×100 = Rs.11,00,000Rs.80,00,000 = 13.75%

 

Capital employed = Long term debt + Shareholders’ Funds

Rs. 80,00,000 = Rs. 10,00,000 + Shareholders’ Funds

Therefore, Shareholder’ Funds = Rs. 70,00,000

 

Debt-Equity Ratio = Long Term DebtSharehiolders'funds = Rs.10,00,000Rs.70,00,000 = 1:7

Question 29
The Quick ratio of X Ltd. is 1:1. State which of the following transactions would (i) increase; (ii) decrease or (iii) not change the ratio:(a) Included in the trade payable was a Bill payable ofRs. 3,000 which was met on maturity.(b) Debentures ofRs. 50,000 were converted into Equity Shares.
  • A.Increase, Decrease
  • B.No change, No change
  • C.Decrease, no change
  • D.No change, decrease
Correct Answer: No change, No change

Given, Quick ratio = 1:1, that is Quick AssetsCurrent Liabilities = 1:1

 

(a) Included in the trade payable was a Bill payable of Rs. 3,000 which was met on maturity.

This transaction will decrease the current liabilities by Rs. 3000 as bill payable is met on maturity and also decrease cash/bank balance by Rs. 3000. Thus, current liabilities and quick assets, both decrease by the same amount, that is, the numerator and denominator are decreased by the same amount. Since Quick Ratio is given to be 1:1, this transaction will not change the quick ratio.

 

(b) Debentures of Rs. 50,000 were converted into Equity Shares.

This transaction will not have any effect on the quick ratio as conversion of debentures into equity shares has no impact on current liabilities or quick assets. Thus, quick ratio of 1:1 will remain the same.

Therefore, option B is the correct answer.

Question 30
Calculate ‘Operating Profit Ratio’ and ‘Operating Ratio’ from the following information:Net Revenue from Operations =Rs. 80,000Cost of Revenue from Operations =Rs. 60,000Operating Expenses =Rs. 10,000Indirect Expenses =Rs. 60,000
  • A.12.5%, 87.5%
  • B.87.5%. 12.5%
  • C.15%. 85%
  • D.85%, 15%
Correct Answer: 12.5%, 87.5%

Operating profit ratio = Operating ProfitNet Sales or Net Revenue from Operations×100

Now, Operating profit = Net Revenue from operations – Cost of Revenue from Operations – Operating Expenses

Therefore, Operating Profit = Rs. 80,000 – Rs. 60,000 – Rs. 10000 = Rs. 10,000

 

Thus, Operating profit ratio = Rs.10,000Rs.80,000 × 100 = 12.5%

 

Operating ratio = Operating CostNet Sales or Net Revenue from Operations×100

 

Now, Operating cost = Cost of Revenue from Operation + Operating expenses

Therefore, Operating cost = Rs. 60,000 + Rs. 10,000 = Rs. 70,000

 

Thus, Operating ratio = Rs.70,000Rs.80,000 × 100 = 87.5%

 

Option A is the correct answer.

Question 31
Working Capital =Rs. 36,000; Current Ratio = 2.8:1; Inventory =Rs. 16,000. Calculate Current Assets, Current Liabilities and Quick Ratio.
  • A.56000, 20000, 2:1
  • B.236000, 200000, 1.1:1
  • C.20000, 56000, 1:1
  • D.200000, 56000, 1.1:1
Correct Answer: 56000, 20000, 2:1

Given, Working capital = Rs. 36,000; Current Ratio = 2.8:1

 

That is, Current AssetsCurrent Liabilities = 2.81

 

Therefore, Current Assets = 2.8 × Current Liabilities

 

We know, Working capital = Current Assets – Current Liabilities

Rs. 36,000 = 2.8 × Current Liabilities – Current Liabilities

Rs. 36,000 = 1.8 × Current Liabilities

 

Current Liabilities = Rs. 20,000

Current Assets = 2.8 × Current Liabilities = Rs 20,000 × 2.8 = Rs. 56,000

 

Quick Ratio = Quick AssetsCurrent Liabilities = Current Assets-InventoryCurrent Liabilities = Rs.56,000-Rs.16,000Rs. 20,000 = 2:1

 

Option A is the correct answer.

Question 32
Calculate Interest Coverage Ratio from the following information Net Profit (after taxes) =Rs. 1,00,000. Fixed interest charges on long term borrowing =Rs. 20,000 and Rate of Income Tax 50%
  • A.10 times
  • B.11 times
  • C.5.5 times
  • D.5 times
Correct Answer: 11 times

Given, Net Profit after taxes = Rs. 1,00,000

Fixed Interest Charges on long term borrowing = Rs. 20,000

Income tax rate = 50%

Interest Coverage ratio = Earnings or Profit Before Interest and Tax Interest Expenses

Earnings before interest and tax = Net profit after tax100%-Tax rate  + Interest expense

Earnings before interest and tax = Rs.1,00,000100%-50%  + Rs. 20,000 = Rs. 2,20,000

Therefore, Interest Coverage ratio = Earnings or Profit Before Interest and Tax Interest Expenses

Interest Coverage ratio = Rs.2,20,000 Rs.20,000 = 11 times

Option B is the correct answer.

Question 33
Calculate ‘Debt-Equity Ratio’ from the following information:Total Assets:Rs. 3,50,000Total Debt:Rs. 2,50,000Current Liabilities:Rs. 80,000
  • A.1.7:1
  • B.2.5:1
  • C.3.5:1
  • D.3.4:1
Correct Answer: 1.7:1

Given, Total Assets = Rs. 3,50,000

Total debt = Long term debt + Current liabilities

Rs. 2,50,000 = Long term debt + Rs. 80,000

Long term debt = Rs. 1,70,000

Total Assets = Shareholders’ Equity + Long Term Debt + Current Liabilities

Rs. 3,50,000 = Shareholders’ Equity + Rs. 1,70,000 + Rs. 80,000

Shareholders’ Equity = Rs. 3,50,000 – Rs. 2,50,000

Shareholders’ Equity = Rs. 1,00,000

Debt-Equity Ratio = Long Term DebtShareholders' Equity = Rs.1,70,000Rs.1,00,000 = 1.7:1

 

Option A is the correct answer.

Question 34
Cost of Revenue from operation =Rs. 2,00,000, Inventory Turnover Ratio = 8 Times.Inventory in the beginning is 1.5 times more than the inventory at the end.Calculate values ofopening and closing inventory.
  • A.Rs. 35714,Rs. 14286
  • B.Rs. 14286,Rs. 35714
  • C.Rs. 14250,Rs. 37750
  • D.Rs. 15750,Rs. 37350
Correct Answer: Rs. 35714,Rs. 14286

Given, Cost of Revenue from Operation = Rs. 2,00,000

Inventory Turnover ratio = 8 times

Let Closing inventory = x

Therefore, Opening inventory = 1.5x + x = 2.5x

Inventory Turnover ratio = Cost of Goods Sold or Cost of Revenue from OpertionsAverage Inventory

8 = Rs.2,00,000(Opening Inventory + Closing Inventory)/2

8 = Rs.2,00,000(2.5x + x)/2 = Rs.2,00,000(3.5x)/2

On solving the above equation, we get x = Rs. 14,286

Therefore, Closing Inventory = Rs. 14,286

Opening Inventory = 2.5x = Rs. 14286 × 2.5 = Rs. 35714

Option A is the correct answer.

Quiz Attempt #119241

Total Questions: 33
Question 1
Low working capital turnover ratio indicates:
  • A.Under-utilization of working capital
  • B.No use of working capital
  • C.Over-utilization of working capital
  • D.There is no working capital
Correct Answer: Under-utilization of working capital

Working Capital Turnover: Working capital turnover ratio is an activity ratio that measures revenue generated per rupee of investment in working capital. Working capital is defined as the amount by which current assets exceed current liabilities.

Working Capital Turnover Ratio = (Net Revenue) / (Average Working Capital)

Working Capital = Current Assets – Current Liabilities

Average Working Capital= (Opening working capital + Closing working capital)/2

Working capital turnover is a ratio that measures how efficiently a company is using its working capital to support a given level of sales. Also referred to as net sales to working capital, work capital turnover shows the relationship between the funds used to finance a company's operations and the revenues a company generates as a result.

In contrast, a low ratio may indicate that a business is investing in too many accounts receivable and inventory to support its sales, which could lead to an excessive amount of bad debts or obsolete inventory. A low working capital turnover ratio thus indicates that the company is under-utilizing its working capital.

A high turnover ratio shows that management is being very efficient in using a company’s short-term assets and liabilities for supporting sales (i.e., it is generating a higher dollar amount of sales for every dollar of the working capital used).

A high working capital turnover ratio shows a company is running smoothly and has limited need for additional funding. Money is coming in and flowing out on a regular basis, giving the business flexibility to spend capital on expansion or inventory. A high ratio may also give the business a competitive edge over similar companies.

However, an extremely high ratio—typically over 80%—may indicate that a business does not have enough capital to support its sales growth. Therefore, the company could become insolvent in the near future. The indicator is especially strong when accounts payable is also very high, which indicates that the company is having difficulty paying its bills as they come due.

Question 2
Ratio of net sales to net working capital is:
  • A.Profitability ratio
  • B.Liquidity ratio
  • C.Current ratio
  • D.Working capital turnover ratio
Correct Answer: Working capital turnover ratio

Working Capital Turnover: Working capital turnover ratio is an activity ratio that measures revenue generated per rupee of investment in working capital. Working capital is defined as the amount by which current assets exceed current liabilities.

Working Capital Turnover Ratio = (Net Revenue) / (Average Working Capital)

Working Capital = Current Assets – Current Liabilities

Average Working Capital= (Opening working capital + Closing working capital)/2

Working capital turnover is a ratio that measures how efficiently a company is using its working capital to support a given level of sales. Also referred to as net sales to working capital, work capital turnover shows the relationship between the funds used to finance a company's operations and the revenues a company generates as a result.

Question 3
Long term solvency is indicated by:
  • A.Debt/Equity ratio
  • B.Current ratio
  • C.Operating ratio
  • D.Net profit ratio
Correct Answer: Debt/Equity ratio

Debt-to-Equity Ratio: Debt-to-Equity ratio is the ratio of total liabilities of a business to its shareholders' equity. It is a leverage ratio and it measures the degree to which the assets of the business are financed by the debts and the shareholders' equity of a business. Lower values of debt-to-equity ratio are favorable indicating less risk. Debt to Equity Ratio indicates Financial Leverage of a firm. Debt-to-Equity is a long term solvency ratio.

Debt-to-Equity Ratio = Total LiabilitiesShareholders' Equity

Current Ratio: Current ratio is one of the most fundamental liquidity ratios. It measures the ability of a business to repay current liabilities with current assets. Optimum current ratio is 2:1. Ratio is high when current assets increase or current liabilities decrease.

Current Ratio = Current AssetsCurrent Liabilities

The main elements of current assets are Inventories, Sundry Debtors, Cash and Bank Balances, Receivables/Accruals, Loans and Advances, Disposable Investments

The Current liabilities include Creditors for goods and services, short term loans, Bank overdraft, Cash Credit, Outstanding Expenses, Provision for taxation, Proposed Dividend and Unclaimed dividend.

 

Operating Ratio: Operating ratio is a type of Profitability ratio. The operating ratio shows the efficiency of a company's management by comparing the total operating expense of a company to net sales. The operating ratio shows how efficient a company's management is at keeping costs low while generating revenue or sales. The smaller the ratio, the more efficient the company is at generating revenue versus total expenses.

Operating Ratio = Cost of Goods Sold+ Operating ExpensesNet Sales×100

 

Net Profit Margin: Net profit margin (also called profit margin) is the most basic profitability ratio that measures the percentage of net income of an entity to its net sales. It represents the proportion of sales that is left over after all relevant expenses have been adjusted. Net profit margin is used to compare profitability of competitors in the same industry. It can also be used to determine the profitability potential of different industries.

Net Profit Margin = Net ProfitNet Sales×100

Net profit = Gross profit – Indirect Expenses

Question 4
Ratio of earnings before interest and tax to sales is:
  • A.Gross profit ratio
  • B.Net profit ratio
  • C.Operating profit ratio
  • D.Interest coverage ratio
Correct Answer: Operating profit ratio

Operating Profit Ratio: Operating margin ratio or return on sales ratio is the ratio of operating income of a business to its revenue. It is profitability ratio showing operating income as a percentage of revenue.

Operating Profit Ratio = Operating ProfitNet Sales×100

Where, Operating Profit is equal to Sales – COGS – Office and Admin Expenses – Selling and Distribution Expenses.

Operating income is same as earnings before interest and tax (EBIT). Both operating income and revenue figures can be obtained from the income statement of a business.

Question 5
The Receivables-Turnover ratio helps the management to:
  • A.Managing resources
  • B.Managing inventory
  • C.Managing customer relations
  • D.Managing working capital
Correct Answer: Managing working capital

Accounts Receivable Turnover Ratio: Accounts receivable turnover is the ratio of net credit sales of a business to its average accounts receivable during a given period, usually a year. It is an activity ratio which estimates the number of times a business collects its average accounts receivable balance during a period.

Receivables Turnover Ratio = Net Credit SalesAverage Accounts Receivables

The accounts receivables turnover ratio throws light on the collection and credit policies of the firm. It measures the efficiency with which management is managing its accounts receivables.

Accounts receivable turnover ratio thus helps the management to manage their working capital, as accounts receivables is a very important part of working capital.

Therefore, Option D is the correct answer.

Question 6
If a firm hasRs100 in inventories, a current ratio equal to 1.2, and a quick ratio equal to 1.1, what is the firm's Net Working Capital?
  • A.Rs0
  • B.Rs100
  • C.Rs200
  • D.Rs1,000
Correct Answer: Rs200

Given that Current Ratio = Current Assets (CA) Current Liabilities (CL)= 1.2

Or, CA = 1.2 CL……………… (i)

 

Quick Ratio = Current Assets-InventoriesCurrent Liabilities = 1.1

 

Or, CA = 1.1 CL + Inventories……………. (ii)

 

Equating both (i) and (ii), we get

 

1.2 CL = 1.1 CL + Inventories

 

1.2 CL – 1.1 CL = 100

 

0.1 CL = 100

 

Therefore, CL = 1000.1 = 1000

 

Putting the value of CL in equation (i),

 

CA = 1.2 CL

 

Therefore, CA = 1.2 × 1000 = 1200

 

Thus, Net Working Capital = CA – CL = 1200 – 1000 = 200

 

Hence, C is the correct option.

Question 7
Given below are two statements, Assertion “A” and Reason “R”. Suggest which of the statements are true.Assertion “A”:Ratio analysis is one of the tools employed to know the financial health of a concern.Reason “R”:Ratio analysis is not the only technique available to take investment decision..
  • A.Both “A” and “R” are true and “R” is the correct explanation of “A”.
  • B.Both “A” and “R” are true, but “R” is incorrect explanation of “A”.
  • C.“A” is true, but “R” is false.
  • D.“A” is false, but “R” is true.
Correct Answer: Both “A” and “R” are true and “R” is the correct explanation of “A”.

Both “A” and “R” are true and “R” is the correct explanation of “A”.

Ratio Analysis is one of the tools employed to know the financial health of a concern due to the following reasons:

It helps in identifying problem areas.

It enables Intra-firm and Inter -firm analysis.

It helps in assessing the long-term solvency of the business.

It helps in analyzing the liquidity position of the companies.

Question 8
Consider the following: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2012)(i) Basic defensive and interval ratio(ii) Current ratio(iii) Super quick ratio(iv) Quick ratioArrange these ratios in sequence to reflect the liquidity in descending order.
  • A.(ii), (iv), (iii) and (i)
  • B.(i), (ii), (iv) and (iii)
  • C.(iv), (ii), (iii) and (i)
  • D.(iii), (iv), (i) and (ii)
Correct Answer: (ii), (iv), (iii) and (i)

The ratios in order of their liquidity in descending order are as follows:

 

(i) Current ratio = Current assets/Current liabilities

(ii) Quick ratio = [Current assets minus inventory]/ Current liabilities

(iii) Super quick ratio = [Cash + Marketable securities]/ Current liabilities

(iv) Basic defensive and interval ratio = [Cash + Marketable securities + Trade receivables] / Average daily expenditures

 

As we move from ratio number 1 to ratio number 4 we are calculating the liquidity on more and more conservative basis as it can be seen that as we move from ratios 1 to 3 we are considering few and fewer assets and in the 4th ratio we are considering average daily expenditures instead of the whole of current liabilities as this ratio helps us to understand that for how many days can the company survive without having to liquidate its long term assets.

Question 9
From the following information, compute inventory turnover and days in inventory.Sales RevenueRs. 18,00,000Cost of Goods SoldRs. 9,10,000Beginning InventoryRs. 2,10,000Ending InventoryRs. 50,000
  • A.Inventory Turnover 8 times and Days in Inventory 52.10
  • B.Inventory Turnover 8 times and Days in Inventory 51.14
  • C.Inventory Turnover 7 times and Days in Inventory 52.14
  • D.Inventory Turnover 7 times and Days in Inventory 52.16
Correct Answer: Inventory Turnover 7 times and Days in Inventory 52.14

Inventory Turnover = Cost of Goods Sold(Opening Inventory+Closing Inventory)/2 = 9,10,0002,10,000+50,0002 = 7 times

 

Days in Inventory = Number of Days in a year  Inventory Turnover = 3657 = 52.14 days

Question 10
Santana Company had beginning inventory ofRs. 80,000, ending inventory ofRs. 110,000, cost of goods sold ofRs. 285,000, and sales ofRs. 475,000.Santana’s days in inventory is:
  • A.73 days
  • B.121.7 days
  • C.102.5 days
  • D.84.5 days
Correct Answer: 121.7 days

Santana’s days in inventory = 365/Inventory turnover

 

Inventory Turnover = Cost of Goods SoldAverage Inventory  =285,00080,000+110,0002 = 285,00095,000 = 3 times

 

Days in Inventory = 3653 = 121.7 days

Question 11
Which of these would cause the inventory turnover to increase the most?
  • A.Increasing the amount of inventory on hand.
  • B.Keeping the amount of inventory on hand constant but increasing sales.
  • C.Keeping the amount of inventory on hand constant but decreasing sales.
  • D.Decreasing the amount of inventory on hand and increasing sales.
Correct Answer: Decreasing the amount of inventory on hand and increasing sales.

Decreasing the amount of inventory on hand will cause the denominator to decrease, causing inventory turnover to increase. Increasing sales will cause the numerator of the ratio to increase (higher sales means higher COGS), thus causing inventory turnover to increase even more.

 

The other options are incorrect because:

(i) increasing the amount of inventory on hand causes the denominator of the ratio to increase while the numerator stays the same, causing inventory turnover to decrease.

(ii) keeping the amount of inventory on hand constant but increasing sales will cause inventory turnover to increase because the numerator of the ratio will increase (higher sales means higher COGS) while the denominator stays the same, which will result in a lesser inventory increase than decreasing amount of inventory on hand and increasing sales.

(iii) keeping the amount of inventory on hand constant but decreasing sales will cause inventory turnover to decrease because the numerator of the ratio will decrease (lower sales means lower COGS) while the denominator stays the same.

Question 12
In 2017,PhaleraCompany has net credit sales ofRs. 923,795 for the year. It had a beginning accounts receivable (net) balance ofRs. 38,275 and an ending accounts receivable (net) balance ofRs. 35,988. ComputePhaleraCompany’s (a) accounts receivable turnover and (b) average collection period in days. Choose your answer from the options given below:
  • A.24.5 times and 14.1 days, respectively
  • B.24.6 times and 14.3 days, respectively
  • C.24.9 times and 14.7 days, respectively
  • D.24.2 times and 14.0 days, respectively
Correct Answer: 24.9 times and 14.7 days, respectively

Accounts Receivable Turnover = Net Credit SalesAverge net Accounts Receivables = 923,79538,275+35,9882 = 923,79537,131.5 = 24.9 times

 

Average Collection period in days = Days in YearAccounts receivable turnover = 36524.9 = 14.7 days

Question 13
Oliver Company had net credit sales during the year ofRs. 800,000 and cost of goods sold ofRs. 500,000. The balance in accounts receivable at the beginning of the year wasRs. 100,000, and the end of the year it wasRs. 150,000. What were the accounts receivable turnover and the average collection period in days?
  • A.4.0 and 91.3 days
  • B.5.3 and 68.9 days
  • C.6.4 and 57 days
  • D.8.0 and 45.6 days
Correct Answer: 6.4 and 57 days

Accounts Receivable Turnover = Net Credit SalesAverge net Accounts Receivables = 800,000100,000 + 150.0002 = 800,000125,000 = 6.4 times

 

Average Collection period in days = Days in YearAccounts receivable turnover = 3656.4 = 57 days

Question 14
Paramour Company reported net income ofRs. 180,000, net sales ofRs. 420,000, and had total assets ofRs. 460,000 on January 1, 2017, and total assets on December 31, 2017, ofRs. 540,000. Determine Paramour’s asset turnover for 2017 from the options given below:
  • A.0.81
  • B.0.84
  • C.0.87
  • D.0.90
Correct Answer: 0.84

The asset turnover for Paramour Company is computed as follows.

 

Asset Turnover = Net SalesAverage Total Assets

 

Average Total Assets = 460,000+540,0002 = 1000,0002 = Rs. 500,000

 

Therefore, Asset Turnover = 420,000500,000 = 0.84

Question 15
Lake Coffee Company reported net sales ofRs. 180,000, net income ofRs. 54,000, beginning total assets ofRs. 200,000, and ending total assets ofRs. 300,000. What was the company’s asset turnover?
  • A.0.90
  • B.0.20
  • C.0.72
  • D.1.39
Correct Answer: 0.72

The asset turnover of Lake Coffee Company is computed as follows.

 

Asset Turnover = Net SalesAverage Total Assets

 

Average Total Assets = 200,000+300,0002 = 500,0002 = Rs. 250,000

 

Therefore, Asset Turnover = 180,000250,000 = 0.72

Question 16
“Higher the ratio, the morefavorableit is.” This presumption does not apply to:
  • A.Operating ratio
  • B.Stock turnover ratio
  • C.Operating profit ratio
  • D.Return on Investment
Correct Answer: Operating ratio

Operating ratio is the ratio of operating expenses to the net sales. Higher this ratio higher would be the operating expense and lower the operating profit. So, a lower ratio is more favorable in terms of business. Therefore, option A is correct.

Operating profit ratio is the ratio between operating profit and the net sales. Higher the ratio, higher would be the operating profit and it would be more favorable.

 

Stock turnover ratio is the relationship between the COGS and the average inventory. It indicates how fast the inventory is sold or used. A high ratio is favorable from the point of view of liquidity and vice versa.

 

ROI shows the returns made from the funds invested by the owners. A higher ratio is always preferred in case of returns.

Question 17
If Orange Ltd.’s current ratio is 5.5:1, Quick ratio is 4:1 and Inventory isRs. 24,000, its current liabilities are:
  • A.Rs. 8,000
  • B.Rs. 16,000
  • C.Rs. 30,000
  • D.Rs. 32,000
Correct Answer: Rs. 16,000

Current Ratio is 5.5, which means current assets are 5.5 times of current liabilities. In other words, if current liabilities be x, then current assets = 5.5x

 

Quick Ratio = Current Assets-InventoryCurrent Liabilities ……(1)

 

Putting the value of current assets = 5.5x and current liabilities = x in equation (1) above

 

41 = 5.5x-24,000x

 

1.5x = 24,000

 

Or x = Rs. 16,000

Question 18
Which of the following measures is an evaluation of a firm’s ability to pay current liabilities?
  • A.Acid-test ratio
  • B.Current ratio
  • C.Both A and B
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Both A and B

Both the acid-test ratio and the current ratio measure a firm’s ability to pay current liabilities.

Question 19
A measure useful in evaluating the efficiency in managing inventories is:
  • A.inventory turnover
  • B.days in inventory
  • C.Both A and B
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Both A and B

Both inventory turnover and days in inventory measure a firm’s efficiency in managing inventories.

Question 20
Raman company has issued 13% debentures forRs. 10,00,000in cash at par. The impact of this item:
  • A.Increase in current assets and working capital
  • B.Increase in current liabilities and working capital
  • C.Increase in current assets but no increase in working capital
  • D.Decrease in current assets and working capital
Correct Answer: Increase in current assets and working capital

The given transaction will lead to increase in current assets and working capital, as the Company will receive Rs. 10,00,000 as cash (which is a current asset). However, the transaction will have no impact on current liabilities, as the money is raised through issue of debentures, which is a long-term liability and not the current liability. Hence, there will be an increase in current assets and increase in working capital (which is equal to Current Assets – Current Liabilities).

Question 21
Particulars20172016Inventory54,00048,000Current Assets81,000106,000Total Assets382,000326,000Current Liabilities27,00036,000Total Liabilities102,00088,000Net Sales784,000697,000Cost of Goods Sold306,000277,000Net Income134,00090,000Income Tax expense22,00018,000Interest Expense12,00012,000Computethe days in inventory for 2017.
  • A.64.4 days
  • B.60.8 days
  • C.6 days
  • D.24 days
Correct Answer: 60.8 days

Inventory turnover = Cost of Goods SoldAverage Inventory = 306,000(54,000+48,000)/2 = 306,00051,000 = 6 times

 

 

Thus, days in inventory = Number of days in a yearInventory Turnover=  3656 = 60.8 days

Question 22
Particulars20172016Inventory54,00048,000Current Assets81,000106,000Total Assets382,000326,000Current Liabilities27,00036,000Total Liabilities102,00088,000Net Sales784,000697,000Cost of Goods Sold306,000277,000Net Income134,00090,000Income Tax expense22,00018,000Interest Expense12,00012,000Computethe current ratio for 2017.
  • A.1.26:1
  • B.3.0:1
  • C.2.94:1
  • D.3.75:1
Correct Answer: 3.0:1

Current Ratio = Current AssetsCurrent Liabilities = 81,00027,000 = 31

Question 23
Particulars20172016Inventory54,00048,000Current Assets81,000106,000Total Assets382,000326,000Current Liabilities27,00036,000Total Liabilities102,00088,000Net Sales784,000697,000Cost of Goods Sold306,000277,000Net Income134,00090,000Income Tax expense22,00018,000Interest Expense12,00012,000Computethe profit margin for 2017.
  • A.17.1%
  • B.18.1%
  • C.37.9%
  • D.5.9%
Correct Answer: 17.1%

Profit margin = Net IncomeNet Sales  =134,000784,000 = 0.1709 or 17.1%.

Question 24
Particulars20172016Inventory54,00048,000Current Assets81,000106,000Total Assets382,000326,000Current Liabilities27,00036,000Total Liabilities102,00088,000Net Sales784,000697,000Cost of Goods Sold306,000277,000Net Income134,00090,000Income Tax expense22,00018,000Interest Expense12,00012,000Compute the times interest earnedfor 2017.
  • A.11.2 times
  • B.65.3 times
  • C.14.0 times
  • D.13.0 times
Correct Answer: 14.0 times

Times interest earned = Net income + Interest expense + Income tax expense Interest expense

 

= 134,000+12,000+22,00012,000

 

= 168,00012,000 = 14 times

Question 25
Rondo Corporation’s comparative balance sheets are presented below.Rondo CorporationBalance Sheets as at December 3120172016Accounts Payable10,37031,100Equity Share Capital75,00069,000Retained Earnings25,13020,000Total110,500120,100Cash5,3003,700Accounts Receivable21,20023,400Inventory9,0007,000Land20,00026,000Buildings70,00070,000Accumulated Depreciation – buildings(15,000)(10,000)Total110,500120,100Rondo’s 2017 income statement included net sales ofRs. 120,000, cost of goods sold ofRs. 70,000, and net income ofRs. 14,000.Compute the current ratio for 2017 and choose your answer from the options given below:
  • A.3.26
  • B.2.90
  • C.3.42
  • D.3.85
Correct Answer: 3.42

Current Ratio =Current AssetsCurrent Liabilities

 

5,300+21,200+9,00010,370 = 3.42

Question 26
Rondo Corporation’s comparative balance sheets are presented below.Rondo CorporationBalance Sheets as at December 3120172016Accounts Payable10,37031,100Equity Share Capital75,00069,000Retained Earnings25,13020,000Total110,500120,100Cash5,3003,700Accounts Receivable21,20023,400Inventory9,0007,000Land20,00026,000Buildings70,00070,000Accumulated Depreciation – buildings(15,000)(10,000)Total110,500120,100Rondo’s 2017 income statement included net sales ofRs. 120,000, cost of goods sold ofRs. 70,000, and net income ofRs. 14,000.Compute the Acid-test ratio for 2017 and choose your answer from the options given below:
  • A.2.56
  • B.3.40
  • C.2.87
  • D.3.90
Correct Answer: 2.56

Acid Test Ratio = Cash+Accounts ReceivableCurrent Liabilities

 

5,300+21,20010,370 = 2.56

Question 27
Rondo Corporation’s comparative balance sheets are presented below.Rondo CorporationBalance Sheets as at December 3120172016Accounts Payable10,37031,100Equity Share Capital75,00069,000Retained Earnings25,13020,000Total110,500120,100Cash5,3003,700Accounts Receivable21,20023,400Inventory9,0007,000Land20,00026,000Buildings70,00070,000Accumulated Depreciation – buildings(15,000)(10,000)Total110,500120,100Rondo’s 2017 income statement included net sales ofRs. 120,000, cost of goods sold ofRs. 70,000, and net income ofRs. 14,000.Compute the Accounts Receivable turnover for 2017 and choose your answer from the options given below:
  • A.6.38
  • B.5.38
  • C.7.38
  • D.9.38
Correct Answer: 5.38

Accounts Receivable Turnover = Net Credit SalesAverage Trade Receivables

 

 

120,000(21,200+23,400)/2 = 5.38

Question 28
Rondo Corporation’s comparative balance sheets are presented below.Rondo CorporationBalance Sheets as at December 3120172016Accounts Payable10,37031,100Equity Share Capital75,00069,000Retained Earnings25,13020,000Total110,500120,100Cash5,3003,700Accounts Receivable21,20023,400Inventory9,0007,000Land20,00026,000Buildings70,00070,000Accumulated Depreciation – buildings(15,000)(10,000)Total110,500120,100Rondo’s 2017 income statement included net sales ofRs. 120,000, cost of goods sold ofRs. 70,000, and net income ofRs. 14,000.Compute the Inventory Turnover for 2017 and choose your answer from the options given below:
  • A.8.50
  • B.8.65
  • C.8.70
  • D.8.75
Correct Answer: 8.75

Inventory Turnover = Cost of Goods SoldAverage Inventory

 

70,000(9,000+7,000)/2 = 8.75

Question 29

  • B.11.5%
  • C.12.0%

14,000120,000 = 0.117 or 11.7%

Question 30
Rondo Corporation’s comparative balance sheets are presented below.Rondo CorporationBalance Sheets as at December 3120172016Accounts Payable10,37031,100Equity Share Capital75,00069,000Retained Earnings25,13020,000Total110,500120,100Cash5,3003,700Accounts Receivable21,20023,400Inventory9,0007,000Land20,00026,000Buildings70,00070,000Accumulated Depreciation – buildings(15,000)(10,000)Total110,500120,100Rondo’s 2017 income statement included net sales ofRs. 120,000, cost of goods sold ofRs. 70,000, and net income ofRs. 14,000.Compute the Asset Turnover for 2017 and choose your answer from the options given below:
  • A.1.90
  • B.1.25
  • C.1.04
  • D.1.65
Correct Answer: 1.04

Asset Turnover = Net SalesAverage Total Assets

 

 

120,000(110,500+120,100)/2 = 1.04

Question 31
Rondo Corporation’s comparative balance sheets are presented below.Rondo CorporationBalance Sheets as at December 3120172016Accounts Payable10,37031,100Equity Share Capital75,00069,000Retained Earnings25,13020,000Total110,500120,100Cash5,3003,700Accounts Receivable21,20023,400Inventory9,0007,000Land20,00026,000Buildings70,00070,000Accumulated Depreciation – buildings(15,000)(10,000)Total110,500120,100Rondo’s 2017 income statement included net sales ofRs. 120,000, cost of goods sold ofRs. 70,000, and net income ofRs. 14,000.Compute the Return on Assets for 2017 and choose your answer from the options given below:
  • A.12.5%
  • B.12.8%
  • C.12.3%
  • D.12.1%
Correct Answer: 12.1%

Return on Assets =  Annual Net Income after tax (Net profit after tax)Average Total Assets

 

14,000(110,500+120,100)/2 = 0.121 or 12.1%

Question 32
Rondo Corporation’s comparative balance sheets are presented below.Rondo CorporationBalance Sheets as at December 3120172016Accounts Payable10,37031,100Equity Share Capital75,00069,000Retained Earnings25,13020,000Total110,500120,100Cash5,3003,700Accounts Receivable21,20023,400Inventory9,0007,000Land20,00026,000Buildings70,00070,000Accumulated Depreciation – buildings(15,000)(10,000)Total110,500120,100Rondo’s 2017 income statement included net sales ofRs. 120,000, cost of goods sold ofRs. 70,000, and net income ofRs. 14,000.Compute the Return on Equity for 2017 and choose your answer from the options given below:
  • A.15.4%
  • B.13.9%
  • C.16.8%
  • D.14.9%
Correct Answer: 13.9%

Return on Equity = Annual Net IncomeEquity Shareholder's Funds

 

14,000(75,000+25,130) = 14,000100,130 = 0.139 or 13.9%

Question 33
Rondo Corporation’s comparative balance sheets are presented below.Rondo CorporationBalance Sheets as at December 3120172016Accounts Payable10,37031,100Equity Share Capital75,00069,000Retained Earnings25,13020,000Total110,500120,100Cash5,3003,700Accounts Receivable21,20023,400Inventory9,0007,000Land20,00026,000Buildings70,00070,000Accumulated Depreciation – buildings(15,000)(10,000)Total110,500120,100Rondo’s 2017 income statement included net sales ofRs. 120,000, cost of goods sold ofRs. 70,000, and net income ofRs. 14,000.Compute the Debt to Assets ratio for 2017 and choose your answer from the options given below:
  • A.8.5%
  • B.9.4%
  • C.7.3%
  • D.10.4%
Correct Answer: 9.4%

Debt to Assets Ratio = Total DebtNet Assets 

 

10,370110,500 = 0.094 or 9.4%

Quiz Attempt #119242

Total Questions: 46
Question 1
A and B are equal partners, when partnership is dissolved, their capital are Rs. 40,000 and Rs. 50,000 respectively. After all assets are sold and liabilities paid, there is a cash balance of Rs. 80,000. What is the amount of profit or loss on realization?(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2023)
  • A.10,000 (Profit)
  • B.20,000 (Profit)
  • C.30,000 (Profit)
  • D.10,000 (Loss)
Correct Answer: 10,000 (Loss)

Total Capital after dissolution = A’s Capital + B’s Capital = 40,000 + 50,000 = Rs. 90,000

Cash balance after sale of all assets and liabilities paid off = Rs. 80,000

 

Therefore, amount of profit or loss = Cash realized – Capital Invested

= 80,000 – 90,000 = (-10,000)

 

So, Rs. 10,000 is the amount of loss on realization.

Question 2
Given below are two statements: One is labelled as AssertionAand the other is labelled as Reason R.(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2023)Assertion ‘A’:When a partner retires, all the assets and liabilities are revalued according to current value.Reason ‘R’:The balance sheet should show the correct values of assets and liabilities.In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both A and R arecorrectand R is the correct explanation of A
  • B.Both A and R arecorrectbut R is not the correct explanation of A
  • C.A is correct but R is not correct
  • D.A is not correct but R is correct
Correct Answer: Both A and R arecorrectbut R is not the correct explanation of A

Assertion A states that when a partner retires, all the assets and liabilities are revalued according to the current value. This assertion is correct because when a partner leaves a partnership firm, it's essential to determine the current value of the assets and liabilities to settle the partner's share of the partnership.

 

Reason R states that the balance sheet should show the correct values of assets and liabilities. This reason is also correct because a balance sheet is a financial statement that provides an accurate representation of a company's financial position, including the values of assets and liabilities.

 

However, while both Assertion A and Reason R are correct, they are not related to each other.

Question 3
P, R and M are Partner in the firm. They shared profit and losses in the ratio of 3:2:1. On 1stApril, R retired. The goodwill of the firm wasvalueattwo yearprofits. The Profitsofthe last threeyearwere asunder:(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2023)2020-21 Profit Rs 2,48,0002021-22 Loss Rs 36,0002022-23 Profit Rs 1,48,000Calculate the amount of Goodwillwith the given information.
  • A.Rs. 2,40,000
  • B.Rs. 1,60,000
  • C.Rs. 2,80,000
  • D.Rs. 2,50,000
Correct Answer: Rs. 2,40,000

Average Business Profits = Total ProfitsNo. of years = 2,48,000-36,000+1,48,0003 = 3,60,0003 = 1,20,000

 

Goodwill = Average Business Profit × 2 = 1,20,000 × 2 = Rs. 2,40,000

Question 4
In which ratio, will the remaining partners compensate the retiring partner for a share of goodwill?(UGC NET Commerce Dec 2023)
  • A.Profit-sharing ratio
  • B.Sacrificing ratio
  • C.Gaining ratio
  • D.Capital ratio
Correct Answer: Gaining ratio

The retiring or deceased partner is entitled to his share of goodwill at the time of retirement/death because the goodwill has been earned by the firm with the efforts of all the existing partners. Hence, at the time of retirement/death of a partner, goodwill is valued as per agreement among the partners the retiring/ deceased partner compensated for his share of goodwill by the continuing partners (who have gained due to acquisition of share of profit from the retiring/ deceased partner) in their gaining ratio.

Question 5
Current assets are Rs 4,00,000, inventories are Rs 2,00,000, and working capital is Rs 2,40,000. Calculate the Current Ratio.(UGC NET Commerce Dec 2024)
  • A.2:1
  • B.2.5:1
  • C.1.5:1
  • D.1:2
Correct Answer: 2.5:1

Question 6
Which of the following statements are true regarding the admission of a new partner?(UGC NET Commerce Dec 2024)A. According to section 25 of the Indian Partnership Act, 1932, a person can be admitted as a partner.B. New Profit-sharing ratio is the ratio in which all partners, including new partners, will share future profits and losses of the firm.C. New Profit Share = Profit Share Sacrificed - Old Profit ShareD. Sacrificing Ratio = Old Profit Share - New Profit ShareE. The Profit or loss which arises from Revaluation Account will be transferred to the partner's capital account.Choose the correct answer:
  • A.B, D, E Only
  • B.A, B, C Only
  • C.B, C, D Only
  • D.C, D, E Only
Correct Answer: B, D, E Only

The correct answer is option (A) i.e., Statement B, D and E are true.

Statement A: Incorrect

Admission of a new partner is governed by Section 31 of the Indian Partnership Act, 1932, not Section 25. As per Section 31, a new partner can be admitted only with the consent of all existing partners unless otherwise agreed.

 

Statement B: Correct

New Profit-Sharing Ratio refers to the ratio in which all partners (including the new partner) will share future profits and losses of the firm.

 

Statement C: Incorrect

The correct formula is New Profit Share = Old Profit Share - Profit Share Sacrificed.

 

Statement D: Correct

Sacrificing Ratio = Old Profit Share - New Profit Share

It represents the proportion of profit that the existing partners give up in favor of the new partner.

 

Statement E: Correct

Profit or loss from Revaluation Account is transferred to the capital accounts of existing partners in their old profit-sharing ratio before the new partner is admitted.

Question 7
The assets of the Partnership firm, including any sums contributed by the partners to make-up deficiencies of capital at the time of dissolution, shall be applied in the following manner and order: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2021)(1) In paying each partnerrateablywhat is due to him for advances as distinguished from capital.(2) In paying to each partnerrateablywhat is due to him on account of capital.(3) In paying the debts of the firm to third parties.(4) Dividing among the partners in the proportion in which they were entitled to share profits.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.3, 1, 2, 4
  • B.3, 2, 1, 4
  • C.1, 2, 3, 4
  • D.2, 3, 1, 4
Correct Answer: 3, 1, 2, 4

In case of dissolution of a firm, the firm ceases to conduct business and has to settle its accounts. For this purpose, it disposes off all its assets for satisfying all the claims against it. In this context it should be noted that, subject to agreement among the partners, the following rules as provided in Section 48 of the Partnership Act 1932 shall apply. 

(a) Treatment of Losses 

Losses, including deficiencies of capital, shall be paid: 

(i) first out of profits, 

(ii) next out of capital of partners, and 

(iii) lastly, if necessary, by the partners individually in their profit-sharing ratio. 

 

(b) Application of Assets 

The assets of the firm, including any sum contributed by the partners to make up deficiencies of capital, shall be applied in the following manner and order: 

(i) In paying the debts of the firm to the third parties; 

(ii) In paying each partner proportionately what is due to him/her from the firm for advances as distinguished from capital (i.e., partner’s loan); 

(iii) In paying to each partner proportionately what is due to him on account of capital; and 

(iv) the residue, if any, shall be divided among the partners in their profit-sharing ratio.

 

Thus, the amount realized from assets along with contribution from partners, if required, shall be utilized first to pay off the outside liabilities of the firm such as creditors, loans, bank overdraft, bill payables, etc. (it may be noted that secured loans have precedence over the unsecured loans); the balance should be applied to repay loans made by the partners to the firm. (in case the balance amount is not adequate enough to pay off such loans and advances, they are to be paid proportionately). The amount left thereafter is utilized in settlement of capital account balances. Then the surplus if any is divided among partners in their profit-sharing ratio.

Question 8
The net profits of a partnership business, after providing for income tax for the last five years were:Rs80,000:Rs1,00,000:Rs1,20,000:Rs1,25,000 andRs2,00,000. The capital employed in the business isRs10,00,000and the normal rate of return is 10%. The value of goodwill on the basis of the annuity method; taking the present value of the annuity of Re 1 for 5 years at 10% is 3.7907 (approx..) will be (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2021)
  • A.Rs2,500 (approx.)
  • B.Rs79,225 (approx.)
  • C.Rs94,770 (approx.)
  • D.Rs2,25,000 (approx.)
Correct Answer: Rs94,770 (approx.)

Under Annuity method, goodwill is calculated by taking average super profit as the value of an annuity over a certain number of years. The present value of this annuity is computed by discounting at the given rate of interest (normal rate of return). This discounted present value of the annuity is the value of goodwill. The value of annuity for Rupee 1 can be known by reference to the annuity tables. 

The value of goodwill will be calculated as follows:

 

Average profit = 6,25,0005 = 1,25,000

Calculation of Super Profits = Average profit – Normal Profits

= 1,25,000 – (10% of 10,00,000)

= 25,000

Value of goodwill – 25,000 × 3.7907 = 94,767.50 (or Rs. 94,770 approx.)

Question 9
‘A’, ‘B’ and ‘C’ are partners sharing profits in the ratio of 3:2:1. ‘D’ is admitted for 1/6thshare and ‘C’ should retain his original share. The sacrificing ratio of A and B will be: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2021)
  • A.1: 2
  • B.2: 3
  • C.3: 2
  • D.2: 1
Correct Answer: 3: 2

A's old share = 36

B's old share = 26

C's old share = 16

 

D is admitted for 1/6th share. C will retain his original share. 

Hence, remaining share= 1- 16 - 16 = 46 = 23

                                    

This remaining share will be shared by A and B in their old ratio, i.e., 3:2

A's new share = 35 × 23 = 25

           

B's new share = 25 × 23 = 415

 

New Profit-sharing ratio = 25: 415: 16:16 or 12:8:5:5

 

Sacrificing ratio = old ratio - new ratio

 

A's sacrifice = 36 - 1230 = 330

 

B's sacrifice = 26 - 830 = 230

 

Sacrificing ratio = 3:2

Question 10
X and Y are partners, sharing profits and losses in the ratio of 4:3. They admit Z into the partnership for 1/5thshare. X and Y decide to share future profits in the ratio of 2:1. What is the sacrificing ratio of X and Y? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2021)
  • A.4:3
  • B.13:8
  • C.8:13
  • D.4:17
Correct Answer: 4:17

Z is admitted as a new partner for 1/5th share.

 

Let total profit = 1

Therefore, share left for X and Y = 1 – 15 = 45

Now, X and Y decide to share future profits in the ratio of 2:1 or23 and 13 respectively.

 

Therefore, 4/5th share in the firm will be divided in the ratio of 2:1, as below:

 

For X = 23 × 45 =815

 

For Y = 13 × 45 = 415

 

Sacrificing ratio = Old profit-sharing ratio – New profit-sharing ratio

 

Calculation of sacrificing ratios

For X = 47 - 815 = 4105

 

For Y = 37 - 415 = 17105

 

Therefore, the sacrificing ratio = 4:17

Question 11
Which of the following are false? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2020)I. Partners are not bound to carry on the business of the firm to the greatest common advantage.II. Where a partner is entitled to interest on capital subscribed by him, such interest shall be payable whether or not there are profits.III. An outgoing partner has a right to claim a share in the profits of the firm till his account is finally settled.IV. A partner may be expelled from the firm only with the consent of all other partners.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.I, II, IV only
  • B.I, III, IV only
  • C.II, IV, III only
  • D.III, IV only
Correct Answer: I, II, IV only

Statement I is false because partners are bound to carry on the business of the firm to the greatest common advantage.

Statement II is false because partner will be entitled to interest on capital only when there are profits.

Statement IV is false because partner cannot be expelled by the consent of partners. He can be expelled only by the rules of contract formed among partners.

 

Section 9 General Duties of Partners: Partners are bound to carry on the business of the firm to greatest common advantage, to be just and faithful to each other, and to render true accounts and full information of all things affecting the firm to any partner, his heir or legal representative.

 

Section 13 Mutual Right and Liabilities: Where a partner is entitled to interest on the capital subscribed by him, such interest shall be payable only out of profits.

 

Section 33 Expulsion of A Partner: A partner may not be expelled from a firm by any majority of the partners, save in the exercise in good faith or powers conferred by contract between the partners.

Question 12
X and Y are partners in a business sharing profits and losses in the ratio of 3:2. They admit Z as a new partner with 1/5 share in the profits. Calculate the new profit-sharing ratio of the partners. (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2020)
  • A.12:8:5
  • B.12:8:6
  • C.12:7:6
  • D.12:3:7
Correct Answer: 12:8:5

X's old share = 35

Y's old share = 25

Z is admitted as a partner for 15 shares

Total share = 1

Remaining share = 1- 15 =45

X's new share = 35 x 45

                        = 1225

Y's new share = 25 x 45

                        = 825

Equating the denominator of Z’s share

Z’s share = 15 x 55= 525

New profit-sharing ratio = 12:8:5

Question 13
Which one of the following statements is ‘True’ in partnership? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2020)
  • A.In the absence of any provision in the partnership deed, only a working partner is entitled to remuneration
  • B.Any firm which earns normal profit has no goodwill
