  • C.The business of the firm must be carried on by all the partners
  • D.Interest on loan given by a partner to the firm shall be paid if there are profits
Correct Answer: Any firm which earns normal profit has no goodwill

Only Statement B is correct in relation to partnership. Over a period, all well-established business develops an advantage of good name, reputation and wide business connections. This helps the business in earning more profits as compared to a newly set up business. In accounting, this monetary value of such an advantage is known as “Goodwill”. Thus, goodwill exists only when the firm earns super profits. Any firm that earns normal profits or is incurring losses has no goodwill.

 

Statement A is incorrect, a partner is not entitled to receive remuneration for taking part in the conduct of the business.

 

Statement C is incorrect, because according to Sec. 4 of the Indian Partnership Act. 1932, partnership can be carried on by all or any one of them acting for all.

 

Statement D is incorrect, because if a partner has provided any Loan to the firm, he would be paid Interest at the rate 6% p.a. This interest on loan is a charge against profits i.e., it is to be allowed even if there are losses to the firm.

Question 14
Which of the following types of goodwill is considered to be the best?(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2019)
  • A.Dog goodwill
  • B.Cat goodwill
  • C.Rat goodwill
  • D.Cow goodwill
Correct Answer: Cat goodwill

P. D. Leake has classified goodwill as:

 

(i) Dog-Goodwill: There are some businesses whose goodwill depends on the owner. Such goodwill is called Dog Goodwill and its value is less. Certain customers are attached to the owner of the business due to his exceptional skill, personality, honesty etc. This applies specifically to professionals like Chartered Accountants, Doctors, Lawyers, and Sweet-stall Owners etc. Dog goodwill is difficult to transfer and is correspondingly less valuable.

(ii) Cat-Goodwill: The cat stays in the old home although the person who has kept the home leaves, and so it represents the customer who goes to the old shop whoever keeps it and provides local goodwill. This type of goodwill has stability and therefore its value is always maximum. Hence, this type of goodwill is considered to be the best.

(iii) Rat-Goodwill: The characteristic of a rat is that it moves from place to place. The rat has no attachments and is purely casual. If the Goodwill of a business often changes, it is known as Rat Goodwill. Such goodwill is valueless.

(iv) Rabbit Goodwill: The rabbit is attracted by mere propinquity. He comes because he happens to live close by and it would be more troublesome to go elsewhere.

Note: There is no concept as Cow Goodwill.

Question 15
A andB are partners in a firm sharing profits in the ratio of 3:2. They admit X as a partner for 1/3 share in profits of the firm. The new profit-sharing ratio of A, B and X is (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2018)
  • A.3:2:2
  • B.3:2:1
  • C.6:4:5
  • D.3:2:3
Correct Answer: 6:4:5

Working note of new profit-sharing ratio after X’s admission to partnership:

Old or existing ratio between A: B = 3: 2 or A’s share =35 and B’s share = 25

 

X’s share from A = 35 × 13 = 315

 

A’s share after X’s admission = 35 - 315 = 615

 

X’ share from B = 25 × 13 = 215

 

B’s share after X’s admission = 25 - 215 = 415

 

And, X’s share of profit taken from A and B = 315 + 215 = 515

 

Therefore, the new ratio of profit of A, B and X will be 615, 415 and 515 or 6:4:5, hence the option C is correct.

Question 16
A andB are partners in a firm sharing profit and loss in the ratio of 3: 2. They admit C into partnership for ¼ share and the new ratio between A and B is 2: 1. The sacrificing ratio is (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2011)
  • A.1: 1
  • B.2: 1
  • C.3: 1
  • D.2: 3
Correct Answer: 2: 3

C is admitted as a new partner for 1/4th share.

 

Let total profit = 1

Therefore, share left for A and B = 1 – 14 = 34

Now, A and B decide to share future profits in the ratio of 2:1 or 23 and 13 respectively.

 

Therefore, 3/4th share in the firm will be divided in the ratio of 2:1, as below:

 

For A = 23 × 34 =24

 

For B = 13 × 34 = 14

 

Sacrificing ratio = Old profit-sharing ratio – New profit-sharing ratio

 

Calculation of sacrificing ratios

For A = 35 - 24 = 220

 

For B = 25 - 14 = 320

 

Therefore, the sacrificing ratio = 2: 3

Question 17
X and Y are partners in a firm. They withdrew @ ₹ 1,500 and ₹ 1,000 respectively on 15th day of every months for all the twelve months during 2009. Interest on drawings is chargeable @ 10% per annum. What would be the interest on drawings respectively? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2011)
  • A.₹ 1,800 and ₹ 1,200
  • B.₹ 900 and ₹ 600
  • C.₹ 18,000 and ₹ 12,000
  • D.₹ 150 and ₹ 100
Correct Answer: ₹ 900 and ₹ 600

Many a time, a fixed amount of money is withdrawn by the partners, at equal time interval, say each month.

While calculating the time period, attention must be paid to whether the fixed amount was withdrawn at the beginning (first day) of the month, middle of the month or at the end (last day) of the month.

If withdrawn on the first day of every month, interest on total amount will be calculated for 6½ months.

If withdrawn at the end at every month, interest on total amount will be calculated for 5½ months.

If withdrawn during the middle of the month, interest on total amount will be calculated for 6 months.

 

Therefore, interest on drawings in this case shall be computed as follows.

Interest on drawing of Mr. X = 1500 × 12 × 10 × 6100 ×  12 = Rs. 900

 

Interest on drawing of Mr. Y = 1000 × 12 × 10 × 6100 ×  12 = Rs. 600

Question 18
A andB are partners sharing profits in the ratio of 2:3. They admit C for 1/4th share in the business. The sacrificing ratio of A and B is: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2009)
  • A.3: 1
  • B.1: 4
  • C.2: 3
  • D.1: 1
Correct Answer: 2: 3

A's old share = 25

B's old share = 35

 

D is admitted for 1/4th share.

Hence, remaining share= 1- 14 = 34

                                    

This remaining share will be shared by A and B in their old ratio, i.e., 2:3

A's new share = 34 × 25 = 620

           

B's new share = 34 × 35 = 920

 

C’s Share = 14 or 520

 

 

New Profit-sharing ratio = 6: 9: 5

 

Sacrificing ratio = old ratio - new ratio

 

A's sacrifice = 25 - 620 = 220

 

B's sacrifice = 35 - 920 = 320

 

Sacrificing ratio = 2:3

Question 19
X and Y sharing profits in the ratio of 7: 3, admit Z for 3/7 share in the new firm in which he takes 2/7 from X and 1/7 from Y. The new ratio of X, Y and Z will be: (UGC NET Commerce Jul 2018)
  • A.7: 3: 3
  • B.4: 2: 3
  • C.14: 6: 15
  • D.29: 11: 30
Correct Answer: 29: 11: 30

X’s old share = 7/10

X’s sacrifice for Z = 2/7

X’s new share = 7/10 – 2/7 = 29/70

Y’s old share = 3/10

Y’s sacrifice for Z = 1/7

Y’s new share = 3/10 – 1/7 = 11/70

Z’s share = 3/7 = 30/70

New Profit Sharing Ratio among X, Y and Z is 29:11:30.

Question 20
Goodwill of a firm of X and Y is valued at ₹ 30,000. It is appearing in the books at ₹ 12,000. Z is admitted for 1/4 share. What amount he is supposed to bring for goodwill? (UGC NET Commerce Nov 2017)
  • A.₹ 3,000
  • B.₹ 4,500
  • C.₹ 7,500
  • D.₹ 10,500
Correct Answer: ₹ 4,500

Goodwill of the firm is valued at = Rs. 30,000

Existing Goodwill = Rs. 12,000

Goodwill to be brought in by C = Rs. (30,000 - 12,000) × 1 4= Rs. 4,500

Question 21
A, B and C are partners in a firm sharing profits and losses in the ratio of 4: 3: 2. They agreed to take D into partnership and gave him 1/8 share. What will be their new profit-sharing ratio? (UGC NET Commerce Jul 2016)
  • A.4: 3: 2: 1
  • B.28: 21: 14: 9
  • C.28: 21: 14: 8
  • D.4: 1: 2: 1
Correct Answer: 28: 21: 14: 9

Let total profit = 1

 

‘D’ is admitted with Share = 18

 

Remaining share = 1 – 18 = 78

 

A’s share = 49 of 78 = 2872

 

B’s share = 39 of 78 = 2172

 

C’s share = 29 of 78 = 1472

 

D’s share = 18 or 972

 

Thus, the new ratio among A, B, C and D is. 28: 21: 14: 9.

Question 22
Ram andShyamare partners in a firm with capital of ₹ 4,80,000and ₹ 3,10,000, respectively. They admitted Ganesh as a partner with 1/4th share of profit. Ganesh brings ₹ 3,00,000as his capital. Ganesh’s share of goodwill will be (UGC NET Commerce Jul 2016)
  • A.₹ 1,10,000
  • B.₹ 27,500
  • C.₹ 17,500
  • D.₹ 70,000
Correct Answer: ₹ 27,500

When in the question goodwill is not specifically given, then it is case of hidden goodwill.

 

Calculation of hidden goodwill:

As Ganesh is admitted as a partner with ¼ share of profit and he is bringing Rs. 3,00,000 as capital, then the total capital = 3,00,000 ×41=12,00,000

But, the actual capital of all three is = 4,80,000 + 3,10,000 + 3,00,000 = 10,90,000

Therefore, hidden goodwill = 1,10,000

 

Ganesh's share of goodwill for 1/4th share = Total goodwill/4 = 110000/4 = Rs. 27,500

Question 23
When a firm is dissolved, profit or loss on realisation is shared by the partners (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2014)
  • A.Equal
  • B.In the ratio of their capital balances
  • C.In the profit-sharing ratio
  • D.In the ratio laid down in Garner Vs. Murray
Correct Answer: In the profit-sharing ratio

When the firm is dissolved, its books of account are to be closed and the profit or loss arising on realisation of its assets and discharge of liabilities is to be computed. For this purpose, a Realisation Account is prepared to ascertain the net effect (profit or loss) of realisation of assets and payment of liabilities which is transferred to partner’s capital accounts in their profit-sharing ratio. Realisation Account is a Nominal Account.

 

Hence, all assets (other than cash in hand, bank balance and fictitious assets, if any), and all external liabilities are transferred to this account. It also records the sale of assets, and payment of liabilities and realisation expenses. The balance in this account is termed as profit or loss on realisation which is transferred to partners’ capital accounts in their profit-sharing ratio.

Question 24
A, a partner in a firm, is drawing ₹ 500 regularly on the 16th of every month. He will have to pay interest at the given rate in a year on ₹ 6000 for the total period of(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2014)
  • A.5 months
  • B.6 months
  • C.7 months
  • D.12 months
Correct Answer: 6 months

Many a time, a fixed amount of money is withdrawn by the partners, at equal time interval, say each month.

While calculating the time period, attention must be paid to whether the fixed amount was withdrawn at the beginning (first day) of the month, middle of the month or at the end (last day) of the month.

If withdrawn on the first day of every month, interest on total amount will be calculated for 6½ months.

If withdrawn at the end at every month, interest on total amount will be calculated for 5½ months.

If withdrawn during the middle of the month, interest on total amount will be calculated for 6 months.

Since, in the given case, Mr. A is withdrawing money during the middle of the month, interest on total amount of Rs. 6,000 will be calculated for total period of 6 months.

Question 25
A andB are partners sharing profits in the ratio of 3:1. They admit C for 1/4 share in the future profits. The new profit-sharing ratio will be:
  • A.A= 9/16 B= 3/16 C= 4/16
  • B.A= 8/16 B= 4/16 C= 4/16
  • C.A= 10/16 B= 2/16 C= 4/16
  • D.A= 8/16 B= 9/16 C= 10/16
Correct Answer: A= 9/16 B= 3/16 C= 4/16

Old profit-sharing ratio among A: B = 3:1

Now, C is admitted into partnership for ¼ share.

Let total profit = 1

Remaining profit = 1 – ¼ = ¾

This remaining profit will be distributed among A and B in their Old profit-sharing ratio.

Thus, New share of A = 34 × 34 = 916

New share of B = 34 × 14 = 316

Therefore, New Profit-sharing ratio A: B: C = 916 : 316 : 14 = 916 : 316 : 416

Question 26
X and Y share profits in the ratio of 3:2. Z was admitted as a partner who gets 1/5 share. New profit-sharing ratio, if Z acquires 3/20 from X and 1/20 from Y would be:
  • A.9: 7: 4
  • B.8: 8: 4
  • C.6: 10: 4
  • D.10: 6: 4
Correct Answer: 9: 7: 4

Old profit sharing ratio among X : Y = 3:2

Now, Z is admitted into the partnership firm for 1/5 share.

Given, X’s sacrifice = 320 Y’s sacrifice = 120

New share = Old share – Sacrificing share

Therefore, new share of X = 35 – 320 = 920

New share of Y = 25 – 120 = 720

Therefore, New Profit-Sharing Ratio X: Y: Z = 920 : 720 : 15 = 920 : 720 : 420

Question 27
Depreciation fund given in the balance sheet is _________.
  • A.Credited to old partners in their old profit-sharing ratio
  • B.Debited to old partners in their old profit-sharing ratio
  • C.Credited to all partners in the new profit-sharing ratio
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: None of the above

Depreciation fund is an investment of a sum equal to the depreciation allowance for the assets. Depreciation fund is shown on the liabilities side and depreciation fund investment account on the asset side of the balance sheet. Depreciation fund in the balance sheet will not be distributed among the partners upon admission, retirement, death.

Question 28
A & B are partners in a business sharing profits and losses in the ratio of 7:3. They admit C as a partner. A sacrificed 1/7th share and B sacrificed 1/3rd of his share in favour of C. New Profit-sharing ratio will be?
  • A.3:1:1
  • B.2:1:1
  • C.2:2:1
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: 3:1:1

New profit-sharing ratios:

 

A 710 – ( 17 ×  710 )= 610

 

B 310 - (13 × 310) = 210

 

C (17  × 710 )+ (13 × 310) = 210

 

Therefore, the new profit-sharing ratio of A, B & C = 6:2:2 or 3:1:1

Question 29
A and B share profits and losses in the ratio of 3: 1, C is admitted into partnership for 1/4 share. The sacrificing ratio of A and B is:
  • A.Equal
  • B.3: 1
  • C.2: 1
  • D.3: 2
Correct Answer: 3: 1

Old profit-sharing ratio among A: B = 3:1

Now, C is admitted into partnership for ¼ share.

Let total profit = 1

Remaining profit = 1 – ¼ = ¾

This remaining profit will be distributed among A and B in their Old profit-sharing ratio.

Thus, New share of A = 34 × 34 = 916

New share of B = 34 × 14 = 316

Sacrificing share = Old share – New share

Therefore, sacrificing share of A = 34 – 916 = 316

Sacrificing share of B = 14 – 316 = 116

Sacrificing Ratio A: B = 3:1

Question 30
At the time of admission of a new partner, general reserve appearing in the old balance sheet is transferred to:
  • A.All partner’s capital account
  • B.New partner’s capital account
  • C.Old partner’s capital account
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Old partner’s capital account

At the time of admission of a new partner, general reserve appearing in the old balance sheet is transferred to Old partners’ capital account.

Sometimes a firm may have accumulated profits not yet transferred to capital accounts of the partners. These are usually in the form of general reserve, reserve fund and/or Profit and Loss Account balance.

The new partner is not entitled to have any share in such accumulated profits. These are distributed among the partners by transferring it to their capital accounts in old profit-sharing ratio.

Similarly, if there are some accumulated losses in the form of a debit balance of profit and loss account appearing in the balance sheet of the firm which is a remote possibility, the same should also be transferred to the old partners’ capital accounts.

Question 31
A partnership firm earned net profits during the last 3 years as follows:2001 150002002 200002003 25000The capital investment in the firm throughout the above-mentioned period has beenRs. 100000. Having regard to the risk involved 15% is considered to be a fair return on capital. Goodwill based on 2 years purchase of average super profit earned during the above mentioned 3 years will be?
  • A.Rs. 8000
  • B.Rs. 10000
  • C.Rs. 12000
  • D.Rs. 15000
Correct Answer: Rs. 10000

Normal profit = Capital employed ×Normal rate of return100 = 100000 ×15100 = 15000

 

Net profits = 15000 + 20000 + 25000 = 60000

 

Average profit = 600003 = 20000

 

Super profit = Average profit – Normal profit = 20000 – 15000 = 5000

 

Therefore, Goodwill = Super profit × Number of years of purchase = 5000 × 2 = Rs.10000.

Question 32
A, B & C are partners sharing profits in the ratio of 3:2:1. B retires and goodwill of the firm is fixed atRs. 180000. No goodwill A/c appears in the books of the firm. A & C decide to share profits in the ratio of 3:1. B’s share of goodwill will be adjusted in the Capital accounts of A and C in?
  • A.Profit sharing
  • B.Gaining ratio
  • C.Sacrificing ratio
  • D.Old ratio
Correct Answer: Gaining ratio

When Goodwill does not appear in the Books and Goodwill is raised to the extent of retired/deceased partner’s share and written off immediately, goodwill account is raised only to the extent of retired/deceased partner’s share by debiting goodwill account with the proportionate amount and credited only to the retired/deceased partner’s capital account. Thereafter, the remaining partners’ capital accounts are debited in their gaining ratio and goodwill account is credited to write it off. The journal entries to be passed to record this are given below.

 

1. When goodwill is raised to the extent of the retired/deceased partner’s share.

Goodwill Account …Dr.

To Retired/Deceased Partner’s Capital A/c (Proportionate amount of Goodwill as per the share of Retired/Deceased Partner)

 

2. When goodwill raised at its full value is to be written off.

Remaining Partners Capital Account …Dr. (Individually in their Gaining Ratio)

To Goodwill Account

 

In the given question, B’s share of goodwill will be adjusted in the Capital accounts of A and C in their gaining ratio.

Question 33
Asha andNishaare partner’s sharing profit in the ratio of 2:1. Asha’s son Ashish was admitted for 1/4 share of which 1/8 was gifted by Asha to her son. The remaining was contributed byNisha. Goodwill of the firm is valued atRs. 40,000. How much of the goodwill will be credited to the old partner’s capital account?
  • A.Rs. 2,500 each
  • B.Rs. 5,000 each
  • C.Rs. 20,000 each
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Rs. 5,000 each

Old profit sharing ratio among Asha: Nisha = 2:1

Now, Ashish is admitted into the partnership for ¼ share.

Asha’s sacrifice = 18

Nisha’s sacrifice = 14 - 18 = 18

 

Therefore, Sacrificing ratio Asha: Nisha = 1:1

 

Amount of goodwill to be distributed as compensation to sacrificing partners = ¼ of Rs. 40,000 = Rs. 10,000

 

Amount of goodwill will be credited to the old partner’s capital account in sacrificing ratio = Rs. 10,000 (i.e. in the ratio of 1:1), that is Rs. 5,000 each.

Question 34
A, B and C are partners in a firm. If D is admitted as a new partner:
  • A.Old firm is dissolved
  • B.Old firm and old partnership is dissolved
  • C.Old partnership is reconstituted
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Old partnership is reconstituted

According to the Partnership Act 1932, a new partner can be admitted into the firm only with the consent of all the existing partners unless otherwise agreed upon. With the admission of a new partner, the partnership firm is reconstituted, and a new agreement is entered into to carry on the business of the firm.

Question 35
On the admission of a new partner, increase in the value of assets is debited to:
  • A.Profit and Loss Adjustment account
  • B.Assets account
  • C.Old partner’s capital account
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Assets account

On the admission of a new partner increase, in the value of assets is debited to Assets account.

At the time of admission, a revaluation account is opened to record the revisions in the amounts of existing assets and liabilities of partnership firm. Revaluation account is a nominal account; thus, it is credited with incomes/gains, that is, decrease in the value of liabilities or increase in the value of assets. Likewise, revaluation account is debited with any expenses/losses, that is, increase in the value of liabilities or decrease in the value of assets. The revaluation account’s balancing figure is net profit or net loss which is transferred to old partners’ capital account in their old profit-sharing ratio.

Any increase in the value of assets is credited to revaluation account and the same is debited to assets account to bring the asset to its revised value.

Question 36
Average profit = Rs.372000, Normal rate of return = 12%, Total assets = Rs.6800000, Outside liabilities = Rs.4200000. Calculate the value of goodwill under capitalization method.
  • A.Rs.500000
  • B.Rs.600000
  • C.Rs.700000
  • D.Rs.800000
Correct Answer: Rs.500000

Capitalised Value of Average Profits = Average profits × 100Normal rate of return

 

 

 

= 372000 × 10012

 

= Rs.3100000

 

Capital employed = Total assets - Outside liabilities = 6800000 – 4200000 = 2600000

 

Goodwill = Capitalised Value of Average Profits – Capital Employed

= Rs.3100000 – Rs.2600000

= Rs.500000.

Question 37
A & B are partners in a firm in the ratio of 5:3. C is admitted as a new partner. He gets 1/4thof A’s share and 1/5thof B’s share. The new profit-sharing ratio is ______?
  • A.19:08:09
  • B.20:15:9
  • C.75:48:37
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: 75:48:37

A & B are partners in a firm in the ratio of 5:3.

C gets 1/4 th of A’s share and 1/5 th of B’s share.

 

Therefore, profit sharing ratio of C = ( 14 × 58 ) + ( 15 × 38 ) = 37160

 

Profit sharing ratio of A = Present share – Share taken by C = 58 – ( 14 × 58 ) = 1532 or 75160

 

 

Profit sharing ratio of B = Present share – Share taken by C = 38 – ( 15 × 38  ) = 1240 or 48160

 

Therefore, the new profit-sharing ratio is 75:48:37.

Question 38
In the absence of agreement between the partners, on the death of a partner, his legal representatives are entitled to ________.
  • A.Profits till death, JLP, Interest on capital, Revaluation profit, Goodwill
  • B.Profits till death, JLP, Interest on capital, Goodwill
  • C.Profits till death, Capital, JLP, Revaluation profit, Goodwill
  • D.Profits till death, Interest on capital, Goodwill
Correct Answer: Profits till death, Capital, JLP, Revaluation profit, Goodwill

In the absence of agreement between the partners, on the death of a partner, his legal representatives are entitled to share in profits till death, Capital, Joint life policy, Revaluation profit and Goodwill.

Question 39
At the time of admission of a partner, undistributed profits appearing in the balance sheet of the old firm is transferred to the capital account of:
  • A.Old partners in old profit-sharing ratio
  • B.Old partners in new profit-sharing ratio
  • C.All the partner in the new profit-sharing ratio
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Old partners in old profit-sharing ratio

At the time of admission of a partner, undistributed profits appearing in the balance sheet of the old firm is transferred to the capital account of old partners in old profit sharing ratio.

To expand the business in the future, the partnership firm reserves some profits as General Reserve or undistributed profits. These accumulated profits appear in the liabilities side of the Balance Sheet.

These undistributed profits belong to old partners. Therefore, these undistributed profits are transferred to the old partners’ account in their old profit-sharing ratio before the admission of a new partner.

In the same manner, it is possible that undistributed losses, if any, may appear in the assets side of the Balance Sheet. These undistributed losses are also transferred to Partners’ Capital/Current Account in the old profit-sharing ratio. After these adjustments, the general reserve or undistributed losses do not appear in the Balance Sheet.

Question 40
Abhishek,RajatandVivekare partners sharing profits in the ratio of 5:3:2. IfVivekretires, the New Profit-Sharing Ratio betweenAbhishekandRajatwill be:
  • A.3:2
  • B.5:3
  • C.5:2
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: 5:3

Old profit sharing ratio Abhishek : Rajat : Vivek = 5:3:2

Now, Vivek retires. Since no information regarding gaining ratio or new profit-sharing ratio among Abhishek and Rajat is provided, it is assumed that Abhishek and Rajat will acquire Vivek’s share in their old profit sharing ratio, that is, in 5:3.

Therefore, gaining ratio among Abhishek: Rajat = 5:3

Gaining share of Abhishek = 58 × 210 = 1080

Gaining share of Rajat = 38 × 210 = 680

New share = Old share + Gaining share

Therefore, new share of Abhishek = 510 + 1080 = 5080 = 58

New share of Rajat = 310 + 680 = 3080 = 38

Therefore, New Profit-sharing ratio of Abhishek: Rajat = 5:3

Question 41
X and Y are partners in a firm sharing profits in the ratio 4:5. X surrenders 1/4 of his share and Y surrenders 1/5 of his share in favour of Z, the new partner. What will be the new profit-sharing ratio of the firm's partners? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2022)
  • A.3:4:2
  • B.55:44:81
  • C.4:5:2
  • D.44:55:81
Correct Answer: 3:4:2

X’s old share = 49

Share sacrificed in favour of Z = 49 × 14 = 19

X’s new share = 49 – 19 = 39  

 

Y’s old share = 59

Share surrendered in favour of Z = 59 × 15 = 19 

Y’s new share = 59 - 19 = 49

 

Z’s share = 19 + 19 = 29

 

New Profit-Sharing Ratio among X, Y and Z is 3:4:2.

Question 42
Given below are two statements: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022)One is labelled as Assertion A and the other is labelled as Reason R.Assertion A:There is a change in the profit-sharing ratio of the old partners when a new partner gets his share of profit from all the partners.Reasons R:When a new partner is admitted into the partnership for a certain share of profit, the combined shares of the old partners will be reduced.In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both A and R are correct and R is the correct explanation of A.
  • B.Both A and R are correct but R is NOT the correct explanation of A.
  • C.A is true but R is false.
  • D.A is false but R is true.
Correct Answer: Both A and R are correct and R is the correct explanation of A.

Assertion A states that there is a change in the profit-sharing ratio of the old partners when a new partner gets his share of profit from all the partners. This is correct because the introduction of a new partner typically involves a redistribution of profits among all partners.

 

Reason R provides an explanation for Assertion A, stating that when a new partner is admitted into the partnership for a certain share of profit, the combined shares of the old partners will be reduced. This is also correct, as the total profit needs to be shared among the existing and new partners, leading to a change in the profit-sharing ratios of the old partners.

Question 43
X & Y are partners sharing profits and losses in the ratio of 3:2. They admit Z as a new partner with 1/5 share in the profits. Calculate the new profit-sharing ratio of the partners. (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2022)
  • A.12:8:5
  • B.12:8:6
  • C.12:7:6
  • D.12:3:7
Correct Answer: 12:8:5

Let the total profit be 1

‘Z’ is admitted with Share = 15

Remaining share = 1 – 15 = 45

X’s share = 45 × 35 = 1225

Y’s share = 45 × 25 = 825

Z’s share = 15 or 525

Thus, the new ratio among X, Y and Z is. 12:8:5.

Question 44
The profit for the year before appropriation in a partnership firm wasRs. 50,000.Shagun, one of the partners, receives a salary ofRs. 4,000 and interest at ten per cent per annum on his capital ofRs. 1,00,000. Amir, the other partner, receives interest on capital at the same rate asShagun. Amir's capital wasRs. 89,000. They share profits and losses equally. What was the total share of profits credited to Amir's current account? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022)
  • A.Rs. 13,550
  • B.Rs. 15,350
  • C.Rs. 22, 450
  • D.Rs. 24,350
Correct Answer: Rs. 22, 450

Profit and Loss Appropriation Account is merely an extension of the Profit and Loss Account of the firm. It shows how the profits are appropriated or distributed among the partners. All adjustments in respect of partner’s salary, partner’s commission, interest on capital, interest on drawings, etc. are made through this account. It starts with the net profit/net loss as per Profit and Loss Account is transferred to this account.

Profit & Loss Appropriation Account

 

Particulars

Amt.

(in Rs.)

Particulars

Amt.

(in Rs.)

Interest on capital (10,000 + 8,900))

18,900

Profit and Loss Account

50,000

Salary to partner (Shagun)

4,000

 

 

Partners’ Capital Account:

(Distribution of Profit)

Amir’ current account – 13,550

Shagun current account – 13,550

 

 

 

27,100

 

 

Total

50,000

Total

50,000

 

Therefore, Amir’ current accounted will be credited with total share of Rs. 13,550 + Rs. 8,900 = Rs. 22,450.

Question 45
Which one of the following rights is usually not available to a partner consequent to the dissolution of a firm? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022)
  • A.Right of equitable distribution of firm’s property
  • B.Right to return of premium on premature winding up
  • C.Right to be consulted
  • D.Right to restrain any partner or his representative from the use of firm name or firm property
Correct Answer: Right to be consulted

The question is based on the provisions of Indian Partnership Act of 1932. Following are the relevant provisions.

 

RIGHT OF PARTNERS TO HAVE BUSINESS WOUND UP AFTER DISSOLUTION (Section 46) - On the dissolution of a firm, every partner or his representative is entitled, as against all the other partners or their representatives, to have the property of the firm applied in payment of the debts and liabilities of the firm, and to have the surplus distributed among the partners or which representatives according to their rights.

 

RETURN OF PREMIUM ON PREMATURE DISSOLUTION (Section 51) - Where a partner has paid a premium on entering into partnership for a fixed term, and the firm is dissolved before the expiration of that term otherwise than by the death of a partner, he shall be entitled to repayment of the premium or of such part thereof as may be reasonable, regard being had to the terms upon which he became a partner, and to the length of time during which he was a partner, unless -(A) the dissolution is mainly due to his own misconduct, or(B) the dissolution is in pursuance of an agreement containing no provision for the return of the premium or any part of it.

 

RIGHT TO RESTRAIN FROM USE OF FIRM-NAME OR FIRM-PROPERTY (Section 53) - After a firm is dissolved, every partner or his representative may, in the absence of a contract between the partners to the contrary, restrain any other partner or his representative from carrying on a similar business in the firm-name or from using any of the property of the firm for his own benefit, until the affairs of the firm have been completely wound up : Provided that where any partner or his representative has brought the goodwill of the firm, nothing in this section shall affect his right to use the firm-name.

 

Thus, option C is correct.

Question 46
When the incoming partner cannot bring premium for goodwill, then the necessary adjustment for goodwill is done through which one of the following? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022)
  • A.Goodwill account of the partners
  • B.Capital account of the new partners
  • C.Balance sheet of the new partnership firm
  • D.Profit & Loss Appropriation account
Correct Answer: Capital account of the new partners

When the incoming partner cannot bring premium for goodwill, then the necessary adjustment for goodwill is done through capital account of the new partners.

Quiz Attempt #119243

Total Questions: 40
Question 1
In the admission of a partner, the new partner is liable ________.
  • A.After the date of admission
  • B.Before the date of admission
  • C.Before and after the date of admission
  • D.None
Correct Answer: After the date of admission

Option A is correct. The new partner is liable from the date of his admission to the partnership. Each partner is liable jointly with all the other partners and also severally to the third party for all the acts of the firm done while he is a partner. Not only that, the liability of a partner for acts of the firm is also unlimited. This implies that his private assets can be used to pay off firm’s debts.

Question 2
X and Y are partners sharing profits and losses in the ratio of 3:2. They admitted Z for 1/4thshare. The new profit-sharing ratio will be ________.
  • A.9:6:5
  • B.9:8:5
  • C.9:5:6
  • D.5:6:9
Correct Answer: 9:6:5

Old profit-sharing ratio of X and Y is 3:2.

Z is admitted for 1/4th share in the profits.

Let total profit = 1

Z is admitted with Share = 14

 

Remaining share = 1 – 14 = 34

 

X’s share = 35 × 34 = 920

 

Y’s share = 25 × 34 = 620

 

R’s share = 14 or 520

 

Thus, the new ratio among X, Y and Z is 9:6:5.

Question 3
If there is no partnership deed, the profits will be shared by thepartners_________.
  • A.As per capitals ratio
  • B.Equally
  • C.As per seniority
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Equally

As per the Indian Partnership Act, 1932, if there is no partnership deed in place, then Profit sharing Ratio will be equal, irrespective of capital contribution of the partners.

Question 4
The old profit-sharing ratio amongRajender,SatishandTejpalwere 2:2:1. The New Profit-Sharing Ratio afterSatish’sretirement is 3:2. The gaining ratio is ________.
  • A.3:2
  • B.2:1
  • C.1:1
  • D.2:2
Correct Answer: 1:1

Old profit-sharing ratio among Rajender, Satish and Tejpal = 2:2:1

Now, Satish retires and the new profit sharing ratio is Rajender : Tejpal = 3:2

Gaining ratio = New ratio – Old ratio

Gaining share of Rajender = 35 - 25 = 15

Gaining share of Tejpal = 25 - 15 = 15

Therefore, gaining ratio = 1:1

Question 5
Anand,BahadurandChanderare partners sharing profits equally onChander’sretirement; his share is acquired byAnandandBahadurin the ratio of 3:2. The New Profit-Sharing Ratio betweenAnandandBahadurwill be _______.
  • A.8:7
  • B.4:5
  • C.3:2
  • D.2:3
Correct Answer: 8:7

Old profit-sharing ratio between Anand: Bahadur: Chandar = 1:1:1

Now, Chander retires, and his share is acquired by Anand and Bahadur in the ratio of 3:2.

Therefore, Gaining ratio of Anand: Bahadur = 3:2

Anand’s gain = 13 × 35 = 315

Bahadur’s gain = 13 × 25 = 215

Anand’s new share = Old share + Gaining share = 13 + 315 = 815

Bahadur’s new share = Old share + Gaining share = 13 + 215 = 715

Therefore, New profit-sharing ratio of Anand: Bahadur = 8:7

Question 6
In the absence of any information regarding the acquisition of share in profit of the retiring/deceased partner by the remaining partners, it is assumed that they will acquire his/her share:
  • A.Old Profit-Sharing Ratio
  • B.New Profit-Sharing Ratio
  • C.Equal Ratio
  • D.None of these
Correct Answer: Old Profit-Sharing Ratio

In the absence of any information regarding the acquisition of share in profit of the retiring/deceased partner by the remaining partners, it is assumed that they will acquire his/her share in their old profit-sharing ratio.

 

Normally, the continuing partners acquire the share of retiring or deceased partners in the old profit-sharing ratio, and there is no need to compute the new profit-sharing ratio among them, as it will be same as the old profit-sharing ratio among them. In fact, in the absence of any information regarding profit sharing ratio in which the remaining partners acquire the share of retiring/deceased partner, it is assumed that they will acquire it in the old profit-sharing ratio and so share the future profits in their old ratio. For example, Asha, Deepti and Nisha are partners in a firm sharing profits and losses in the ratio of 3:2:1. If Deepti retires, the new profit-sharing ratio between Asha and Nisha will be 3:1, and Asha and Nisha will acquire Deepti’s share in the ratio of 3:1, that is, in their old profit-sharing ratio itself.

Question 7
A, B and C are the partners sharing profits and losses in the ratio of 2: 2:1. They changed the ratio to 3: 4: 5. They had workmen’s compensation fund. How it will be distributed on the change of ratio?
  • A.Capital Ratio
  • B.Old profit-sharing ratio
  • C.New profit-sharing ratio
  • D.Not at all distributed
Correct Answer: Old profit-sharing ratio

Option B is correct. Workmen’s compensation fund is distributed in old profit sharing ratio. Workmen’s compensation Fund helps in replacing employer’s liability and giving prompt and equitable protection against injury, disease, disability, or death resulting from employment to the employees.

Question 8
Ram is a partner. He made drawings as follows:July 1 – Rs.200August 1 – Rs.200September – 1 Rs.300November 1 – Rs.50February 1 – Rs.100If the rate of interest on drawings is 6% and accounts are closed on March 31 the interest on drawings is:
  • A.Rs. 29.75
  • B.Rs. 35
  • C.Rs. 30
  • D.Rs. 40
Correct Answer: Rs. 29.75

In order to calculate interest on drawings, the amount of drawings will be multiplied by the number of months left after drawings are made.

 

The relevant amount = (200 × 9) + (200 × 8) + (300 × 7) + (50 × 5) + (100 × 2) = 5950

 

Interest on drawings = Amount × Rate of interest × Time = 5950 × 6100 × 112 = Rs. 29.75.

Question 9
On retirement/death of a partner, the retiring/deceased partner’s capital account will be credited with __________.
  • A.His/Hershare of goodwill.
  • B.Goodwill of the firm.
  • C.Shares of goodwill of remaining partners.
  • D.None of these
Correct Answer: His/Hershare of goodwill.

On retirement/death of a partner, the retiring/deceased partner’s capital account will be credited with his/her share of goodwill.

The retiring or deceased partner is entitled to his share of goodwill at the time of retirement or death because the goodwill earned by the firm is the result of the efforts of all the partners in the past.

Since in future, profits will arise because of the present goodwill. The retiring or the deceased partner will not be sharing future profits. Therefore, all continuing partners pay to retiring partner the share of Goodwill in gaining ratio. It is fair to compensate the retiring or deceased partner for the same. At the time of retirement or death of a partner, we value the goodwill based on agreement among the partners.

Question 10
Gobind,HariandPratapare partners. On retirement ofGobind, the goodwill already appears in the Balance Sheet atRs. 24,000. The goodwill will be written-off _______.
  • A.By debiting all partners’ capital accounts in their old profit-sharing ratio.
  • B.By debiting remaining partners’ capital accounts in their new profit-sharing ratio.
  • C.By debiting retiring partners’ capital accounts from his share of goodwill.
  • D.None of these
Correct Answer: By debiting all partners’ capital accounts in their old profit-sharing ratio.

In case of retirement, if goodwill already appears in the balance sheet, it must be written off immediately by debiting all partners’ capital accounts in their old profit-sharing ratio.

The reason behind this is goodwill is recorded in the books only when some consideration in money is paid for it. Therefore, any goodwill which is already appearing in the balance sheet is considered to be self-generated goodwill unless some consideration in money is paid for it. As per AS-26, self-generated goodwill cannot appear in the balance sheet. Thus, goodwill already appearing in the balance sheet must be written off immediately by debiting all partners’ capital accounts in their old profit-sharing ratio.

Question 11
Chaman, Raman andSumanare partners sharing profits in the ratio of 5:3:2. Raman retires, the new profit-sharing ratio betweenChamanandSumanwill be 1:1. The goodwill of the firm is valued atRs. 1,00,000 Raman’s share of goodwill will be adjusted
  • A.By debitingChaman’sCapital account andSuman’sCapital Account withRs15,000 each.
  • B.By debitingChaman’sCapital account andSuman’sCapital Account withRs. 21,429 and 8,571 respectively.
  • C.By debiting onlySuman’sCapital Account withRs. 30,000.
  • D.By debiting Raman’s Capital account withRs. 30,000
Correct Answer: By debiting onlySuman’sCapital Account withRs. 30,000.

Old profit sharing ratio of Chaman : Raman : Suman = 5:3:2

Now, Raman retires, and the New profit sharing ratio is Chaman : Suman = 1:1

Gaining ratio = New profit-sharing ratio – Old profit-sharing ratio

Chaman’s gain = 12 - 510 = 0

Suman’s gain = 12 - 210 = 310

Therefore, in this case, only Suman is gaining.

Thus, Raman’s share of goodwill, that is, 310 of Rs.1,00,000 = Rs. 30,000 will be adjusted by debiting only Suman’s Capital Account with Rs. 30,000. Only Suman must compensate for Raman’s goodwill in the profit-sharing ratio as Chaman’s gain is nil.

Question 12
In case of death of a partner, his share in the profits of the firm till the date of his death will be debited to ______ A/c.
  • A.Profit and Loss Appropriation
  • B.Profit and Loss Suspense
  • C.Profit and Loss Adjustment
  • D.Profit and Loss
Correct Answer: Profit and Loss Suspense

The death of a partner may occur at any time. In this case, the partner’s claim shall include his share of profit or loss, interest on capital, interest on drawings (if any) from the date of the last Balance Sheet to the date of his death. The main problem relates to the calculation of profit for the intervening period (i.e., the period from date of the last balance sheet and the date of the partner’s death). Since, it is considered cumbersome to close the books and prepare final account, for the period, the deceased partner’s share of profit may be calculated based on last year’s profit (or average of past few years) or based on sales. Therefore, when a partner dies his share in the profits of the firm till the date of his death will be debited to Profit and Loss Suspense account.

Question 13
At the time of valuation of goodwill, weighted average price method is followed, if the profits of the firm are __________.
  • A.In increasing trend
  • B.In decreasing trend
  • C.Either A or B
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Either A or B

Option C is correct. If there exists an increasing or decreasing trend in the profits of the firm, it is better to give a higher weightage to the profits of the recent years than those of the earlier years. This is called weighted average price method of valuation of goodwill.

Question 14
Profit of the year =Rs. 600000, Capital employed =Rs. 400000, Normal rate of return = 15%. Calculate the value of goodwill under capitalization method.
  • A.Rs. 4100000
  • B.Rs. 600000
  • C.Rs. 3600000
  • D.Rs. 2100000
Correct Answer: Rs. 3600000

Capitalised Value of Profits = Profit of the year × 100Normal rate of return

 

= 600000 × 10015

 

= 4000000

 

Goodwill = Capitalised Value of Profits – Net Assets

= 4000000 - 400000

= Rs. 3600000.

Question 15
On retirement/death of a partner, the remaining partner(s) who have gained due to change in profit sharing ratio should compensate the ________.
  • A.Retiring partners only.
  • B.Remaining partners (who have sacrificed) as well as retiring partners.
  • C.Remaining partners only (who have sacrificed).
  • D.None of these
Correct Answer: Remaining partners (who have sacrificed) as well as retiring partners.

The retiring or deceased partner is entitled to his share of goodwill at the time of retirement/death because the goodwill has been earned by the firm with the efforts of all the existing partners. The goodwill is valued as per agreement among the partners. The retiring/deceased partner is compensated for his share of goodwill by the continuing partners (who have gained due to acquisition of share of profit from the retiring/deceased partner) in their gaining ratio. However, if in case a continuing partner also sacrifices his share during the retirement of another partner, such continuing partner should be compensated by the other continuing partners for his sacrifice in the profit-sharing ratio.

Question 16
Under Garner & Murray Rule, the insolvency loss should be borne by solvent partners according to:
  • A.Maximum loss ratio
  • B.Capital ratio
  • C.Profit sharing ratio
  • D.Final claims ratio
Correct Answer: Capital ratio

Under Garner vs. Murray rule, the loss arising from insolvency of a partner can be described as follows:

When a partner is unable to pay his debt due to the firm, he is said to be insolvent and the share of loss is to be borne by other solvent partners in accordance with the decision in the English case of Garner vs. Murray.

According to this decision, solvent partners have to bear the loss due to insolvency of a partner and has categorically put that the normal loss on realization of assets to be borne by all partners (including insolvent partner) in the profit-sharing ratio but a loss due to insolvency of a partner has to be borne by the solvent partners in the capital ratio.

The provisions of the Indian Partnership Act are not contrary to Garner vs. Murray rule. However, if the partnership deed provides for a specific method to be followed in case of insolvency of a partner, the provisions as per deed should be applied.

 

The Capital Ratio on Insolvency can be described as under:

The partners are free to have either fixed or fluctuating capitals in the firm.

If they are maintaining capitals at fixed amounts, then all adjustments regarding their share of profits, interest on capitals, drawings, interest on drawings, salary etc. are done through Current Accounts, which may have debit or credit balances and insolvency loss is distributed in the ratio of fixed capitals.

But if capitals are not fixed and all transactions relating to drawings, profits, interest, etc., are passed through Capital Accounts then Balance Sheet of the business shall not exhibit Current Accounts of the partners and capital ratio will be determined after adjusting all the reserves and accumulated profits to the date of dissolution, all drawings to the date of dissolution, all interest on capitals and on drawings to the date of dissolution but before adjusting profit or loss on Realization Account.

If some partner is having a debit balance in his Capital Account and is not insolvent, then he cannot be called upon to bear loss on account of the insolvency of other partner.

Question 17
P & Q are partners in a firm sharing profits and losses in the ratio of5 :3. R is admitted as a new partner for 1/5th share. Then the sacrificing ratio will be ___________.
  • A.4 : 6
  • B.1 : 2
  • C.5 : 3
  • D.1 : 1
Correct Answer: 5 : 3

R is admitted as a new partner for 1/5th share.

Let total profit = 1

Therefore, share left for P and Q = 1 – 15 = 45

4/5th share in the firm will be divided in the old profit-sharing ratio i.e., 5:3

Therefore, new profit-sharing ratios

For P = 58 × 45 = 12

 

For Q = 38 × 45 = 310

 

Sacrificing ratio = Old profit-sharing ratio – New profit-sharing ratio

 

Calculation of sacrificing ratios

For P = 58 - 12 = 18 = 540

 

For Q = 38 - 310 = 340

 

Therefore, the sacrificing ratio = 5:3

Question 18
Maximum number of partners in a firm is mentioned in the __________.
  • A.Companies Act
  • B.Partnership Act
  • C.Income Tax Act
  • D.None of these
Correct Answer: Companies Act

Section 464 of Companies Act, 2013, restricts the maximum number of partners in a partnership firm to 100. Also, the Central Government framed Rule 10 of Companies (Miscellaneous) Rules, 2014 of the Indian Companies Act, 2013, and set the maximum limit of number of partners in a partnership firm to 50.

Question 19
Compulsory dissolution takes place when:
  • A.When there is loss in the current year
  • B.Death of a partner takes place
  • C.When all partners become insolvent
  • D.Retirement of an active partner
Correct Answer: When all partners become insolvent

Dissolution of a partnership firm may take place without the intervention of court or by the order of a court. It may be noted that dissolution of the firm necessarily brings in dissolution of the partnership.

 

Dissolution of a firm takes place in any of the following ways:

1. Dissolution by Agreement among partners through consent or agreement.

2. Compulsory Dissolution: A firm is dissolved compulsorily in the following cases:

(a) when all the partners or all but one partner, become insolvent, rendering them incompetent to sign a contract;

(b) when the business of the firm becomes illegal; or

(c) when some event has taken place which makes it unlawful for the partners to carry on the business.

3. On the happening of certain contingencies: Subject to contract between the partners, a firm is dissolved:

(a) if constituted for a fixed term, by the expiry of that term;

(b) if constituted to carry out one or more ventures, by the completion thereof;

(c) by the death of a partner;

(d) by the adjudication of a partner as an insolvent.

4. Dissolution by Notice: In case of partnership at will, the firm may be dissolved if any one of the partners gives a notice in writing to the other partners, signifying his intention of seeking dissolution of the firm.

5. Dissolution by Court: At the suit of a partner, the court may order a partnership firm to be dissolved on any of the following grounds:

(a) when a partner becomes insane;

(b) when a partner becomes permanently incapable of performing his duties

(c) when a partner is guilty of misconduct

(d) when a partner persistently commits breach of partnership agreement;

(e) when a partner has transferred the whole of his interest in the firm to a third party;

(f) when the business of the firm cannot be carried on except at a loss; or

(g) when, on any ground, the court regards dissolution to be just and equitable.

Question 20
Realization account is _________.
  • A.P/L adjustment account
  • B.Personal account
  • C.Real account
  • D.Nominal account
Correct Answer: Nominal account

Realization account is a Nominal account.

A nominal account records all expenses, incomes, and gives the net result in the form of losses or gains. In the realisation account we calculate profit or loss on sale of assets and payment of liabilities. So, here the output is either profit or loss. It means that it fulfills the requirement of nominal account. Hence it is a nominal account.

Question 21
Interest on partners’ capitals is allowed out of _________.
  • A.Profits
  • B.Capitals
  • C.Goodwill
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Profits

No interest is allowed on partners’ capitals unless it is expressly agreed among the partners. The Interest on capital is calculated with due allowance for any addition or withdrawal of capital during the accounting period. The Interest on partners’ capitals is allowed out of profits of the partnership firm.

Question 22
A, B, C & D are equal partners in a firm. They changed the profit-sharing ratio as 2: 2: 1: 1. The sacrificed share of ‘D’ is _________.
  • A.1/24
  • B.1/12
  • C.1/10
  • D.1/6
Correct Answer: 1/12

The old profit share of D, being an equal partner of a firm of 4 partners = 14

His new share = 16

Thus, sacrificed share of ‘D’ = 14 - 16 = 112

Question 23
A andB are partners in a firm in the profit-sharing ratio of 2:3. C is admitted as a new partner. A sacrificed 1/3rd of his share and B 1/4th of his share in favour of C. Find the new profit-sharing ratio of A, B & C.
  • A.17: 27: 37
  • B.16: 27 : 17
  • C.17 : 21 : 27
  • D.None of these
Correct Answer: 16: 27 : 17

New profit-sharing ratios:

 

A 25 – ( 13 ×  25 ) = 415 = 1660

 

B 35 - (14 × 35) = 920 = 2760

 

C (13  × 25 ) + (14 × 35) = 1760

 

Therefore, the new profit-sharing ratio of A, B & C = 16:27:17.

Question 24
A andB are partners in a firm with capitals ofRs. 500000 each. They admit C as a partner with 1/4th share in the profits of the firm. C brings in.Rs. 800000 as his share of capital. The Profit and Loss account showed a credit balance ofRs. 400000 as on the date of his admission. The value of hidden goodwill will be:
  • A.Rs. 1400000
  • B.Rs. 1800000
  • C.Rs. 1000000
  • D.None of these
Correct Answer: Rs. 1000000

C is admitted with 1/4th share in the profits of the firm.

Also, C brings Rs. 800000 as capital.

 

Therefore, the total capital of the newly constituted firm = 800000 × 4 = 3200000

 

But the actual capital works out to be (500000 + 500000 + 800000) = 1800000

 

Therefore, the value of hidden goodwill = 3200000 – 1800000 – 400000 (Profit and loss account credit balance) = 1000000.

Question 25
A, B and C are partners in a firm, sharing profits & losses in the ratio of 5:3:2 respectively. The balance of capital is Rs.50000 each for A & B and Rs.40000 for ‘C’. ‘B’ decides to retire from the firm. The goodwill of the firm is valued at Rs.30000 and profit on revaluation of assets and liabilities was Rs.5000. The firm also has a balance in the Reserve A/c at Rs.15000 on that date. What amount will be payable to ‘B’?
  • A.Rs.45000
  • B.Rs.55000
  • C.Rs.65000
  • D.Rs.75000
Correct Answer: Rs.65000

At the time of retirement of B,

Goodwill = 30000

Profit on revaluation of assets and liabilities = Rs.5000

Balance in the Reserve A/c = Rs.15000

Profit sharing ratio of A, B and C = 5:3:2

 

Therefore, share of B at the time of retirement = 310 × (30000 + 5000 + 15000) = 15000

 

Therefore, amount payable to B = 50000 (capital) + 15000 = 65000.

Question 26
A, B and C are partners in a firm sharing profits and losses in the ratio of 7: 5: 4. The profit of the firm for the year ended 31-03-16 wasRs. 240000. C died on 30-06-15. What is the share of ‘C’ in the profit?
  • A.Rs. 15000
  • B.Rs. 18000
  • C.Rs. 24000
  • D.Rs. 20000
Correct Answer: Rs. 15000

Profit of the firm for the year ended 31-03-16 = Rs. 240000.

Profit sharing ratio of A, B and C = 7: 5: 4.

 

C died on 30-06-15, therefore, he was there in the firm for 3 months.

 

Therefore, share of ‘C’ in the profit = 240000 × 416 × 312 = Rs.15000.

Question 27
Capital employed = Rs.600000, Average profit = Rs.105000, Normal rate of return = 15%. Value of goodwill under Capitalization method will beRs. ________.
  • A.100000
  • B.90000
  • C.110000
  • D.None
Correct Answer: 100000

Capitalised Value of Average Profits = Average Profits × 100Normal rate of return

 

 

= 105000 × 10015

 

= Rs. 700000

 

Goodwill = Capitalised Value of Average Profits – Capital Employed

= Rs. 700000 – Rs. 600000

= Rs. 100000.

Question 28
A partnership firm maintains its accounts on calendar year basis. B, one of the three partners died on 31/03/10. The profit of the firm for the year 2009 was Rs.75000, which was distributed among the partners equally. The share of B in the profits of the firm till the date of his death based on previous year’s profits will beRs. __________.
  • A.25000
  • B.6250
  • C.18750
  • D.37500
Correct Answer: 6250

Total profits of the firm = 75000

There is equal profit-sharing ratio.

B, one of the three partners died on 31/03/10. Therefore, he was alive for 3 months in the year 2010.

Therefore, share of B in the profits till the date of his death = 75000 × 13 × 312  = Rs. 6250.

Question 29
Interest on capital will be paid to the partners if provided for in the agreement but only from
  • A.Current year’s Profits.
  • B.Reserves
  • C.Accumulated Profits.
  • D.Goodwill.
Correct Answer: Current year’s Profits.

Option A is correct.

In case, there is no partnership deed in place, no Interest on Capital is to be allowed to any Partner, as per the Indian Partnership Act, 1932. The Interest on capital is calculated with due allowance for any addition or withdrawal of capital during the accounting period. Also, Interest on capital is to be paid to the partners only from current year’s Profits.

Question 30
P & Q are the partners in a firm sharing profits and losses in the ratio 3:2 with capitals of Rs.150000 and Rs.100000 respectively. They admitted R as a partner with Rs.90000 as capital for 1/4th share in the profits of the firm. They adjust the capitals of other partners according to R’s capital and his share in the business. How much cash will be brought in by P?
  • A.Rs.8000
  • B.Rs.9000
  • C.Rs.12000
  • D.Rs.10000
Correct Answer: Rs.12000

Old profit-sharing ratio of P and Q is 3:2.

 

R is admitted for 1/4th share in the profits.

 

Let total profit = 1

 

‘R’ is admitted with Share = 1/4

 

Remaining share = 1 – 14 = 34

 

P’s share = 35 × 34 = 920

 

Q’s share = 25 × 34 = 620

 

R’s share = 14 or 520

 

Thus, the new ratio among P, Q and R is. 9:6:5.

 

Now R contributes Rs. 90000 for 1/4th share in the firm.

 

Therefore, total capital of the firm should be = 90000 × 4 = 360000

 

The capital of P and Q according to new ratio shall be:

 

P = 360000 × 920 = 162000

 

Thus, P will bring in Rs. 162000 – Rs. 150000 = Rs. 12000

Question 31
Outgoing partner is compensated for parting with firm’s future profits in favour of remaining partners. In what ratio do the remaining partners contribute to such compensation amount?
  • A.Gaining Ratio
  • B.Capital Ratio.
  • C.Sacrificing Ratio
  • D.Profit Sharing Ratio
Correct Answer: Gaining Ratio

Option A is correct. The Outgoing partner is given some compensation for parting with firm’s future profits. Such compensation amount is contributed by the remaining partners in the gaining ratio.

Question 32
Tom & Jerry are partners in a firm sharing the profits and losses in the ratio of 3:2. Tom’s capital is Rs.70000 & Jerry’s capital is Rs.50000. They agreed to take Shiva as a new partner for 1/5th share in future profits. Calculate the amount of capital to be brought in by Shiva.
  • A.Rs.16000
  • B.Rs.18000
  • C.Rs.80000
  • D.Rs.30000
Correct Answer: Rs.30000

Total capital before admitting Shiva = 70000 + 50000 = 120000

 

Shiva has 1/5th share in future profits.

 

Therefore, Remaining share in profits for Tom & Jerry = 1 - 15 = 45

 

Let the total capital be P.

P × 45 = 120000

 

P = 150000

Therefore, the amount of capital to be brought in by Shiva = 150000 × 15 = Rs.30000.

Question 33
X, Y & Z are partners in a firm sharing profits and losses in the ratio of5 :4 : 3. Z died on 30/09/16. Profit for the year 2016 – 17 was Rs.40000. What is the share of Z in the profits of the firm till the date of his death?
  • A.Rs.6000
  • B.Rs.5000
  • C.Rs.4500
  • D.Nil
Correct Answer: Rs.5000

Profit sharing ratio of X, Y & Z is 5 : 4 : 3.

 

Total profit for 2016 – 17 is 40000.

 

Therefore, share of profit of Z = 40000 × 312 × 612 = Rs.5000

 

(612 is done because Z died on 30 September 2016).

Question 34
X & Y are partners in a firm sharing profits and losses in the ratio of 3: 2. Z was admitted as a new partner for 1/5thshare of the future profits. Z takes his entire share from X only. The new profit-sharing ratio of X, Y & Z will be
  • A.12 : 8 : 4
  • B.2 : 2 : 1
  • C.1 : 1 : 1
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: 2 : 2 : 1

Profit sharing ratio of X and Y = 3:2

 

Z was admitted for 1/5th share of the future profits.

 

Also, Z takes his entire share from X only.

 

Therefore, New profit-sharing ratios are:

 

X = 35 - 15 = 25

 

Y = 25

 

Z = 15

 

Therefore, the new profit sharing ratio of X, Y & Z = 2 : 2 : 1.

Question 35
In case of death of a partner, the amount of Joint Life Policy (JLP) received by the firm will be distributed _______.
  • A.To all the partners as per their old profit-sharing ratio
  • B.To the continuing partners as per their new profit-sharing ratio
  • C.To the continuing partners as per their old profit-sharing ratio
  • D.To the continuing partners as per their gaining ratio
Correct Answer: To all the partners as per their old profit-sharing ratio

The partners of a firm may decide to take a Joint Life Policy on the lives of all the partners of the firm. The partners take this policy with the aim to reduce the financial burden on the firm at the time of payment of a large sum to the retiring partner. At the time of death of a partner, the JLP received by the firm is to be distributed to all the partners as per their old profit-sharing ratio.

Question 36
Fluctuating Capital A/c is credited by____________.
  • A.Interest on Partner’s capital
  • B.Partner’s share in Profit of the year
  • C.Partner’s salary or remuneration
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: All of the above

There are 2 methods by which the capital accounts of partners can be maintained. These are:

(i) Fixed Capital Method, and

(ii) Fluctuating Capital Method.

Under the Fixed Capital Method, the capital of the partners will be fixed in the books of accounts. To maintain the fixed balance of capital, a separate account, i.e., partners current account is opened. Interest on capital, interest on drawings, salary, profit and loss etc. are shown in current account.

Under the Fluctuating Capital Method, only one account, i.e., capital account is maintained for each partner. All the adjustments such as share of profit and loss, interest on capital, drawings, interest on drawings, salary, or commission to partners, etc. are recorded directly in the capital accounts of the partners. This makes the balance in the capital account to fluctuate from time to time. That’s the reason why this method is called fluctuating capital method.

Question 37
Nivya,NityaandKavyaare partners in a firm sharing profits and losses in the ratio of 1:2:1.Nityaretired from the firm.NivyaandKavyadecided to share future profits and losses in the ratio of 3:1. They want to show the assets and liabilities in the new balance sheet at their old values. Then which account is to be prepared?
  • A.Revaluation A/c
  • B.Profit and Loss A/c
  • C.Memorandum Revaluation A/c
  • D.Profit and Loss Appropriation A/c
Correct Answer: Memorandum Revaluation A/c

Option C is correct. Memorandum Revaluation A/c is to be prepared when on retirement of a partner, the remaining partners want to show the assets and liabilities in the new balance sheet at their old values.

Question 38
On the death of partner, his executors are paid the share of deceased partner in the profit of the firm till the date of his death. This amount is recorded in profit and loss__________ A/c.
  • A.Adjustment
  • B.Appropriation
  • C.Suspense
  • D.Reserve
Correct Answer: Suspense

The Balance Sheet of a firm may show accumulated profits in the form of general reserve on reserve fund and/or accumulated losses in the form of profit and loss account debit balance. The deceased partner is entitled to his/her share in the accumulated profits and is also liable to share the accumulated losses, if any. These accumulated profits or losses belong to all the partners and should be transferred to the capital accounts of all partners in their old profit-sharing ratio. In case of death of a partner, his claim is transferred to his executors.

The death of a partner may occur at any time. In this case, the partner’s claim shall include his share of profit or loss, interest on capital, interest on drawings (if any) from the date of the last Balance Sheet to the date of his death. The main problem relates to the calculation of profit for the intervening period (i.e., the period from date of the last balance sheet and the date of the partner’s death). Since, it is considered cumbersome to close the books and prepare final account, for the period, the deceased partner’s share of profit may be calculated based on last year’s profit (or average of past few years) or on the basis of sales. Therefore, when a partner dies his share in the profits of the firm till the date of his death will be debited to Profit and Loss Suspense account.

Question 39
In the absence of agreement, the partners are entitled to ___________.
  • A.Interest on loan
  • B.Interest on capital
  • C.Salary
  • D.Commission
Correct Answer: Interest on loan

According to Indian Partnership Act, 1932, if there is no partnership deed in place, then interest on loan by a partner is allowed @ 6% per annum.

Question 40
Amit,RohitandSumitare partners sharing profits and losses in the ratio of 5:4:3.Sumitretires and if Amit andRohitshares profits ofSumitin 4:3, then new profit-sharing ratio will be _________.
  • A.4:3.
  • B.47:37.
  • C.5:4.
  • D.5:3
Correct Answer: 47:37.

Old profit-sharing ratio = 5:4:3

 

Share of Sumit = 312

 

New profit-sharing ratios are:

 

Amit 512 + (312 × 47) = 4784

 

 

Rohit 412 + (312 × 37) = 3784

 

Therefore, new profit sharing ratio = 4784 : 3784 = 47 : 37

Quiz Attempt #119244

Total Questions: 41
Question 1
A firm had an unrecorded investment of worth Rs.5000. Entry in the firm’s journal on admission of a partner will be?
  • A.Unrecorded Investment A/c Dr. 5000To Revaluation A/c 5000
  • B.Revaluation A/c Dr. 5000To unrecorded Investment 5000
  • C.Partner capital a/c Dr. 5000To unrecorded investment 5000
  • D.None of the three
Correct Answer: Unrecorded Investment A/c Dr. 5000To Revaluation A/c 5000

Option A is correct. The journal entry for an unrecorded investment is:

 

Unrecorded Investment A/c Dr. 5000

To Revaluation A/c 5000

Question 2
Gaining ratio may be applied when ______.
  • A.A partner is admitted
  • B.A partner retires
  • C.A business is sold out.
  • D.A partner is insolvent
Correct Answer: A partner retires

Option B is correct. The ratio in which the continuing partners acquire the share from the retiring/deceased partner is called the gaining ratio.

Gaining ratio = New share of profit – Old share of profit

 

Sacrificing ratio is calculated in case of admission of a partner. The ratio in which the old partners agree to sacrifice their share of profit in favour of the incoming partner is called sacrificing ratio. The sacrifice by a partner is equal to:

Old Share of Profit – New Share of Profit

Question 3
Interest on capital at 6% p.a. is to be allowed. Capital in the beginning wasRs. 300000. Interest amount will be ___________.
  • A.Rs.18000
  • B.Rs.15000
  • C.Rs.16000
  • D.None of the three
Correct Answer: Rs.18000

Interest amount = Opening Capital × Interest rate

 

= 300000 × 6100 = Rs.18000.

Question 4
Rishi is a partner in a firm. He withdrew the following amounts during the year ended on31st December 2006.February 1Rs. 12000April 30Rs. 6000June 30Rs. 9000August 31Rs. 12000October 1Rs. 8000December 31Rs. 7000Interest on drawings @ 9% p.a. will be?
  • A.Rs.2295
  • B.Rs.2000
  • C.Rs.2200
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Rs.2295

In order to calculate interest on drawings, the amount of drawings will be multiplied by the time left after drawings.

 

The relevant amount = (12000 × 11) + (6000 × 8) + (9000 × 6) + (12000 × 4) + (8000 × 3) + (7000 × 0) = 306000

 

Interest on drawings = Amount × Rate of interest × Time = 306000 × 9100 × 112 = Rs. 2295.

Question 5
The profits for the last four years are given as follows:YearRs.2000 400002001 500002002 600002003 50000The value of goodwill based on 3 years purchase of average profits based on the last four years will be?
  • A.Rs.100000
  • B.Rs.150000
  • C.Rs.200000
  • D.None of the three
Correct Answer: Rs.150000

Average profit = 40000+50000+60000+500004 = 50000

 

Goodwill = Average profit × Number of years of purchase

= 50000 × 3 = Rs.150000.

Question 6
Goods purchased on credit during last year worthRs. 60000 were not recorded in the books of a partnership firm namely ABC and Co. whose profit is shared equally by A, B & C, but the said amount was included in last year’s closing stock figure. Adjusting entry will be?
  • A.S. Creditors A/c Dr. 60000To A 60000
  • B.Sundry Creditors A/c Dr. 60000To A 30000To B 30000
  • C.A's Capital Dr. 20000B's Capital Dr. 20000C's Capital Dr. 20000To Sundry Creditors 60000
  • D.None of the three
Correct Answer: A's Capital Dr. 20000B's Capital Dr. 20000C's Capital Dr. 20000To Sundry Creditors 60000

Option C is correct. Since the goods are purchased on credit and were not recorded in books, therefore, creditors account should be credited. Also, the capital accounts of A, B and C should be debited with Rs. 20000 each (since profits are shared equally). Adjusting entry is:

 

A's Capital Dr. 20,000

B's Capital Dr. 20,000

C's Capital Dr. 20,000

To Sundry Creditors 60,000

Question 7
J andR areequal partners. U is admitted as a partner for ¼ share of profits but is unable to contribute premium for goodwill in cash amounting toRs. 8000 and so it decided to raise a loan A/c in the name of U. Journal entry will be?
  • A.U's loan A/c Dr. 8000To J 8000
  • B.U’s loan A/c Dr. 8000To R 4000
  • C.U’s Loan A/c Dr. 8000To J 4000To R 4000
  • D.None of the three
Correct Answer: U’s Loan A/c Dr. 8000To J 4000To R 4000

Option C is correct. The journal entry for the loan account raised in the name of U is:

 

U’s Loan A/c Dr. 8000

To J 4000

To R 4000

Question 8
Find the goodwill of the firm using capitalization method from the following information:Total capital employed in the firmRs. 8000000Reasonable rate of return 15%Profits for the yearRs. 1200000
  • A.Rs. 6800000
  • B.Rs. 1200000
  • C.Rs. 1188000
  • D.Nil
Correct Answer: Nil

Capitalized Value of Profits = Profit of the year × 100Normal rate of return

 

= 1200000 × 10015

 

= 8000000

 

Goodwill = Capitalized Value of Profits – Net Assets

= 8000000 - 8000000

= NIL

Question 9
If the incoming partner brings any additional amount in cash other than his capital contributions, then it is termed as ______________.
  • A.Capital
  • B.Reserves
  • C.Goodwill
  • D.Premium for goodwill
Correct Answer: Premium for goodwill

Option D is correct. If an incoming partner brings any additional amount in cash other than his capital contributions, then it is referred to as Premium for goodwill. When the new or incoming partner brings cash for his share of goodwill, it is transferred to the Capital Accounts of the sacrificing partners. In other words, the amount of goodwill brought in by the new partner is shared by the sacrificing partners in their sacrificing ratio.

The Journal Entries to be passed in this case are discussed below.

1. When the new partner brings his amount of Premium for Goodwill in cash

Cash/Bank Account …Dr.

To Premium for Goodwill Account

2. To distribute the premium for goodwill among the old partners in sacrificing ratio

Premium for Goodwill Account …Dr.

To Sacrificing Partners’ Capital Account

(Individually in sacrificing ratio)

Question 10
Profit and loss of realization account is shared among the partners in _______ ratio.
  • A.Old profit-sharing ratio
  • B.New profit-sharing ratio
  • C.Capital ratio
  • D.Equal ratio
Correct Answer: Old profit-sharing ratio

When the firm is dissolved, its books of account are to be closed and the profit or loss arising on realization of its assets and discharge of liabilities is to be computed. For this purpose, a Realization Account is prepared to ascertain the net effect (profit or loss) of realization of assets and payment of liabilities which is transferred to partner’s capital accounts in their old profit-sharing ratio. Realization Account is a Nominal Account.

Hence, all assets (other than cash in hand, bank balance and fictitious assets, if any), and all external liabilities are transferred to this account. It also records the sale of assets, and payment of liabilities and realization expenses. The Pro-forma of Realization Account is provided below:

 

Particulars

Amount in Rs.

Particulars

Amount in Rs.

To Assets:

Land and Building

Plant and Machinery

Furniture and Fittings

Bills Receivables

Sundry Debtors

 

To Cash/Bank A/c (Payment of Liabilities)

 

To Cash/Bank A/c (Payment of Unrecorded Liabilities)

 

To Partner’s Capital A/c (Liability taken over by partner)

 

To Partner’s Capital A/c (Profit on Realisation transferred to Partners’ Capital Account in their Profit-Sharing Ratio)

Sundry Creditors

Bills Payable

Bank Overdraft

Outstanding Expenses

Provision for Doubtful Debts

 

By Cash/Bank A/c (Sale of Assets)

 

By Partner’s Capital A/c (Assets taken over by the Partner)

 

By Partner’s Capital A/c (Loss on Realisation transferred to Partners’ Capital Account in their Profit-Sharing Ratio)

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Question 11
Interest on Partner’s capital is _________?
  • A.An expenditure
  • B.An appropriation
  • C.A gain
  • D.None of the three
Correct Answer: An appropriation

Interest on Partner’s capital is an appropriation. In case of partnership, certain adjustments such as interest on drawings, interest on capital, salary to partners, and commission to partners are required to be made. For this purpose, it is customary to prepare a Profit and Loss Appropriation Account of the firm and ascertain the final figure of profit and loss to be distributed among the partners, in their profit-sharing ratio.

Question 12
Goodwill is to be calculated at one year’s purchase of the average of the last 3 years profit. The profit of the first year wasRs. 6000, second year twice the profit of the first year and the third year one and half times of the profit of the second-year goodwill amount will be?
  • A.Rs.10000
  • B.Rs.12000
  • C.Rs.11000
  • D.Rs.13000
Correct Answer: Rs.12000

Profit in the first year = 6000

 

Profit in the second year = 6000 × 2 = 12000

 

Profit in the third year = 12000 × 1.5 = 18000

 

Average profit = 6000+12000+180003 = 12000

 

Goodwill = Average profit × Number of years of purchase

= 12000 × 1 = Rs.12000

Question 13
A, B and C are partners in the firm sharing profits and losses in 5:3:2 ratio. The firm's balance sheet as on 31.03.2006 shows the reserve balance ofRs. 25000, profit of the last yearRs. 50000, Joint life policy ofRs. 1000000 and fixed assets ofRs. 1200000. On 1st June, C died and on the same date assets were revalued. The executor of the deceased partner will get along with the capital of C?
  • A.Share in the reserve account of the firm
  • B.Proportionate share of profituptothe date of death
  • C.Share in joint life policy
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: All of the above

Option D is correct. The sum due to the legal representatives/executors, in case of death of a partner includes:

1. credit balance of his capital account;

2. credit balance of his current account (if any);

3. his share of goodwill;

4. his share of accumulated profits (reserves);

5. his share in the gain of revaluation of assets and liabilities;

6. his share of profits up to the date of retirement/death;

7. interest on his capital, if involved, up to the date of retirement/death; and

8. salary/commission, if any, due to him up to the date of retirement/death.

 

In case of revaluation of assets of Rs.1200000, a Revaluation Account is prepared in order to ascertain net gain (loss) on revaluation of assets and/or liabilities and bringing unrecorded items into firm’s books and the same is transferred to the capital account of all partners including deceased partners in their old profit-sharing ratio i.e., 5:3:2.

 

The Balance Sheet of a firm may show accumulated profits in the form of general reserve or reserve fund and/or accumulated losses in the form of profit and loss account debit balance. The deceased partner is entitled to his/her share in the accumulated profits and is also liable to share the accumulated losses, if any. These accumulated profits or losses belong to all the partners and should be transferred to the capital accounts of all partners in their old profit-sharing ratio. Therefore, reserve balance of Rs. 25,000 and profit of the last year Rs. 50,000 will be transferred to the capital accounts of all partners in their old profit-sharing ratio i.e., 5:3:2.

 

The partners of a firm may decide to take a Joint Life Policy on the lives of all the partners of the firm. At the time of death of a partner, the JLP received by the firm is to be distributed to all the partners as per their old profit-sharing ratio.

Question 14
General reserve at the time of retirement of a partner is transferred to_______.
  • A.Revaluation A/c
  • B.Memorandum Revaluation A/c
  • C.Partners’ capital accounts
  • D.Profit & Loss Adjustment account
Correct Answer: Partners’ capital accounts

The Balance Sheet of a firm may show accumulated profits in the form of general reserve or reserve fund and/or accumulated losses in the form of profit and loss account debit balance. The retiring partner is entitled to his/her share in the accumulated profits and is also liable to share the accumulated losses, if any. These accumulated profits or losses belong to all the partners and should be transferred to the capital accounts of all partners in their old profit-sharing ratio.

Question 15
Which of the following statements about partnership financial statements istrue?
  • A.Details of the distribution of net income are shown in the owners’ equity statement.
  • B.The distribution of net income is shown on the balance sheet.
  • C.Only the total of all partner capital balances is shown in the balance sheet.
  • D.The owners’ equity statement is called the partners’ capital statement.
Correct Answer: The owners’ equity statement is called the partners’ capital statement.

The owners’ equity statement for a partnership is called the partners’ capital statement. The other options are incorrect.

 

Option A is incorrect. The total amount, not the details, of the distribution of net income is shown in the partners’ capital statement.

Option B is incorrect. The distribution of net income is not shown on the balance sheet but on the partners’ capital statement.

Option C is incorrect. Each individual partner’s capital balance is shown in the balance sheet.

Question 16
In the absence of any provision in the partnership agreement, profits and losses are shared:
  • A.In the ratio of capitals
  • B.Equally
  • C.In the ratio of capital invested by partners to the firm
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Equally

According to Indian Partnership Act, 1932, if there is no partnership deed in place, then profits and losses are shared equally among the partners.

Question 17
A andB are partners, sharing profits in the ratio of 5:3. They admit C with 1/5 share in profits, which he acquires equally from both 1/10 from A and 1/10 from B. New profit-sharing ratio will be
  • A.21:11:8
  • B.20:10:4
  • C.15:10:5
  • D.None of the three
Correct Answer: 21:11:8

New profit-sharing ratio:

 

A 58 – 110 = 4280

 

B 38 - 110 = 2280

 

C 15 or 1680

 

Therefore, the new profit-sharing ratio of A, B & C = 42:22:16 = 21:11:8.

Question 18
Ramesh & Suresh are partners sharing profits in the ratio of 2:1 (Ramesh Capital is Rs.102000 and Suresh Capital isRs. 73000) They admitted Mahesh & agreed to give him 1/5 in share. He bringsRs. 14000 as his share of goodwill. He agreed to contribute capital in profit sharing ratio. How much capital will be brought by incoming partner?
  • A.Rs. 43750
  • B.Rs. 45000
  • C.Rs. 47000
  • D.Rs. 48000
Correct Answer: Rs. 43750

Mahesh’s capital = (Ramesh’s capital + Suresh’s capital) × Reciprocal of their remaining share × Profit share of Mahesh

 

Total of capitals of Ramesh and Suresh = 102000 + 73000 = 175000

 

Now, Let the total profit be 1

 

Mahesh is admitted with Share = 1/5

 

Remaining share = 1 – 15 = 45

 

Reciprocal of remaining share = 54

 

Mahesh’s share = 15

 

Therefore, Mahesh’s capital = 175000 × 54  × 15 = 43750

Question 19
A & B are equal partners with capitals of theRs. 10000 andRs. 8000 respectively. They admit C as a partner with 1/4th share in the profits of the firm. C bringsRs. 8000 as his share of capital. Value of goodwill will be _______?
  • A.Rs. 6000
  • B.Rs. 5000
  • C.Rs. 8000
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Rs. 6000

C is admitted with 1/4th share in the profits of the firm.

Capital brought in by C = 8000

Therefore, the total capital of the newly constituted firm = 8000 × 4 = 32000
