But the actual capital works out to be (10000 + 8000 + 8000) = 26000

 

Therefore, the value of goodwill = 32000 – 26000 = Rs.6000.

Question 20
AkashandVikasare partners in a firm with capitals of Rs.60000 each.Srikanthis admitted as a new partner for 1/5th share, who brings in Rs.80000 as capital. Find the value of inferred goodwill.
  • A.Rs.200000
  • B.Rs.220000
  • C.Rs.400000
  • D.Rs.300000
Correct Answer: Rs.200000

Srikanth is admitted with 1/5th share in the profits of the firm.

Also, Srikanth brings Rs. 80000 as capital.

 

Therefore, the total capital of the newly constituted firm = 80000 × 5 = 400000

 

But the actual capital works out to be (60000 + 60000 + 80000) = 200000

 

Therefore, the value of hidden goodwill = 400000 - 200000 = 200000.

Question 21
Consider the following parties: (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2012)(i) Secured creditors(ii) Unsecured creditors(iii) Partners who have granted loans(iv) Partners who have contributed over and above profit sharing ratioArrange them in correct sequence in the event of the dissolution of a firm.
  • A.(ii), (i), (iii), (iv)
  • B.(i), (ii), (iii), (iv)
  • C.(i), (ii), (iv), (iii)
  • D.(ii), (i), (iv), (iii)
Correct Answer: (i), (ii), (iii), (iv)

Settlement of Accounts in partnership firm: As soon as a firm is dissolved, it ceases to transact normal business. The mode of settlement of accounts between partners after the dissolution of a firm is determined by the partnership agreement. In the absence of any specific agreement as to the mode of settlement of accounts after the dissolution of the firm, the Partnership Act laid down the following provisions for settlement of accounts.

a) Expenses of dissolution

b) The assets of the firm including any sums contributed by the partners to make up deficiencies of capital shall be applied in the following manner and order:

- Secured Creditors.

- Unsecured Creditors.

- In paying to each partner rateably what is due to him on account of capital, and

- The surplus, if any, will be divided among the partners in their profit sharing ratio.

Question 22
X and Y are partners in a firm sharing profits in the ratios of 2:1. Z is admitted with a13profit sharing. What will be the new profit-sharing ratio of X, Y and Z? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2012)
  • A.3: 3: 3
  • B.4: 3: 2
  • C.4: 2: 3
  • D.2: 3: 4
Correct Answer: 4: 2: 3

At the time of admission of the new partner into the firm there is a need to calculate the new profit-sharing ratio of the firm.

Let total profit = 1

‘Z’ is admitted with Share = 13

Remaining share = 1 – 13= 23

X’s share = 23of 23= 49

Y’s share = 13of 23= 29

Z’s share = 13 = 39

Thus, the new ratio among X, Y and Z is. 4:2:3.

Question 23
When a partnership is dissolved and the following claims need to be met out piece-meal of the cash released, which is the correct sequence in which these claims have to be met? (UGC NET Commerce Sep 2013)(a) Any partner’s loan(b) Capital and Current account balances(c) Expenses of dissolution(d) Outsider’s claim (both payable and accrued)Codes:
  • A.(c), (d), (a), (b)
  • B.(b), (c), (a), (d)
  • C.(a), (b), (d), (c)
  • D.(a), (b), (c), (d)
Correct Answer: (c), (d), (a), (b)

Settlement of Accounts in partnership firm:

As soon as a firm is dissolved, it ceases to transact normal business. The mode of settlement of accounts between partners after the dissolution of a firm is determined by the partnership agreement. In the absence of any specific agreement as to the mode of settlement of accounts after the dissolution of the firm, the Partnership Act laid down the following provisions for settlement of accounts.

a) Expenses of dissolution

b) The assets of the firm including any sums contributed by the partners to make up deficiencies of capital shall be applied in the following manner and order:

-Secured Creditors: Outsider’s claim (both payable and accrued).

- Unsecured Creditors.

- In paying to each partner rateably what is due to him on account of capital: Any partner’s loan.

- The surplus, if any, will be divided among the partners in their profit sharing ratio: Capital and Current account balances.

Question 24
X, Y,Zare sharing profits in the ratio of 6:5:3. A is admitted into partnership for18thshare. The sacrificing ratio of X, Y and Z is (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2014)
  • A.Equal
  • B.6: 5: 3
  • C.514,414,514
  • D.4: 5: 5
Correct Answer: 6: 5: 3

At the time of admission of the new partner into the firm there is a need to calculate the new profit-sharing ratio of the firm.

Let total profits = 1

Z is admitted with Share = 18

Remaining share = 1 – 18= 78

X’s share = 614 of 78= 616

Y’s share = 514 of 78= 516

Z’s share = 314 of 78= 316

A’s share = 18 = 216

Thus, the new ratio among X, Y, Z and A is. 6:5:3:2.

Sacrificing Ratio = Old Ratio – New Ratio

X’s share = 614- 616 = 6112

Y’s share = 514- 516 = 5112

Z’s share = 314 - 316 = 3112

Sacrificing Ratio among X, Y and Z is. 6:5:3.

Question 25
A retiring partner continues to be liable for obligations incurred after his retirement: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2015)
  • A.If unpaid amount is transferred to his loan account.
  • B.Ifhe does not give public notice.
  • C.If he starts a similar business elsewhere.
  • D.In all the situations till he survives.
Correct Answer: Ifhe does not give public notice.

A retiring partner is one, who doesn’t want to continue with the partnership firm and withdraws his association.

A retiring or outgoing partner continues to be liable for obligations incurred before his retirement and will continue to be liable even for future obligations, if he does not give public notice of his retirement.

Question 26
A andB are partners in a firm who share profits and losses equally. They admitted C on the following terms: (UGC NET Commerce Aug 2016)C should bring Rs.12,000as capital and Rs.8,000 as goodwill. New profit-sharing ratio of A, B and C will be 2: 1: 2, respectively. A and B will share the goodwill in which of the following ratios?
  • A.3: 4
  • B.2: 3
  • C.2: 1
  • D.1: 3
Correct Answer: 1: 3

Goodwill brought in by new partner “C” will be shared by the old partners in the ratio of sacrifice made by the existing partners.

Sacrificing Ratio = Old Ratio – New Ratio

X’s share = 12- 25 = 110

Y’s share = 12- 15 = 310

Sacrificing Ratio among A and B is 1:3.

Question 27
X, Y and Z are partners in a firm sharing profits and losses equally. They decided to share profits in ratio of 2:1:2 respectively. The gaining ratio of X and Z will be: (UGC NET Commerce Aug 2016)
  • A.1:2
  • B.2:1
  • C.1:1
  • D.3:2
Correct Answer: 1:1

Gaining Ratio = New Ratio - Old Ratio

X’s share = 25 - 13 = 115

Y’s share = 15 - 13 = -215 (A sacrificing)

Z’s share = 25 - 13 = 115

Sacrificing Ratio among X and Z is 1:1.

Question 28
Amount due to outgoing partner is shown in the balance sheet as his ________. (UGC NET Commerce Jan 2017)
  • A.Liability
  • B.Asset
  • C.Capital
  • D.Loan
Correct Answer: Loan

When a partner is retiring, then any withdrawals and interest due should be deducted from the amount payable to the outgoing partner. The firm is obliged to make payment to the retiring partners of the firm due to him at the time of retirement. The total amount so calculated will be transferred to retiring partner’s loan account by debiting the retiring partner’s capital account.

Question 29
What is the minimum number of partners required to commence a partnership business?
  • A.10
  • B.20
  • C.2
  • D.4
Correct Answer: 2

Two or more Persons: There must be at least two partners in a partnership firm. Maximum number of partners in banking business is 10 and in other are 20.

Question 30
The written agreement of a partnership is most commonly referred to as:
  • A.Partnership deed
  • B.Partnership contract
  • C.Agreement
  • D.Partnership act
Correct Answer: Partnership deed

Though the law does not expressly require that the partnership agreement should be in writing, it is desirable to have it in writing in order to avoid any dispute with regard to the terms of the partnership. The written document which contains the term of a partnership as agreed among the partners is called ‘partnership deed’. The deed is required to be duly stamped as per the Indian Stamp Act, 1889 and duly signed by all the partners. The partnership deed contains various provisions relating to various matters such as:

Name of the firm, Address and its main business.

Names and addresses of all partners.

Nature and place of business.

Date of commencement of partnership.

Duration of partnership.

Amount of capital of each partner.

Profit sharing ratio.

Interest on capital.

Interest on drawings.

Interest on loan advanced by a partner to the firm.

Salary or commission payable to any partner.

Method of valuation of goodwill and other assets and liabilities in case of admission or retirement or death of a partner.

Settlement of accounts in case of retirement/death of a partner and dissolution of firm.

The clauses of partnership deed can be altered with the consent of all the partners.

Question 31
When no partnership deed exists among the partners, what will be the profit sharing between the partners?
  • A.Unequal
  • B.It will depend on a partner’s capital
  • C.Equal
  • D.It will depend upon experience of a partner
Correct Answer: Equal

In case, there is no partnership deed among the partners, the profit-sharing ratio should be equal between the partners, irrespective of their capital contribution as per the provisions of Indian Partnership Act, 1932.

Question 32
Under fluctuating capital method, what is the treatment of ‘interest on capital’?
  • A.Credited to capital account
  • B.Debited to capital account
  • C.Credited to current account
  • D.No treatment or adjustment needed
Correct Answer: Credited to capital account

Under fluctuating capital method, all the adjustments regarding drawings, interest on drawings, salary, commission, interest on capital etc are made in capital account itself. Interest on capital is to be given by the partnership firm to the respective partners, and thus it should be credited to partner’s capital account, which will increase firm’s liability towards the partner.

Question 33
Which one of the following is NOT generally a characteristic/feature of a partnership firm?
  • A.Sharing of profits
  • B.Two or more persons
  • C.Mutual agency
  • D.Limited liability
Correct Answer: Limited liability

The following are the essential elements/characteristics of a partnership firm:

Two or more Persons: There must be at least two partners in a partnership firm.

Agreement: Partnership is an agreement between partners. The agreement may be written, or it may be verbal also.

Business: Partnership is formed for doing business that is legal.

Sharing of Profits: Profit and loss of the partnership firm will be divided in the partners in their profit-sharing ratio.

Mutual Agency: The business of the partnership firm may be carried by all the partners or any of them acting for all. This statement has two important implications. First, every partner is entitled to participate in the conduct of the affairs of its business. Second, that there exists a relationship of mutual agency between all the partners. Each partner carrying on the business is the principal as well as the agent for all the other partners.

Liability of Partnership: Each partner is liable jointly with all the other partners and also severally to the third party for all the acts of the firm done while he is a partner. Not only that, the liability of a partner for acts of the firm is also unlimited. This implies that his private assets can be used to pay off firm’s debts.

Question 34
An incoming partner pays his share of goodwill in cash, and profit-sharing ratio of old partners is changed, then the goodwill paid in cash by the incoming partner will be distributed among old partners:
  • A.In their old profit-sharing ratio
  • B.In sacrificing ratio
  • C.In their new profit-sharing ratio
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: In sacrificing ratio

The incoming partner who acquires his share in the profits of the firm from the existing partners brings in some additional amount to compensate them for loss of their share in super profits. It is termed as his share of goodwill (also called premium). This share of goodwill brought in by the incoming partner is to be distributed among the old partners to the extent to which the old partners lose their share in super profits, that is, in sacrificing ratio.

Question 35
In the absence of an agreement, Interest on loan advanced by the partner to the firm is allowed at the rate of:
  • A.6% p.a.
  • B.5% p.a.
  • C.12% p.a.
  • D.24% p.a.
Correct Answer: 6% p.a.

As per the provisions of Indian Partnership Act, 1932, if no partnership deed is in place, interest on loan provided by the partner to the firm is allowed @6% p.a.

Question 36
A new partner may be admitted to a partnership with:
  • A.With the consent of all the partners
  • B.With the consent of two-third of old partners
  • C.With the consent of only one partner
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: With the consent of all the partners

According to the Partnership Act 1932, a new partner can be admitted into the firm only with the consent of all the existing partners unless otherwise agreed upon. With the admission of a new partner, the partnership firm is reconstituted, and a new agreement is entered into, to carry on the business of the firm.

Question 37
The loss or gain an account of revaluation at the time of retirement of a partner is shared by:
  • A.Remaining partners
  • B.Retiring partner
  • C.All partners
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: All partners

Revaluation and Adjustment of assets and liabilities: A revaluation Account is prepared in order to ascertain net gain (loss) on revaluation of assets and/or liabilities and bringing unrecorded items into firm’s books and the net gain or loss is transferred to the capital account of all partners including retiring/deceased partners in their old profit-sharing ratio.

Question 38
Which of the following is not a characteristic of a partnership?
  • A.Taxable entity
  • B.Co-ownership of property
  • C.Mutual agency
  • D.Limited life
Correct Answer: Taxable entity

A partnership is not a taxable entity. Rather, the partnership income is taxed on the individual tax returns of the partners. The other options are characteristics of a partnership.

Question 39
The advantages of a partnership donotinclude:
  • A.ease of formation
  • B.unlimited liability
  • C.freedom from government regulation
  • D.ease of decision-making
Correct Answer: unlimited liability

Unlimited liability is a disadvantage of a partnership. The other options are advantages of a partnership.

Question 40
The NBC Company reports net income ofRs. 60,000. If partners N, B, and C have an income ratio of 50%, 30%, and 20%, respectively, C’s share of the net income is:
  • A.Rs. 30,000
  • B.Rs. 12,000
  • C.Rs. 18,000
  • D.No correct answer is given
Correct Answer: Rs. 12,000

Income will be distributed in the ratio of 5:3:2.

 

Therefore, C’s share of net income = 210 × 60,000 = Rs. 12,000

Question 41
To close a partner’s drawings account, an entry must be made that:
  • A.debits partner’s drawings account and credits the Income Summary
  • B.debits partner’s drawings account and credits the partner’s capital account
  • C.credits partner’s drawings account and debits the partner’s capital account
  • D.credits partner’s drawings account and debits the firm’s dividend account
Correct Answer: credits partner’s drawings account and debits the partner’s capital account

To close a partner’s drawings account, an entry must be made that credits the partner’s drawings account and debits the partner’s capital account.

Quiz Attempt #119245

Total Questions: 39
Question 1
In a situation where the holding and subsidiary companies own share in each other is knownas-(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2023)
  • A.Partly owned subsidiary
  • B.Cross holding
  • C.Subsidiary company
  • D.Wholly owned subsidiary
Correct Answer: Cross holding

In a cross holding situation, two companies own shares in each other. This creates a complex ownership structure where each company has a stake in the other. It can lead to interconnectedness between the two companies, influencing decision-making, governance, and strategic direction.

Question 2
Luxmi industries issued 1000 shares of Rs. 100 at a premium of Rs 10 per share, payable Rs 20 on application, Rs. 35 on allotment (including premium) and the balance on the first and final call. Mr. X who held 200 shares has paid only the application money and these shares were subsequently forfeited by the company. In this regard, by which amount share forfeiture account will be credited?(UGC NET Commerce Dec 2023)
  • A.Rs. 4000
  • B.Rs. 2000
  • C.Rs. 3000
  • D.Rs. 200
Correct Answer: Rs. 4000

In case shares are issued at premium and thereafter forfeited there can be two situations:

 

1. Premium on shares has been received prior to the forfeiture.

In this case, if the amount of premium on shares forfeited has been received by the company prior to the forfeiture, securities Premium A/c will not get affected. In this case the journal entry of forfeiture of shares will be similar to the entry made as if the shares had been issued at par.

 

The journal entry under Case 1 will be:

Share Capital A/c …Dr

To Share forfeited A/c

To Unpaid Calls A/c./Calls in arrears A/c

(forfeiture of share issued at premium)

 

2. Amount of premium on shares has not been received and it still stands credited to the Securities Premium A/c.

When a share is forfeited on which the amount of premium has been made due but has not been received, either wholly or partially, the Securities Premium A/c will be cancelled. At the time of making due, Securities Premium A/c will be credited.

 

The journal entry will be as follows:

 

Share Capital A/c Dr

Securities Premium A/c Dr

To Share Forfeited A/c

To Unpaid call A/c

(Being forfeiture of shares originally issued at premium due to non-payment of dues).

 

Since, in the given case, shares have been forfeited before the payment of premium, case 2 applies here.

 

The journal entry will be as follows.

 

Share Capital A/c Dr (200 × 100) DrRs. 20,000

Securities Premium A/c (200 × 10) Dr Rs. 2,000

To Share Forfeited A/c (200 × 20)Rs. 4,000

To Share Allotment A/c (200 × 35)Rs. 7,000

To Unpaid Call A/c (200 × 55)Rs. 11,000

(Being forfeiture of shares originally issued at premium due to non-payment of dues).

 

Therefore, the correct answer is option A.

Question 3
A company forfeits 100 shares of Rs. 10 each on which Rs. 300 had been received. 60 shares are reissued at Rs. 9 per share. Which one of the followingamountis to be transferred to Capital Reserve Account?(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2024)
  • A.Rs. 200
  • B.Rs. 180
  • C.Rs. 120
  • D.Rs. 60
Correct Answer: Rs. 120

Since the company has forfeited Rs. 3 per share (300 ÷ 100), the amount forfeited on re-issued shares is (60 × Rs. 3) = Rs. 180, the amount with which the share forfeiture account will be credited.

 

Also, the company re-issues these forfeited shares at Re. 1 (10 – 1) discount each, thus the share forfeiture account will be debited with Rs. 60 (60 × Rs. 1).

 

The total amount of share forfeiture account to be transferred to Capital Reserve account will be Rs. 180 – Rs. 60 = Rs. 120.

Question 4
Which of the following are true in case of Internal Reconstruction?(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2024)A. The existing company is liquidatedB. No new company is formedC. There is certain reduction of capital and sometime liabilities are also reducedD. The new company issues fresh capitalE. It is done as per section 66 of the Companies Act, 2013Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, D & E only
  • B.A, C & E only
  • C.B, C & E only
  • D.B, C & D only
Correct Answer: B, C & E only

To determine which statements are true regarding Internal Reconstruction, let's analyze each statement based on the principles of corporate restructuring under the Companies Act:

 

A. The existing company is liquidated: This is false for internal reconstruction. Internal reconstruction does not involve liquidation; instead, it refers to restructuring the company's finances without dissolving the existing entity.

 

B. No new company is formed: This is true. In internal reconstruction, the existing company continues to exist, and no new company is created.

 

C. There is certain reduction of capital and sometimes liabilities are also reduced: This is true. Internal reconstruction often involves reducing the company’s capital and may also involve negotiating with creditors to reduce liabilities.

 

D. The new company issues fresh capital: This is false. In internal reconstruction, the existing company does not issue new shares. Instead, it may involve restructuring the existing capital structure.

 

E. It is done as per section 66 of the Companies Act, 2013: This is true. Section 66 of the Companies Act, 2013, provides the legal framework for the reduction of share capital, which is a key component of internal reconstruction.

 

Based on this analysis, the true statements regarding internal reconstruction are option (C) i.e., B, C, and E.

Question 5
The liquidator after realizing the assets of the company should distribute the proceeds among below mentioned claimants in the following order: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2021)1. Legal charges2. Liquidators remuneration and cost of expenses of winding up3. Workman’s dues and claims of the secured creditors4. Preferential creditor and creditors secured by floating charge5. Unsecured creditorsChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.2, 3, 1, 4, 5
  • B.4, 3, 2, 1, 5
  • C.1, 2, 3, 4, 5
  • D.2, 3, 5, 1, 4
Correct Answer: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5

Section 53 of the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code, 2016 has established an ordered of priority among creditors, which will determine the sequence in which outstanding debts will be repaid. This is as follows:

1. Insolvency Resolution Process and liquidation costs;

2. Workmen’s dues (for 24 months preceding liquidation commencement date), and debts owed to a secured creditor, if the security has been relinquished;

3. Employees’ dues (for 12 months preceding liquidation commencement date);

4. Unsecured financial creditors;

5. Government dues, and unpaid dues to secured creditor, if the security has been realized;

6. Remaining debts and dues (which include, unsecured operational debts);

7. Preference shareholders; and

8. Equity shareholders.

 

Accordingly, option C is correct.

Question 6
Match List IwithList II: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2021)List I (Method)(a) Lump-sum payment method(b) Net Assets Method(c) Net Payment Method(d) Swap Ratio MethodList II (Purchase consideration)(i) Calculated by adding up the total amount (money value) of existing shares, preference shares and cash received from the purchasing company for the shareholders of the vendor company.(ii) On the basis of ratio in which the shares of the transferee company are to be exchanged for the shares of the transferor company(iii) The amount to be paid by the transferee company to transferor company for amalgamation of its business(iv) Arrived at by adding the agreed value of assets taken over and deducting there from the agreed values of liabilities.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.(a)-(iii), (b)-(ii), (c)-(i), (d)-(iv)
  • B.(a)-(iii), (b)-(iv), (c)-(i), (d)-(ii)
  • C.(a)-(iv), (b)-(i), (c)-(ii), (d)-(iii)
  • D.(a)-(iv), (b)-(ii), (c)-(ii), (d)-(i)
Correct Answer: (a)-(iii), (b)-(iv), (c)-(i), (d)-(ii)

List I (Method) – List II (Purchase consideration)

(a) Lump-sum payment method - The amount to be paid by the transferee company to transferor company for amalgamation of its business.

 

(b) Net Assets Method - Arrived at by adding the agreed value of assets taken over and deducting there from the agreed values of liabilities.

 

(c) Net Payment Method - Calculated by adding up the total amount (money value) of existing shares, preference shares and cash received from the purchasing company for the shareholders of the vendor company.

 

(d) Swap Ratio Method - On the basis of ratio in which the shares of the transferee company are to be exchanged for the shares of the transferor company.

Question 7
When the value of “Investment in subsidiary” in the holding company’s balance sheet is more than the book value of the net assets acquired, the difference represents (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2021)
  • A.Capital reserve on consolidation
  • B.Goodwill on consolidation
  • C.Minority Interest
  • D.Post acquisitionprofit
Correct Answer: Goodwill on consolidation

When the value of "Investment in Subsidiary" in the holding company's Balance Sheet is more than the book value of the net assets acquired, the difference represents "Goodwill on Consolidation". In this case, Investment in Subsidiary will not cancel out against the share capital of the subsidiary unless a goodwill equal to the difference of the two items is shown on the assets side of the Consolidated Balance Sheet. 

 

Conversely, if the value of Investment in Subsidiary is less than the book value of the net assets acquired, the difference represents Capital Reserve on Consolidation. In this case also, Investment in Subsidiary will not cancel out against the share capital of the subsidiary unless a capital reserve equal to the difference of the two items is shown on the liabilities side of the Consolidated Balance Sheet. 

 

To calculate goodwill or capital reserve, the value of the net assets acquired by the holding company in the subsidiary company must be compared with the cost of the investment. This value can be ascertained by adding together proportionate share capital and reserve of the subsidiary. Goodwill on consolidation arises when holding company consider that subsidiary is worth more than the book value of its net assets. This leads one to believe that those assets can earn super profits and the difference between the real value and the book value is termed as goodwill. On the other hand, capital reserve arises when the shares are purchased by the holding company at a price less than the book value of the net assets acquired.

Question 8
In case the purchasing company agrees to act as the agent of the vendor for collection of the book debts, in the books of the purchasing company, the amount of debtors should be credited to (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2021)
  • A.Vendor’s debtors’ account
  • B.Vendor’s suspense account
  • C.Debtors account
  • D.Creditors account
Correct Answer: Vendor’s suspense account

A company may start an entirely new business or it may start with buying an existing business, either that of a partnership or of a limited company.

 

Often, a company does not take over the debtors and creditors belonging to the vendor but merely agrees to collect the debts and pay the creditors on behalf of the vendor. This means that any profit or loss made in the process will belong to the vendor.

 

Following entries will be passed, at the time of the acquisition of the business:

 

Debit Vendors’ Debtors at the book value.

Credit Vendors’ Creditors at the book value.

Credit Vendors’ Suspense Account with the difference.

 

Note: The Debtors and Creditors, in this case, will not be included when the main entries for purchase of business are passed.

Question 9
Which of the following is NOT a method for calculating or ascertaining the amount of purchase consideration? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2019)
  • A.Net Payment Method
  • B.Net Assets Method
  • C.Gross Receipts Method
  • D.Share Exchange Method
Correct Answer: Gross Receipts Method

In case of amalgamation, purchase consideration is the agreed amount which transferee company (Purchasing company) pays to the transferor company (Vendor company) in exchange of the ownership of the transferor company. It may be in form of cash, shares or any other assets as agreed between both the companies. There are four various methods which can be used in this calculation:

 

1. Net asset method – Purchase consideration is equal to the total net assets of transferor company.

 

Total agreed amount of asset – Total agreed amount of liabilities

 

2. Net payment method – Payment made to the shareholders of transferor company in form of cash, shares or debentures.

 

3. Lump sum method – Fixed amount paid by the transferee company to the transferor company. This method does not require any calculation as the amount is decided by mutual consent of both the companies.

 

4. Intrinsic value/ Share exchange method – It is calculated by dividing the net asset value of transferor company by price of one share of transferee company. The result figure then divided by number of existing shares of transferor company to find out the ratio.

 

Intrinsic value – Net asset / Number of equity shares.

Question 10
Merger of two companies under the Board for Industrial and Financial Reconstruction (BIFR) supervision is known as (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2018)
  • A.Negotiated merger
  • B.Offer for sale
  • C.Reverse merger
  • D.Arranged merger
Correct Answer: Arranged merger

Merger of two companies under the Board for Industrial and Financial Reconstruction (BIFR) supervision is known as Arranged Merger.

 

Mergers and acquisitions (M&A) are defined as consolidation of companies. Differentiating the two terms, Mergers is the combination of two companies to form one, while Acquisitions is one company taken over by the other. M&A is one of the major aspects of corporate finance world. The reasoning behind M&A generally given is that two separate companies together create more value compared to being on an individual stand. With the objective of wealth maximization, companies keep evaluating different opportunities through the route of merger or acquisition.

 

Merger or amalgamation may take two forms: merger through absorption or merger through consolidation. Mergers can also be classified into three types from an economic perspective depending on the business combinations, whether in the same industry or not, into horizontal (two firms are in the same industry), vertical (at different production stages or value chain) and conglomerate (unrelated industries). From a legal perspective, there are different types of mergers like short form merger, statutory merger, subsidiary merger and merger of equals.

 

Reasons for Mergers and Acquisitions:

•Financial synergy for lower cost of capital

•Improving company’s performance and accelerate growth

•Economies of scale

•Diversification for higher growth products or markets

•To increase market share and positioning giving broader market access

•Strategic realignment and technological change

•Tax considerations

•Under-valued target

•Diversification of risk

 

Arranged Merger: The revival and rehabilitation of sick industrial units is governed by Sick Industrial Companies (Special Provisions) Act, 1985 (“SICA”) and it constituted Board for Industrial and Financial Reconstruction (“BIFR”) for this purpose. One of the significant powers of BIFR is to sanction a scheme of amalgamation/re‐organization/takeover of management between a sick unit and a “healthy” company.

 

A 'sick industrial company' means an industrial company that has been registered with the Register of Companies for minimum of five years and at the end of any financial year its accumulated losses is equal to or exceeding its entire net worth (i.e., the sum of the company's paid share capital and free reserves).

 

SICA establishes an elaborate regime to deal with sick industrial units. If a company at any point qualifies under the definition of “sick company” a reference to BIFR is made by its board of directors. BIFR may even on the basis of its own knowledge or any information received about the financial position of any company, can require an Operating Agency (“OA”) to inquire into its working and submit a report. The OA is usually a lead financial institution or bank (such as IDBI, ICICI, IFCI, and SFC) that had financed the unit. After inquiry, if the unit is considered “sick” by BIFR, it may direct OA to recommend measures or prepare a scheme of rehabilitation for the company. A scheme of merger may also be prepared, and such schemes are framed by the OAs in consultation with the companies being merged and the lead bank which takes initiative to decide the terms and conditions of the restructuring.

 

Negotiated Merger- Once the appropriate company is shortlisted through primary screening, detailed analysis of the target company has to be done through the process of due diligence. Once the target company is selected, the next step is to start negotiations to come to consensus for a negotiated merger or a bear hug. This brings both the companies to agree mutually to the deal for the long term working of the M&A. If all the above steps fall in place, there is a formal announcement of the agreement of merger by both the participating companies.

 

Reverse Merger: A reverse merger is a merger in which a private company becomes a public company by acquiring it. It saves a private company from the complicated process and expensive compliance of becoming a public company. Instead, it acquires a public company as an investment and converts itself into a public company. However, there is another angle to the concept of a reverse merger. When a weaker or smaller company acquires a bigger company, it is a reverse merger. In addition, when a parent company merges into its subsidiary or a loss-making company acquires a profit-making company, it is also termed as a reverse merger. For example, Merging of Godrej Soaps, profitable and with a turnover of Rs. 437 crore with loss-making Gujarat Godrej Innovative Chemicals with a turnover of Rs. 60 crore, the resulting firm was named Godrej Soaps. The reason for reverse merger are:

• To carry forward tax losses of the smaller firm, this allows the combined entity to pay lower taxes. Tax savings under Income Tax Act, 1961.

• Economies of scale of production

• Marketing network

• To protect the trademark rights, licence agreements, assets of small/loss making company

 

Offer for sale (OFS) is a simpler method of share sale through the exchange platform for listed companies. The mechanism was first introduced by India’s securities market regulator SEBI, in 2012, to make it easier for promoters of publicly-traded companies to cut their holdings and comply with the minimum public shareholding norms by June 2013. The method was largely adopted by listed companies, both state-run and private, to adhere to the SEBI order. Later, the government started using this route to divest its shareholding in public sector enterprises. Unlike a follow-on public offering (FPO), where companies can raise funds by issuing fresh shares or promoters can sell their existing stakes, or both, the OFS mechanism is used only when existing shares are put on the block. Only promoters or shareholders holding more than prescribed per cent of the share capital in a company can come up with such an issue.

Question 11
X Ltd. forfeited 40 shares of Rs.10 each and on which Rs.4 per share was paid. If the forfeited shares are reissued as Rs.8 per share paid up, what is the minimum price the company must charge? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2018)
  • A.Rs.2 per share
  • B.Rs.10 per share
  • C.Rs. 4 per share
  • D.Rs. 8 per share
Correct Answer: Rs. 4 per share

Shares are forfeited because only a part of the due amount of such shares is received and the balance remains unpaid. On forfeiture the membership of the original allottee is cancelled. He/she cannot be asked to make payment of the remaining amount. Such shares become the property of the company. Therefore, company may sell these shares. Such sale of shares is called ‘reissue of shares. Thus, reissue of shares means issue of forfeited shares.

 

Once the Board of directors has forfeited the shares, the defaulting shareholder is asked to return the share certificate which is cancelled thereafter. The board of directors passes a resolution allotting the forfeited shares to the new purchaser/purchasers of such shares. In case of reissue of shares neither a prospectus is issued nor is any offer otherwise made to the general public. Though the amount of such shares may be called in more than one instalment but usually the entire amount is called in one instalment i.e. lumpsum.

 

The board of directors of the company while reissuing the shares decide the price of reissue. These shares can be reissued at par, at premium or at discount. Generally, these shares are reissued at a discount i.e. at a price which is less than its nominal value. The amount of discount allowed at the time of reissue in no case should be more than the amount forfeited on such shares.

 

Question arises at what price the forfeited shares can be reissued? There is no limit of the price at which it can be reissued if price charged is more than the price of issue at the time of their forfeiture. But then there is a limit below which price cannot be charged or we can say that there is a minimum price below which the company cannot reissue its forfeited shares. We can look at it from another angle i.e., the company cannot give discount more than a particular amount while reissuing the forfeited shares.

 

The maximum permissible discount at the time of reissue of forfeited shares is ascertained in different situations in the following manner:

(i) Shares originally issued at par: When the shares are originally issued at par, the maximum permissible discount for reissue of shares is equal to the amount forfeited on such shares. And here in the question the amount forfeited is 4; hence, 4 is the minimum price that the company can charge.

(ii) Shares originally issued at premium: In case of shares originally issued at premium, there can be two situations :(A) premium has not been received on the forfeited shares, and(B) premium has been received on such shares. The amount forfeited is the amount that has been received including the amount of premium if it has been received and the maximum discount that can be allowed on reissue of such shares is the amount so forfeited.

(iii) Shares originally issued at discount: In this case the actual amount received becomes the forfeited amount. But the maximum permissible discount on reissue of shares will be equal to the amount forfeited plus the amount of discount initially allowed on these shares at the time of their original issue.

Question 12
Arrange the following liabilities in the order of company balance sheet. (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2011)(i) Bank Overdraft(ii) Bank Loan(iii) Share Capital(iv) Provision for Taxation
  • A.i, ii, iii, iv
  • B.iv, iii, ii,i
  • C.iii, ii,i, iv
  • D.iii, ii, iv,i
Correct Answer: iii, ii, iv,i

The correct sequence of liabilities in the order of company balance sheet:

(a) Share Capital

(b) Bank Loan

(c) Provision for Taxation

(d) Bank Overdraft.

Question 13
Intrinsic value of a share is given by (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2011)
  • A.TotalNetassetsNo.ofshares
  • B.TotalassetsNo.ofshares
  • C.SharecapitalNo.ofshares
  • D.MarketCapitalisationNo.ofshares
Correct Answer: TotalNetassetsNo.ofshares

Under intrinsic value method, intrinsic value per share is calculated as follows.

Total assets taken over at their agreed values

xxx

Less: Total liabilities taken over at their agreed values

xxx

Total purchase consideration (A)

xxx

No. of Equity Shares (B)

xxx

Intrinsic Value per Share (A) ÷ (B)

xxx

Thus, correct answer is option A.

Question 14
The following relate to the shares of a company. What is the correct order? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2011)
  • A.Issue, Application, Call and Forfeiture.
  • B.Application, Call, Forfeiture, and Issue.
  • C.Call, Issue, Application and Forfeiture.
  • D.Forfeiture, Application, Issue and Call.
Correct Answer: Issue, Application, Call and Forfeiture.

The correct answer is option A.

Issue: The first step is the issuance of shares. This involves offering shares to the public or a specific group of investors.

 

Application: Interested investors apply for the shares by submitting application forms along with the necessary payment.

 

Call: After the application stage, the company may make a call for the payment of the remaining amount on the shares. This may be done in installments.

 

Forfeiture: If a shareholder fails to make the required payments (calls), the company may forfeit their shares. Forfeiture involves canceling the shares of non-compliant shareholders.

Question 15
If the purchase consideration is calculated by adding the various payments to be made, the method is called (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2011)
  • A.Lump-sum method
  • B.Net-worth method
  • C.Net-payments method
  • D.Value of shares method
Correct Answer: Net-payments method

Following are the methods of computing purchase consideration:

 

1. Net Payment Method: Under this method, all the payments made to the shareholders of the transferor company are aggregated to obtain purchase consideration. The payment may be in the form of shares, debentures, other securities or cash. As per AS 14, only the payment made to shareholders is to be considered.

 

2. Net Assets Method: This is also known as Net-worth Method. This method is used only when the Net Payment Method is not adopted.

 

Under this method, Purchase consideration = Assets taken over of new value less Liabilities over of new value.

 

Miscellaneous expenditure, reserves and surplus, debit balances of Profit and Loss Account is not included while calculation of purchase consideration. Only external liabilities must be taken into consideration.

 

3. Share Exchange Method: In this method, shares of the transferee company are issued to shareholders of transferor company on the basis of certain ratio. The shares may be exchanged at intrinsic value or market value. Fractional shares should be valued on the same basis as the rest of the shares issued.

Question 16
The funds available with a company after paying all claims including tax and dividend is called (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2012)
  • A.Net Profit
  • B.Net Operating Profit
  • C.Capital Profit
  • D.Retained Earnings
Correct Answer: Retained Earnings

Retained Earnings: A portion of company’s net profit after paying tax and dividend which is kept aside and not distributed as profit is called retained earnings. The main purpose of retainedearnings is reinvestment during the recession or depression period and to meet the daily needs of the business. This is also called source of self-financing.

 

A Capital profit refers to profit that results from a sale of a capital asset, such as stock, bond or real estate, where the sale price exceeds the purchase price. The gain is the difference between a higher selling price and a lower purchase price.

 

Net Profit is the residual income left with the company after all deductions.

 

Operating Profit is the income of the company left after paying off operating expenses.

Question 17
In a reconstruction scheme, the reduction of capital may take the form of (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2013)
  • A.Reducing the liability of the shareholders in respect of any unpaid amount on the shares held by them.
  • B.Paying-off any paid-up share capital which is in excess of its requirement.
  • C.Cancelling any paid-up share capital which is lost or unrepresented by available assets.
  • D.All of the above.
Correct Answer: All of the above.

According to Section 66 of the Companies Act, 2013, subject to confirmation by the Tribunal on an application by the company, a company limited by shares or limited by guarantee and having a share capital may, by a special resolution, reduce the share capital in any manner and in, particular, may—

 

(a) extinguish or reduce the liability on any of its shares in respect of the share capital not paid-up; or

 

(b) either with or without extinguishing or reducing liability on any of its shares:

 

(i) cancel any paid-up share capital which is lost or is unrepresented by available assets; or

 

(ii) pay off any paid-up share capital which is in excess of the wants of the company,

 

alter its memorandum by reducing the amount of its share capital and of its shares accordingly.

 

However, no such reduction shall be made if the company is in arrears in the repayment of any deposits accepted by it, either before or after the commencement of this Act, or the interest payable thereon.

 

Thus, option D is the correct answer.

Question 18
ABC Ltd was incorporated with an authorised Share Capital of ₹ 1,00,000equity shares of ₹ 10 each. The Board of Directors of the company decided to allot 10,000 shares credited as fully paid to the promoters of the company for their services. Which account should be debited in the books of ABC Ltd.? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2013)
  • A.Promoters’ Account
  • B.Services Account
  • C.Goodwill Account
  • D.Share Capital Account
Correct Answer: Goodwill Account

Goodwill Account is to be debited as shares are credited as fully paid to the promoters of the company.

Question 19
Which of the following items is not an appropriation of profit for a limited company? (UGC NET Commerce Sep 2013)
  • A.Corporate tax payable
  • B.Ordinary dividend payable
  • C.Debenture interest payable
  • D.Preference dividend payable
Correct Answer: Debenture interest payable

The return on shares is known as dividend while the return on debentures is called interest. The rate of return on shares may vary from year to year depending upon the profits of the company but the rate of interest on debentures is prefixed. The payment of dividend is an appropriation of profits, whereas the payment of interest is a charge on profits and is to be paid even if there is no profit.

Question 20
If there is mutual indebtedness between the transferor company and the transferee company in business combination, which of the following is correct? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2013)
  • A.No adjustment is required in the books of the transferor company.
  • B.Adjustment is required in the books of the transferor company.
  • C.No adjustment is required in the books of the transferee company.
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: No adjustment is required in the books of the transferor company.

If there is mutual indebtedness between the transferor company and the transferee company in business combination, then no adjustment is required in the books of the transferor company and journal entries shall be passed in the books of transferee company, such as,

 

Sundry Creditors A/c Dr.

To Sundry Debtors A/c

Question 21
Assertion ‘A’:Dividend paid out of pre-acquisition profit by the subsidiary company to the holding company is deducted from the cost of investment.Reason ‘R’:Dividend paid out of pre-acquisition profit by the subsidiary company should be treated as a return of capital to the holding company.Which one of the following is correct? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2013)
  • A.Both ‘A’ and ‘R’ are correct.
  • B.‘A’ is correct, but ‘R’ is wrong.
  • C.‘A’ is wrong, but ‘R’ is correct.
  • D.Both ‘A’ and ‘R’ are wrong.
Correct Answer: Both ‘A’ and ‘R’ are correct.

Both ‘A’ and ‘R’ are correct.

 

During the first time, when the holding company receive any kind of dividend out of preacquisition from its subsidiary company. The following journal entries are recorded.

1) Bank A/c Dr.

To Shares in Subsidiary Company

(Being dividend received from Subsidiary Company out of pre-acquisition required)

 

2) Dividend Received from Subsidiary Company A/c Dr.

To Profit & Loss A/c

(Transfer of dividend from subsidiary company to profit & Loss Account).

Question 22
Match the items of the following two lists: (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2013)List – I(i) Zero-base Budgeting(ii) Goodwill or Capital Reserve(iii) Reduction of Capital(iv) Basic & DilutedList – II(a) Internal Reconstruction(b) Earnings Per Share(c) Control of Expenditure(d) Business CombinationCodes:
  • A.i-c, ii-d, iii-b, iv-a
  • B.i-d, ii-c, iii-a, iv-b
  • C.i-d, ii-a, iii-c, iv-b
  • D.i-c, ii-d, iii-a, iv-b
Correct Answer: i-c, ii-d, iii-a, iv-b

List – I - List – II

(i) Zero-base Budgeting - Control of Expenditure

ZBB is a budgeting approach where each expense must be justified from scratch, helping in a thorough examination and control of expenditure to ensure efficiency.

 

(ii) Goodwill or Capital Reserve - Business Combination

Goodwill or Capital Reserve is often associated with Business Combination, reflecting the excess value paid over the fair value of net assets acquired during the combination.

 

(iii) Reduction of Capital - Internal Reconstruction

Reduction of Capital is a step in Internal Reconstruction, where a company reorganizes its capital structure, often involving a decrease in the nominal value of its shares.

 

(iv) Basic & Diluted - Earnings Per Share

asic & Diluted represent different calculations of Earnings Per Share, a financial metric that indicates the portion of a company's profit allocated to each outstanding share of common stock.

Question 23
X Ltd. forfeited 20 shares of ₹ 10 each, ₹ 8 called up, on which John had paid application and allotment money of ₹ 5 per share, of these, 15 shares were reissued to Parker as fully paid up for ₹ 6 per share. What is the balance in the share Forfeiture Account after the relevant amount has been transferred to Capital Reserve Account? (UGC NET Commerce Jul 2018)
  • A.NIL
  • B.₹ 5
  • C.₹ 25
  • D.₹ 100
Correct Answer: ₹ 25

In the given case, the company forfeits 20 shares of Rs. 10 each on which Rs. 100 (20 × 5) had been received. The company reissues 15 shares for Rs. 90 (@ Rs. 6 per share), the necessary journal entries will be:

 

Share Capital A/c (20 × Rs. 8) Dr. Rs. 160

To Share Forfeiture A/c (20 × 5)Rs. 100

To Shares Calls A/c (20 × 3)Rs. 60

(Being 20 shares of Rs. 10 each, Rs. 8 called-up forfeited for non-payment of call)

 

Bank A/c (15 × Rs. 6)Dr. Rs. 90

Share Forfeiture A/c (15 × 4)Dr. Rs. 60

To Share Capital A/c (15 × Rs. 10) Rs. 150

(Being Reissue of 15 forfeited shares at Rs. 6 per share as fully paid)

 

Share Forfeiture A/c Dr. Rs. 15

To Capital Reserve Rs. 15

(Being balance in shares forfeitures account of 1,000 re-issue, transferred to capital reserve account)

 

Working Notes

Profit on 20 shares (20 × 5) = 100

 

Profit on 15 shares (15 × 5) = 75

Less: Loss on Reissue (15 × 4) = 60

Amount to be transferred to Capital Reserve = Rs. 15

 

Amount left in share forfeiture = No. of shares not re-issued × Amount paid per share

= 5 × 5 = 25

Question 24
Which one of the following statements is not true? (UGC NET Commerce Nov 2017)
  • A.When there is one liquidation and one formation it is known as external construction
  • B.Goodwill or Capital reserve arises only when the amalgamation is in the nature of merger
  • C.Under the pooling of interest method, the transferee company incorporates the assets and liabilities of the transferor company at book value
  • D.The vendor company transfers preliminary expenses (at the time of absorption) to equity shareholders’ account
Correct Answer: Goodwill or Capital reserve arises only when the amalgamation is in the nature of merger

Statement 1 is true. When a company is suffering losses for the past several years and facing financial crisis, the company can sell its business to another newly formed company. Actually, the new company is formed to take over the assets and liabilities of the old company. This process is called external reconstruction. In other words, external reconstruction refers to the sale of the business of existing company to another company formed for the purpose. In external reconstruction, one company is liquidated and another new company is formed. The liquidated company is called "Vendor Company" and the new company is called "Purchasing Company". Shareholders of Vendor Company become the shareholders of Purchasing Company.

 

Statement II is not correct. As per AS-14, goodwill or capital reserve are created/accounted where the amalgamation is in the 'nature of purchase'.

 

Statement III is correct. Pooling of Interest Method of accounting is one in which the assets, liabilities and reserves are combined and shown at their historical values, as on the date of amalgamation.

 

Statement IV is correct. At the time of absorption, the vendor company transfers preliminary expenses to equity shareholders’ account.

Question 25
A Ltd. issued a prospectus inviting applications for 2,000 shares. Applications were received for 3,000 shares and pro-rata allotment was made on the applications of 2,400 shares. If A has been allotted 40 shares, how many shares he must have applied for? (UGC NET Commerce Nov 2017)
  • A.40
  • B.44
  • C.48
  • D.52
Correct Answer: 48

By following the simple unitary method, shares applied by Mr. A, who was allotted shares 40 shares:

 

= Number of shares allotted × Total shares appliedTotal shares allotted

 

= 40 × 24002000 = 48 shares

Question 26
The directors of X Ltd. resolved to forfeit 2000 equity shares of ₹ 10 each. On these shares ₹ 7.50 per share was paid up, but final call of ₹ 2.50 per share was unpaid. 1,000 of the forfeited shares were reissued at 7 per share. Capital Reserve Account will be credited by (UGC NET Commerce Aug 2016)
  • A.₹ 4,500
  • B.₹ 7,500
  • C.₹ 2,500
  • D.₹ 5,000
Correct Answer: ₹ 4,500

In the given case, the company forfeits 2000 shares of Rs. 10 each on which Rs. 15,000 (2000 × 7.5) had been received. The company reissues 1000 shares for Rs. 7,000 (@ Rs. 7 per share), the necessary journal entries will be:

 

Share Capital A/c (2000 × Rs. 10) Dr. Rs. 20,000

To Share Forfeiture A/c (2,000 × 7.5)Rs. 15,000

To Shares Calls A/c (2,000 × 2.5)Rs. 5,000

(Being 2000 shares of Rs. 10 each forfeited for non-payment of calls)

 

Bank A/c (1000 × Rs. 7)Dr. Rs. 7,000

Share Forfeiture A/c (1000 × 3)Dr. Rs. 3,000

To Share Capital A/c (1000 × Rs. 10) Rs. 10,000

(Being Reissue of 1000 forfeited shares at Rs. 7 per share as fully paid)

 

Share Forfeiture A/c Dr. Rs. 4,500

To Capital Reserve Rs. 4,500

(Being balance in shares forfeitures account of 1,000 re-issue, transferred to capital reserve account)

 

Working Notes

Share Forfeiture (Cr.) Rs. 7.5

Share Forfeiture (Dr.)Rs. 3

Balance in Share Forfeiture Account after re-issue (per share) (Cr.) = 4.5

 

Calculation of Capital Reserve

= Number of shares reissued × Balance in Share Forfeiture Account after re-issue (per share)

= 1000 × 4.5 = Rs. 4,500

Question 27
Equity shareholders are:
  • A.Creditors
  • B.Owners
  • C.Customers of the company
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Owners

Equity Shareholders are Owners of the Company.

Question 28
Reserve capital means ___________.
  • A.The part of subscribed uncalled capital which will be called up at the time of liquidation only
  • B.Accumulated Profits
  • C.The part of Capital Reserve
  • D.The part of Capital Redemption Reserve
Correct Answer: The part of subscribed uncalled capital which will be called up at the time of liquidation only

Option A is correct. The company may decide by passing a special resolution that a portion of the uncalled amount shall not be called up by the company except in case of winding up or liquidation. This is called reserve capital.

Question 29
Shares can be forfeited:
  • A.For non-payment of call money
  • B.For failure to attend meetings
  • C.For failure to repay the loan to the bank
  • D.For which shares are pledged as a security
Correct Answer: For non-payment of call money

Shares can be forfeited for non-payment of call money.

 

It may happen that some shareholders fail to pay one or more instalments, viz. allotment money and/or call money. In such circumstances, the company can forfeit their shares, i.e. cancel their allotment and treat the amount already received thereon as forfeited to the company within the framework of the provisions in its articles.

 

The effect of forfeiture of shares is that the defaulting shareholder loses all his rights in the forfeited shares and ceases to be a member of the company. The name of the shareholder is removed from the Register of Members and the amount already paid by him is forfeited. He is not entitled in future to dividends and rights of membership.

Question 30
G Ltd. acquired assets worthRs. 750000 from H. Ltd. by issue of shares ofRs. 100 each at a premium of 25%. The number of shares to be issued by G. Ltd., to settle the purchase consideration will be _______.
  • A.6000 shares
  • B.7500 shares
  • C.9375 shares
  • D.5625 shares
Correct Answer: 6000 shares

Value of assets acquired by G Ltd. = 750000

 

Issue price per share = Nominal value + Premium amount = 100 + (25100 × 100) = 125

 

Therefore, the number of shares to be issued by G. Ltd., to settle the purchase consideration

= Value of assetsIssue price per share = 750000125 = 6000 shares.

Question 31
Nominal share capital is:
  • A.That part of the authorized capital which is issued by the company.
  • B.The amount of capital which is actually applied for by the prospective shareholders.
  • C.The maximum amount of share capital which a company is authorized to issue.
  • D.The amount actually paid by the shareholders.
Correct Answer: The maximum amount of share capital which a company is authorized to issue.

Nominal Share Capital or Authorized Capital is the maximum limit of capital which the company is authorized to raise.

Question 32
“A” Assertion: Premium received on issue of shares is credited to share premium account but not to Profit and Loss account. (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2012)“R” Reasoning: Since share premium is not a trading profit, it is not distributed to shareholders.
  • A.Both “A” and “R” are true but “R” is not correct explanation to “A”.
  • B.“A” is false but “R” is correct.
  • C.Both “A” and “R” are true and “R” is correct explanation of “A”.
  • D.“A” is correct but “R” is false.
Correct Answer: Both “A” and “R” are true and “R” is correct explanation of “A”.

Both “A” and “R” are true and “R” is correct explanation of “A”.

 

As per the Companies Act, 2013, when a company issues shares at a premium, whether for cash or otherwise, a sum equal to the aggregate amount of the premium collected on shares must be credited to a separate account called “Securities Premium Account.” The premium on issue of shares is not to be treated as revenue profits. In fact, it is considered as capital receipt.

 

There are no restrictions in the Companies Act on the issue of shares at a premium, but there are certain restrictions at the time of its disposal or use.

 

Restrictions on application of premium money received are provided under Section 52 (2) of the Companies Act, 2013. As per this Section, Securities Premium Account may be applied by the company:

(a) towards the issue of unissued shares of the company to the members of the company as fully paid bonus shares;

(b) in writing off the preliminary expenses of the company;

(c) in writing off the expenses of, or the commission paid or discount allowed on, any issue of shares or debentures of the company;

(d) in providing for the premium payable on the redemption of any redeemable preference shares or of any debentures of the company; or

(e) for the purchase of its own shares or other securities under section 68.

 

It is to be noted that utilization of the amount of Securities Premium Account except in any of the modes specified above, will attract the provisions relating to the reduction of share capital of a company under Section 66 of the Companies Act, 2013.

 

The Securities Premium Account must be shown as “Securities premium reserves” separately on the liabilities side of the balance sheet under the head “Reserves & Surplus”.

Question 33
Which of the following isnota major advantage of a corporate form of organization?
  • A.Separate legal existence
  • B.Continuous life
  • C.Government regulations
  • D.Transferable ownership rights
Correct Answer: Government regulations

Government regulations are a disadvantage of a corporation. The other options are advantages of a corporation.

Question 34
XY LTD. issued 25000 equity shares ofRs. 100 each at a premium ofRs. 15 each payable asRs. 25 on application,Rs. 40 on allotment and balance in the first call. Applications received for 75000 equity shares but the company issued to them only 25000 shares. Excess money was refunded to them after adjustment for further calls. Last call on 500 shares were not received and were forfeited after due notice. The above is the case of __________.
  • A.Over subscription
  • B.Pro-rata allotment
  • C.Forfeiture of shares
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: All of the above

In the above question, number of shares issued are 25000. But, applications are received for 75000 shares. Therefore, this is a case of over subscription.

An issue is said to be oversubscribed when the number of shares applied for is more than the number of shares offered to the public.

 

Applications are received for 75000 shares but only 25000 shares are allotted to them. Therefore, this is a case of pro rata allotment.

Pro-rata allotment means that only a proportion of the shares applied for are allotted. When a company makes pro-rata allotment, it adjusts the excess money received at the time of application towards the allotment and then towards calls.

 

Also, the shares were forfeited since money was not received on last call of 500 shares. Therefore, this is also a case of forfeiture of shares.

Some shareholders may fail to pay one or more instalments, viz. allotment money and/or call money. In such circumstances, the company can forfeit their shares, i.e. cancel their allotment and treat the amount already received thereon as forfeited to the company within the framework of the provisions in its articles.

The effect of forfeiture of shares is that the defaulting shareholder loses all his rights in the forfeited shares and ceases to be a member of the company. The name of the shareholder is removed from the Register of Members and the amount already paid by him is forfeited. He is not entitled in future to dividends and rights of membership.

Question 35
Match the following and indicate the correct code:List I(A) Mergers resulting in economies achieved primarily by eliminating the duplicate facilities(B) Mergers resulting in the expansion of the company’s business towards ultimate consumer or source of raw material(C) Mergers in an unrelated line of businessList II(i) Conglomerate Merger(ii) Horizontal Merger(iii) Vertical MergerCodes:
  • A.(A)-(i), (B)-(ii), (C)-(iii)
  • B.(A)-(ii), (B)-(iii), (C)-(i)
  • C.(A)-(iii), (B)-(i), (C)-(ii)
  • D.(A)-(iii), (B)-(ii), (C)-(i)
Correct Answer: (A)-(ii), (B)-(iii), (C)-(i)

List I – List II

(A) Mergers resulting in economies achieved primarily by eliminating the duplicate facilities – Horizontal Merger

(B) Mergers resulting in the expansion of the company’s business towards ultimate consumer or source of raw material – Vertical Merger

(C) Mergers in an unrelated line of business – Conglomerate Merger

Question 36
Match the following: (UGC NET Management Dec 2015)List - I (Items/Methods)a. Purchase Considerationb. Written Down Value Methodc. LIFO methodd. Rate of Return MethodList - II (Used/Application)i. Marketingii. Store Recordingiii. Depreciationiv. Capital Budgetingv. MergerCodes:
  • A.(a)- (iv), (b)-(iii), (c)-(v), (d)-(i)
  • B.(a)- (i), (b)-(iii), (c)-(iv), (d)-(v)
  • C.(a)- (i), (b)-(v), (c)-(ii), (d)-(iii)
  • D.(a)- (v), (b)-(iii), (c)-(ii), (d)-(iv)
Correct Answer: (a)- (v), (b)-(iii), (c)-(ii), (d)-(iv)

The correct match is as follows.

List - I (Items/Methods) - List - II (Used/Application)

a. Purchase Consideration - Merger

b. Written Down Value Method - Depreciation

c. LIFO method - Store Recording

d. Rate of Return Method – Capital Budgeting

Question 37
Given below are two statements: (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2022)One is labelled as Assertion A and the other is labelled as Reason R.Assertion ‘A’:When holding company holds more than 50% (but not whole) shares of a company, then the holders of the rest of shares will be known as "Minority".Reason ‘R’:Minority interest is calculated by considering proportionate shares and reserves of Holding Company.In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:Codes :
  • A.Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A.
  • B.Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A.
  • C.A is true but R is false.
  • D.A is false but R is true.
Correct Answer: A is true but R is false.

A is true but R is false. The minority interest is calculated by considering proportionate shares and reserves of the subsidiary company, not the holding company.

 

Question 38
Amalgamation adjustment account is used for recording: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2021)
  • A.Capital Reserve in the books of the transferee company
  • B.General Reserve in the books of the transferee company
  • C.Statutory Reserve in the books of the transferee company
  • D.Revenue Reserve in the books of the transferee company
Correct Answer: Statutory Reserve in the books of the transferee company

Amalgamation adjustment account is used for recording Statutory Reserve in the books of the transferee company.

According to Accounting Standard 14, “Accounting for amalgamation” issued by ICAI, an amalgamation adjustment account arises when certain statutory reserves need to be maintained by the transferee company which was previously maintained in the books of transferor company. Examples of statutory reserves are – investment allowance reserves, development rebate reserve, export profits reserves etc.

Question 39
Fill in the blanks. (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2021)For a holding company, all pre‐acquisition profits/losses of the subsidiary company are ______, while all post‐ acquisition profits/losses of the subsidiary company are _________.
  • A.revenue profits/losses, capital profits/losses
  • B.capital profits, capital losses
  • C.revenue profits, revenue losses
  • D.capital profits/losses, revenue profit/losses
Correct Answer: capital profits/losses, revenue profit/losses

For a holding company, all pre‐acquisition profits/losses of the subsidiary company are capital profits/losses and included in the capital reserves to be adjusted against Goodwill, if any.

While all post‐ acquisition profits/losses of the subsidiary company are revenue profit/losses. It is thus, added to the profits and loss balance of the holding company in the consolidated balance sheet.

Quiz Attempt #119246

Total Questions: 40
Question 1
This consists of two lists of statements or terms and the candidate has to match an item in one list with an item in the other: (UGC NET Management Jun 2013)List-I (Statement)(i) Preventing hostile takeover(ii) Leveraged buyout(iii) Accounting for merger(iv) Financing for mergerList-II (Terms)(a) Management buyout(b) Green mail(c) Pooling of interest(d) Cash offerCodes:
  • A.(i)-(a), (ii)-(b), (iii)-(c), (iv)-(d)
  • B.(i)-(b), (ii)-(a), (iii)-(d), (iv)-(c)
  • C.(i)-(b), (ii)-(a), (iii)-(c), (iv)-(d)
  • D.(i)-(c), (ii)-(d), (iii)-(b), (iv)-(a)
Correct Answer: (i)-(b), (ii)-(a), (iii)-(c), (iv)-(d)

List-I (Statement) – List II (Terms)

(i) Preventing hostile takeover – Green Mail

Greenmail is a buyout by the target of its own shares from the hostile acquirer with a premium over the market price, which results in the acquirer’s agreement not to pursue obtaining control of the target in the near future. In other words, committing Greenmail involves buying a significant number of shares in a target company, threatening a hostile takeover, and then using the threat to force the target company to buy back the shares at a higher price. Similar to blackmail, which is making threats to establish a benefit, greenmail is money that is paid to another company to prevent aggressive behavior (i.e. an unwanted takeover).

 

(ii) Leveraged buyout – Management Buyout

Leveraged buyout (LBO) is a financial transaction in which a company is purchased with a combination of equity and debt, such that the company's cash flow is the collateral used to secure and repay the borrowed money. The use of debt, which normally has a lower cost of capital than equity, serves to reduce the overall cost of financing the acquisition. The assets of the company being acquired are often used as collateral for the loans, along with the assets of the acquiring company. The purpose of leveraged buyouts is to allow companies to make large acquisitions without having to commit a lot of capital. This technique can also be used as a defense against acquisition or hostile takeover as company burdens itself with debt.

 

(iii) Accounting for merger – Pooling of interest

When amalgamation is in the nature of merger the method of accounting used is the pooling of interest method. It is the method of accounting in which the assets, liabilities and reserves are combined and shown at their historical values, as on the date of amalgamation.

 

(iv) Financing for merger- Cash Offer

After the value of the firm to be acquired has been determined, the most straight forward method of making the payment could be by way of offer for cash payment. The major advantage of cash offer is that it will not cause any dilution in the ownership as well as earnings per share of the company.

However, the shareholders of the acquired company will be liable to pay tax on any gains made by them. Another important consideration could be the adverse effect on liquidity position of the company. Thus, only a company having very sound liquidity position may offer cash for financing a merger.

Question 2
Takeover generally involves: (UGC NET Management Dec 2012)
  • A.theacquisition of part of an undertaking to enable the acquirer to increase the market share of the product concerned.
  • B.theacquisition of a certain block of equity capital of a company which enables the acquirer to exercise control over the affairs of the company.
  • C.takingover the responsibility to have trade agreement for the finished product.
  • D.takingover certain long-term liabilities of another group company to help it financially.
Correct Answer: theacquisition of a certain block of equity capital of a company which enables the acquirer to exercise control over the affairs of the company.

A takeover occurs when one company makes a bid to assume control of or acquire another, often by purchasing a majority stake in the target firm. In the takeover process, the company making the bid is the acquirer, while the company it wishes to take control of is called the target.

Question 3
When the target company uses the tactic of divestiture, to defend itself from a hostile takeover, it is said to sell the: (UGC NET Management Jun 2015)
  • A.Crown jewels
  • B.Green mail
  • C.Golden parachutes
  • D.White knight
Correct Answer: Crown jewels

Divestiture (Sell off/Hive off) means an out sale of all or substantially all the assets of the company or any of its business undertakings / divisions, usually for cash (or for a combination of cash and debt) and not against equity shares. In short, divestiture means sale of assets, but not in a piecemeal manner. Divestiture is normally used to mobilize resources for core business or businesses of the company by realizing value of non-core business assets.

When a company is threatened with takeover, the crown jewel defense is a strategy in which the target company sells off its most attractive assets to a friendly third party or spin off the valuable assets in a separate entity. The crown jewel defense is a last-resort defense since the target company will be intentionally destroying part of its value, with the hope that the acquirer drops its hostile bid.

 

The other options of the question ae explained below:

White knight: If the target company wants to avoid a hostile merger, one option is to seek out another company for a more suitable merger. Usually, the target company will enlist the services of an investment banker to locate a "white knight." The White Knight Company comes in and rescues the target company from the hostile takeover attempt.  In order to stop the hostile merger, the White Knight will pay a price more favorable than the price offered by the hostile bidder.

 

Greenmail: Greenmail is a buyout by the target of its own shares from the hostile acquirer with a premium over the market price, which results in the acquirer’s agreement not to pursue obtaining control of the target in the near future. In other words, committing Greenmail involves buying a significant number of shares in a target company, threatening a hostile takeover, and then using the threat to force the target company to buy back the shares at a higher price. Similar to blackmail, which is making threats to establish a benefit, greenmail is money that is paid to another company to prevent aggressive behavior (i.e. an unwanted takeover).

 

Golden parachutes: These are separation clauses of an employment contract that compensate managers who lose their jobs under a change of management scenario. The provision usually calls for a lump-sum payment or payment over a specified period at full and partial rates of normal compensation. Target Companies invoke this provision and pay off a huge compensation to large number of employees so as to make themselves unattractive to the raider.

In other words, Golden parachutes are additional compensations to the target’s top management in the case of termination of its employment following a successful hostile acquisition. Since these compensations decrease the target’s assets, this defense reduces the amount the acquirer is willing to pay for the target’s shares. This defense may thus harm shareholders.

Question 4
Interest is calculated on _______ of securities.
  • A.Market value
  • B.Face value
  • C.Purchase value
  • D.None of the three
Correct Answer: Face value

Option B is correct. Interest is calculated on face value of securities. Face value is also called nominal value or par value of securities.

Question 5
The transfer by a company of one or more of its business divisions to another newly set up company is called ________. (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2013)
  • A.Demerger
  • B.Merger
  • C.Equity Carve-out
  • D.Disinvestment
Correct Answer: Demerger

The question refers to the concept of ‘Corporate Restructuring’, which means any change in the business capacity or portfolio that is carried out by inorganic route or any change in the capital structure of a company that is not in the ordinary course of its business or any change in the ownership of a company or control over its management or a combination of any two or all of the above.

 

Demerger is a form of corporate restructuring in which an entity’s business operations are segregated into one or more components. Demerger can take 3 forms:

 

(i) Spin-off: A company creates a subsidiary company. The shares of the new entity are distributed to the shareholders of the parent company on a pro-rata basis. However, the parent company also retains ownership in the spun-off entity. Spin-offs have 2 approaches that can be followed.

In the first approach, the company distributes all the shares of the new entity to its existing shareholders on a pro rata basis. This leads to the creation of two different companies holding the same proportions of equity as compared to the single company existing previously. The second approach is the floatation of a new entity with its equity being held by the parent company. The parent company later sells the assets of the spun off company to another company.

 

(ii) Split: Splits involve dividing the company into two or more parts. This is done with an aim to maximize profitability by removing stagnant units from the mainstream business. Splits can be of 2 types, Split-ups and Split-offs.

When a company splits itself into two or more entities, it is termed as split-ups. In such cases, the parent company loses its existence. Split-offs is when the shareholders of a parent company surrender their shares in exchange for shares in a subsidiary company. This concept is mainly followed for family businesses when all members cross hold shares in all subsidiaries of the entity. Exchange and conversion of the shares are done to separate the different family streams.

 

(iii) Equity Carve-out: Equity carve-outs are referred to a percentage of shares of the subsidiary company being issued to the public. This method leads to a separation of the assets of the parent company and the subsidiary entity. Equity carve outs result in publicly trading the shares of the subsidiary entity.

The disinvestment occurs when a company boycotts or liquidates stocks. The Disinvestment refers to a process, whereby government/company sells its shares, held in any PSUs, to private sector.

 

Merger / Amalgamation: A merger is a combination of two or more businesses into one business. Laws in India use the term ‘amalgamation’ for merger. Amalgamation is the merger of one or more companies with another or the merger of two or more companies to form a new company, in such a way that all assets and liabilities of the amalgamating companies become assets and liabilities of the amalgamated company.

Merger through Absorption: Absorption is a combination of two or more companies into an ‘existing company’. All companies (except one) lose their identity in such a merger. For example, absorption of Tata Fertilisers Ltd (TFL) by Tata Chemicals Ltd. (TCL).

Merger through Consolidation: A consolidation is a combination of two or more companies into a ‘new company’. In this form of merger, all companies are legally dissolved and a new entity is created. Here, the acquired company transfers its assets, liabilities and shares to the acquiring company for cash or exchange of shares. For example, merger of Hindustan Computers Ltd., Hindustan Instruments Ltd., Indian Software Company Ltd. and Indian Reprographics Ltd. into an entirely new company called HCL Ltd.

Question 6
The Profit on reissue of forfeited shares is transferred to:
  • A.General reserve
  • B.Capital redemption reserve
  • C.Capital reserve
  • D.Revenue reserve
Correct Answer: Capital reserve

The directors can either cancel or re-issue the forfeited shares. In most cases, they reissue such shares which may be at par, at premium or at a discount. Forfeited shares may be reissued as fully paid at a par, premium, discount. In this context, it may be noted that the amount of discount allowed cannot exceed the amount that had been received on forfeited shares at the time of initial issue, and that the discount allowed on reissue of forfeited shares should be debited to the ‘Forfeited Share Account’. The balance, if any, left in the Share-Forfeited Account relating to reissued Shares, should be treated as capital profit and transferred to Capital Reserve Account.

Question 7
Balance of share forfeiture account is shown in the balance sheet under the item:
  • A.Current liabilities and provisions
  • B.Reserves and surpluses
  • C.Share capital
  • D.Unsecured loans
Correct Answer: Share capital

The balance of shares forfeited account is shown as an addition to the total paid-up capital of the company under the head ‘Share Capital’ under title ‘Equity and Liabilities’ of the Balance Sheet till the forfeited shares are reissued.

Question 8
